description:
A tourist trap for sure, but also a must-see if you're in the area. I would suggest that you not purchase any of the attraction passes ahead of time.  The details of how to use the passes are unclear and confusing.  One day there is plenty of time unless you are planning to do more than one tour.  

A sample of tours:  
- Cruise to Alcatraz 
- Bike the bridge
- Cruise around on a boat that takes you under the bridge

Enjoy all the crazy!
author: Alisa C.

description:
I'm a big fan of seafood, but I'm just not really into Fisherman's Wharf food. Last year I went here with a friend and bought some food, and it was just "meh". The calamari was chewy and the fish and chips really didn't taste fresh at all. I love some good fried seafood, but the options here just weren't making my tummy jump for joy. And I love me some fish and chips too!

This recent visit, I literally walked around in circles a few time taking a look into the cases to see if anything really screamed out at me. Nothing!

But this is a must see place of SF. It's just one of those must see touristy places. There's also a wide variety of entertainment, mainly street performers. And you have a wide variety of mainstream food options in the area as well. You have Boudin's SF there and McDonalds if you really are craving that. Then, there's shopping opportunities there too. I wasn't at all intrigued by any of the stores. I did go to The San Francisco Dungeon! And I also jumped onto one of the Big Bus for the night panoramic tour. Read my reviews on those specific locations if you want to read more about them.
author: Antonio L.

description:
Always a fun time at Fisherman's Wharf.

So much to see, so much to do.

If you want to sight see or eat, this is a great place to visit.

I miss seeing the World Famous Bush Man.  May he rest in peace.  He was always entertaining and had a good time startling people.

There are many places to choose from in terms of food.  Whether you want casual or fast food, its all here.

During my most recent visit, it was Fleet Week.  The Blue Angels were putting on an amazing air show.

As always, parking is limited but isn't impossible. 

If you've never been or its been a while, come visit again and see and experience all there is here.
author: Arnel D.

description:
Stop by here for the street entertainment, tourists, an awful lot of flies/mosquitoes in odd corners, odd driving patterns (one-way, two-way and add bike lanes here and there), the cable cars, tourists, tourist shops, restaurants, outdoor food stalls, and more.

You can grab souvenirs and stalls selling chowder and fried seafood. The view of Alcatraz (or rides over), plus the famed sea lions (smelly, but easy setup to see them), some entertainment (carousel and more) plus plenty of shopping draw quite the crowd. It's entertaining but overwhelming.

Go check in and get some discounts on dining from the tourist welcome shack.

Parking at the public lot is easiest ($20 for 2 hours) but that can fill up quickly.
author: Hank C.

description: Okay, so if you go to San Fran, this definitely is a tourist attraction spot you have to go to! The place with all the good seafood and souvenir shops for the win! You can take the cable car from Union Square for about $14 dollars round trip which beats paying for parking or even having the struggle to look for parking. Everything in this area is walking distance from each other and pedestrian friendly. They have everything from souvenir shops, restaurants, attractions like Madame Tussauds and Ripleys. Honestly, I would have spent a whole day here had I had time. Until next time!
author: Amelia L.

description:
The air is noticeably different, the laid back, relaxed pace of this place never really changes...depending on which direction you are coming from you will either see one of the bridges, a cable car or parking signs.

If you arrive before the lunch crowd, try to find a space by the famed Fisherman's Wharf landmark.
Several of the restaurants listed on signs will validate parking up to 3 hours.  Plus you are in a good spot to begin your enjoyment of the area.

It's like a seaside tourist jungle of shops, restaurants, crowds on the street and boat tours, plus several benches between there and Ghirardelli Square to people watch or just take a load off.  

Once you head off in that direction to the right there is the sprawling lawn where you might find a few tourists or homeless taking in the sunshine or having an afternoon siesta on a bench.  But the view of the water, birds, bicycle riders, families, a few dogs on a walk is captivating.

One day it would be nice to book a nite in a swanky hotel by the Fisherman's Wharf area, watch the sunset, have an enjoyable expensive seafood meal  on a 2 Nd floor dining spot for the view of the bridge, then take a stroll to bring back a decadent Ghirardelli ice cream treat to finish off the evening.

If you are a seashore lover, the whimsical nautical atmosphere will draw you back again one day to the City By The Bay.
author: Gail U.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf, on the northern waterfront, is one of the city's busiest tourist areas. Souvenir shops and stalls selling crab and clam chowder in sourdough bread bowls appear at every turn, as do postcard views of the bay, Golden Gate and Alcatraz. There's also a colony of sea lions to see and historic ships to tour. At Ghirardelli Square, boutiques and eateries reside in the famed former chocolate factory.

There is a Navy ship you can take a tour of, as well as a submarine. You can take a boat ride around Alcatraz and under the Golden Gate Bridge. There is a Ripley's Believe It Or Not Studio, Madame Tussaud's Wax Museum and so much more to see and do. 

Definitely a must stop on your tour of San Francisco.
author: Tracey M.

description: This is one of the better places to visit in SF. Lots of history, great views of the water and city, awesome seafood and an overall good place for social interaction. Compared to other parts of the city this is fairly clean and the only issue I have is that there are a lot of pigeons loitering. Interesting museum by the water that chronicles SF maritime history, as well as a submarine and ship that you can tour.
author: John C.

description:
Pier 39, the heart of North Beach... street performers & street dogs from Nathan's Famous. Something for everyone in your group... The Fresh Crab & Clam Chowder is amazing. 

Parking can be an issue, I want to say it's $10/hour ($50 Max) if you just pull up to the lot across the street. I'm leaving a tip on the page that saved me close to $40 for 10 hour parking. 

We walked from Pier 33, took about 10 minutes. There's guys that ride you on their bikes, I believe I was quoted $10 for the trip, we decided to walk, little walk before lunch. A lot of great restaurants & things to do for the entire family.
author: Raul E.

description:
Lord have mercy!  I love this place!  
I try to get here as much as I can. Which is hard since I don't live in the area. I have brought a few friends and family here. Because the food is just amazing!  
Today I brought my beautiful wife. We were in the area for Fleet Week. We were wanting seafood. Surprise! Surprise!  Right?  Bay Area seafood?? Yea so anyway. We were walking around Fisherman's Warf and considered eat there. 
So I mentioned why don't we go to Quinn's. Its amazing food and not near as expensive as being on the warf. Long story short. Bart. Uber. Quinn's. LOL. 
My wife had never eaten here. So I was excited for her to try their amazing food. We were greeted as we walked in my their amazing staff and promptly seated. They must have just open because we were literally the first people seat in the dinning room. Others follow shortly after. 
Given menus and brought water. Normally I order a beer. But I refrained. Because I wanted to enjoy the food without being filled up with empty carbs. So I just stuck to water. 
I have to say their menu is amazing!  I am a creature of habit. When I like something it takes me FOREVER to try something else. Today was no different. I ordered their awesome fish and chips!  With a cup a clam chowder. My wife ordered the calamari with a cup of clam chowder. 
They have to have the best clam chowder anywhere!  It's thick and very wholesome. 
You could just have a bowl and bread and be good. The cup alone is filling. Our food came pretty quick and looked amazing!  It tasted even better!  
One of the benefits of a wide not being able to eat much.  Is helping her eat the rest of her food. 
Which I did today. I mean you can't just let that calamari go to waste right?  Ok I've made my point!  Quinn's Lighthouse is amazing!  Go there!
author: Anthony T.

description:
Fun place to walk around with decent eating spots. It's very touristy of course and crowded. Parking is expensive, we paid $24 for 2 hours but all day was only $40.

Tons of PokeGo spots here though!
author: Chris A.

description:
Fisherman's warf is one of the must see attractions in SF. If you check in on yelp you get a free book that offers discounts on dining in the area and some of the stores!! We made the mistake of eating first before picking up our yelp deal and could have saved 15 or 20% at the restaurant we ate at. 

If you have children you should take them to the carousel in the middle. It's really cool because there's a low and high level. It's fun on the high level because they can see more from the top.

If you go up the stairs you can take pictures with nice views and there are also more restaurants upstairs.
author: Sarah A.

description:
Over the course of my entire existence, I've been to Fisherman's Wharf a bunch of times. Recently, I tend to avoid touristy areas as I don't like dealing with crowds. (Maybe it's just my old age, but I like to keep it low key.) Last week, I went to Fisherman's Wharf and decided to embrace it. I got here on Thursday, September 27th around 6pm.

I ended up checking out Coco Fresh Tea & Juice for a boba tea and Fog Harbor Fish House for a seafood centric dinner. It was a gloomy and cold day, so very chill. Not a lot of people walking around. In the past, I've visiting numerous spots: Alioto's Restaurant, Bubba Gump Shrimp Company, Buena Vista Cafe, Ciopinno's, Ghirardelli Ice Cream and Chocolate Shop, Gold Dust Bar & Piano Lounge, McCormick & Kuleto's Seafood & Steaks, Original Joe's, Pier Market Seafood Restaurant, Players Sports Grill & Arcade, Wipeout Bar an Grill, 7D Experience, Pier 39, Sea Lion Center, etc. I actually didn't know FW was this large until I looked at the businesses on their site. I honestly thought it was just that small around around Ghirardelli Square. I guess I've been to more businesses in this area than I thought. It was fun walking around and reliving my younger years. We used to go to Wipeout and sit at a fire pit, just drinking and talking. Reminded me of when we used to hang out at Pier 39 all the time.

An enjoyable evening playing tourist. Gotta remember it's fun to walk around the more popular areas of SF once in a while.
author: Elena N.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf is one of SF's busiest tourist areas. There are souvenir shops and stalls selling crab and clam chowder. It also offers some of the best views of the bay and Alcatraz. And if you're into attractions, there is a Madame Tussauds and a Ripley's.

I started my first day in SF walking along Fisherman's Wharf and Pier 39. I actually found a really, really good souvenir store called Safe Harbor, which I picked up some really cute souvenirs. The quality was really nice and the prices were competitive with all the other stores on the same block. I love one-stop-shop souvenir stores and this one really hit the mark.

There are a lot of clam chowder spots, but I opted to go to Boudin's Bakery for their famous sourdough soup bowl. Definitely stop in here if you're looking for an "iconic" SF lunch.
author: Michelle T.

description: Fisherman's Wharf, similar to Pier 39, is a tourist trap.  But it's a beautiful and lively tourist trap, situated directly on the water with all kinds of stores for picking up a souvenir of San Francisco, and restaurants as far as the eye can see.  Tours of Alcatraz are offered, along with air tours of the bay area, or you can rent a bicycle to cruise around too. You can also find a bench to park your butt and people watch for hours at a time!
author: Danielle W.

description:
Reviews for places like Fisherman's Wharf are typically an anomaly for me, but I thought with the upcoming tourist season, tourists would be interested in getting the heads up on what to expect, along with my out of town Yelp friends.

First and foremost, "the Wharf", as we locals refer to it, is definitely a touristy locale. In addition to the endless clam chowder and sourdough bread, think lots of tschotske shops filled with SF magnets, SF t-shirts and sweatshirts, etc.  That being said, it doesn't mean it isn't fun.  As a local, I often take a nice walk through the Wharf when the weather is especially nice.  It's an entertaining pastime. In the peak of summer, with all the foreign languages being spoken, I feel like I'm the one who has traveled to a foreign country.  Of course, the backdrop of the Bay, is always alluring, even if you live nearby, and have seen it hundreds of times.

Dining here, however, is a different story.  Locals typically don't think of the Wharf when they think of eating out.  I have come here during crab season, though, to purchase live crabs and have them cook it on the premises for me to take home and devour on the couch.  Outside of that, the only place I've been to recently is Alioto's, which has been owned by the famed Alioto family since the 1920's.  It's ok, if you find yourself at the Wharf, as you'll get friendly service, and decent food at tourist prices, but I wouldn't describe Alioto's as a destination by any means.  

There are often lots of "colorful" characters roaming around the Wharf.  You'll likely run into street performers ranging from magicians, to rap singers.  There's also the famous "Bushman" of Fisherman's Wharf.  The original one died in 2014, but there's another man who has taken his place, duplicating his schtick.  Essentially, Bushman hides himself by holding a huge huge bush in front of himself, and when unsuspecting people pass him, he'll spook you, with a huge "Boo" as he removes the bush and reveals himself.  You've been forewarned, so don't be caught off guard!

Given the homeless situation throughout SF, you're also likely to pass many homeless folks throughout the Wharf, especially in the evening.  If you're coming from the suburbs, or somewhere where homelessness is non existent, you need to be aware of this.

If you haven't heard already, car break-ins throughout SF, have been rampant in the last year.  In fact, there were over 30,000 car break-ins in 2017.  If you think I'm exaggerating, just look it up on-line!  My guess is that that number is actually under reported, as our car was broken into, and we never filed a police report.  It's just par for the course these days in the City, specifically in tourist-centric areas, like the Wharf and Lombard Street, aka the Most Crooked Street in the World.  So, lock your cars, and don't leave anything visible, including your luggage, purses, jackets, makeup bags, food, etc.  It really is that bad, and regardless of what the police say, they've had no real handle on it.  Everyone in SF is aware of this, and you need to be too!

If you've never been to the Wharf, and have some free time, it's an enjoyable place to spend some time at.  If you're up for a good walk, you can walk about a half mile to Pier 39, and then head further, about another mile to the Ferry Building, a personal favorite of mine.  Just a few of many, many things to do in the beautiful City By the Bay.
author: Lori N.

description:
You know of those places in any touristic city, anywhere across the globe, which is kinda must for the visiting flock .. eating, and clicking pics and posting and all that fun .. I will call it fun :D
Fisherman's wharf is definitely that for SF .. And it is really nice when the sun is shining and the weather is good.

To me the best part was not eating or ogling at all that seafood .. yeah I took my plate of fish n chips and all that sure .. but watching the seagulls bullying humans is like genuinely awesome .. :D .. well survival of the fittest .. try and stop them :P
The hilarious moment came when a friend was laughing hysterically on someone's snatched sandwich and his ice cream got snatched .. hehe .. too bad he cursed the poor bird loud enough to make everyone laugh at him. :)

Once you are done here .. walk to downtown via lombard street and the China Town .. that is one more check if you are travelling.
author: Wasil K.

description:
As a kid, teenager, adult and still till this day... I consider Fisherman's Wharf as one of my most favorite hot spot to chill and to have fun!!! And during my middle school and high school days... 

I always like coming here and just to check out the stores... And when there was a time that... I felt hungry for lunch or for a snack at Fisherman's Wharf this famous landmark has a lot of food places and especially Seafood Restaurants for you to choose from!!! 

The one place that... I really like most when eating lunch or for a quick snack would be McDonalds that's the one place that... I would go to of the Fisherman's Wharf area!!!
author: William B.

description:
So many things to here, especially for tourists! The scenery is breathtaking!

This week is FLEET WEEK, so there are a lot of sailors all over the place. I make sure to thank every one of them that I happen to be in the same proximity.
author: Sigal M.

description:
You could literally spend days here exploring new shops, restaurants or even grab yourself a bench and people watch! This is a complete tourist trap however it is completely worth a visit! There are many oceanfront bars and restaurants, seafood galore and every sort of trinket shops you could ever think of. 

So head on down, leave yourself some time to explore and come hungry!
author: Michael P.

description: Simple: this is where Antman fought against the Marvels villains. Antman and wasps are the representation of lovely Bay Area engineers. They are our heros FYI I think Marvel was hinting that Antman attended UC Berkeley.
author: Lulu Y.

description:
What isn't there to do here?! From the aquarium to the restaurants. From the street performers to the gift shops. There is even an area where the seals bunch up together and bathe in the sun. It's always a good time to get in one of the bike carts to have them take you around the area. 

So much area to cover so make sure you wear your sunblock. There is a lot of different parking lots and garages but can get pricey especially if there is an event in the area. 

A must do for tourists and locals alike.
author: Angel M.

description: Crowded yet amazingly relaxing. Probably because of the waters surrouning the whole place with nice breeze of air. Multiple restaurants to choose from according to your appetite or mood. There are also fruit stands, jewelry shops & more engaging areas for adults & kids. Parking maybe a bit struggle.
author: Terr M.

description:
If you come to San Francisco, you have to eat at Fisherman's Wharf. There's so many seafood restaurant to choose from.  If you do takeout from anyplace, beware of the seagulls and birds if you are holding food, they attack in flocks! One will distract you, while the other will knock it out of your hand, and the others will swarm the ground for food.

There's also a lot of souvenir shops, as well as the different piers, ocean views, Alcatraz island and Golden Gate Bridge in the distance, and a unique old arcade at the back of Fisherman's Wharf. Don't forget about Ghirardelli Square and typical tourist attractions like Ripley's and Madame Tussaud's. You can easily spend a few hours in this area.
author: Vincent H.

description: It was my second time here and I love it. I love the restaurants and the shops that they have here. Took my boys here for whale watching too. Definitely a place to visit for activities, food, and souvenirs.
author: Souzana V.

description:
The Fisherman's Wharf is kind of the equivalent to Seattle's Pike Place (expect Pike Place is better). 

There's tons of touristy shops to stop in with clothing, souvenirs, and Alcatraz themed merchandise. There's also a ton of restaurants to choose from in case you get hungry! 

Be wary of parking... It's so expensive. We parked in a lot that allowed us to choose to validate at a participating restaurant (which we did) for three free hours. Otherwise, it's $3 every 15 minutes. Hard pass.

If you have the time when you're in SF, it's a cool place to check out!
author: Lauren P.

description: Tourists flock in from all over for this "must-see" San Francisco destination.  There are plenty of seafood restaurants by the wharf but with qualities swinging widely from poor to pretty decent.  As with other touristy places, you're constantly surrounded by tourists buying things from one shop to another.  It however, remains a great place to see harbour seals and other indigenous marine life forms.
author: Ken L.

description: Love the wharf! Every time I'm in San Francisco it's one of my go to places! Boudin has the BEST sourdough on the planet and their clam chowder is awesome as well! Check out the candy store across the street from Boudins the ice cream there is amazing! Hit up Alcatraz and just enjoy the day it worth it!
author: Tony P.

description: First time in San Francisco I was told this was a must. It's pretty touristy but I think it's nice for families and all different age groups. Area is safe and a pretty decent walk so those who have trouble be careful. There are plenty of places to rest. There is the largest Krispy Creme Donut shop that I've ever seen and I'm from the state where it started. It's a cute place for kids and adults alike to see how they are made. There are plenty of restaurants and souvenir shops.  Here you can also catch boat tours around the bay and to the Golden Gate Bridge.  If you walk to the very end there is a small beach and Ghirardelli Plaza.  You can see Alcatraz here as well as the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Cherrelle S.

description:
Every time I come for a visit to San Francisco, I always make it a point to come by here. Why? There are so many interesting things to do and see. 

Visit some cute shops and if you have the time, check out some of the museums such as the Wax Museum, Ripkey's, Musée Mécanique, and the Maritime Museum among others.

Enjoy some seafood and clam chowder from one of the food stalls or dine in one of restaurants around the wharf. See some talented performers or visit some galleries. There's never a dull moment in here.

The wharf extends to Pier 39 where you can see some sea lions basking under the sun. Or head to ghiardelli square for some chocolate tasting. 

Its a very busy tourist area so if you can deal hustling and bustling with people in a crowded area, come by for a visit. It's definitely a fun place to be!
author: Cris I.

description:
This place has the BEST of the best in seafood.  Especially if you aren't from an area that readily has seafood.  There are a lot of areas to explore around Fisherman's Wharf including restaurants, regular department stores, and souvenir shops.  Pretty cool.  There are also some nice places by the water to get pictures and see Alcatraz island.

I had a phenomenal lobster roll that I think I will be craving for the rest of my life.  IT was amazing!!  I'm so glad I had the opportunity to try it.  I would love to come back and try some of the other seafood.  It all looks delicious!
author: Abby L.

description:
During our visit to San Fran, we stayed in the Fisherman's Wharf area.

We really enjoyed our time here. Some of the reasons why I'm a fan: beautiful water, fresh air, good eats, mom and pop shops, Ghirardelli Square, park, boat tour to Alcatraz, night street performers. Yes, some of the stores are pricey because this is tourist central. At least you are aware of that.

I'm glad we got to check this place out and would definitely come back again. If you're visiting San Francisco, I highly recommend stopping by and don't forget to try some clam chowder at Boudin Bakery & Cafe!
author: Kimberly J.

description:
I'm not sure how it could be much better, it was above all my expectations. Smelling the pacific salt water in the air while tasting the famous bread fish soup. I highly recommend buying one of those while you're at it. Pretty ok price there and a nice view looking over the pier. 
There is also some attractions and shops around there.
author: Ole S.

description:
We love the Wharf. It is not the cleanest and there are some tacky shops with over priced tee-shirts. There are a few restaurants that use barkers to try to get you in. Go anyway, They have street vendors that sell the best clam chowder or if you have a kitchen you can buy fresh crabs, if not, they will steam them for you. Just grab a seat.
There are a few little bars which are fun and the restaurants are good, but not great. I would eat elsewhere. But they have shrimp cocktails they sell from the street and crab cocktails and if on a budget you can eat all fish and be stuffed, all from the large street vendors. 
As you walk the wharf you can find little trinkets to buy and locals and tourist abound. 
It is safe and fun.
author: Elizabeth L.

description: It's exactly what you came for (many times a year) awesome fun for any holiday. Venture out late night to the docks for a romantic by the water local feeling. It's safe. Be smart. ;)
author: Mr. Mrs A.

description:
This is one of those iconic locations you have to visit in San Francisco.

-Parking is insanely expensive and extremely difficult to find, I think we paid like $45 for the day....Take an Uber/Lyft instead.
-Everything is very dirty and disgusting...including restrooms, plan accordingly.
-It is insanely crowded.
-Take the Red and White Bridge 2 Bridge boat tour...worth every penny.
-Walk a few blocks up and ride the Cable cars.
-Too many photo ops to mention.
-Seemingly unlimited restaurants to choose from.
-Zero police presence....I literally saw hobos smoking crack in the street, watch your back and use common sense.

Five stars but be aware this is a tourist trap.
author: Scott S.

description:
Lots of comparisons to Time Square, yet I didn't see racist Elmo. Take that San Francisco!

All kidding aside, Fisherman's Wharf is an American treasure. Gorgeous views of the Bay, Alcatraz and the Golden Gate bridge. Sure it's touristy but its active and there's always something to see. I was surprised at the amount of sea lions just hanging out at the docks. One of the floating dock was filled with sea lions, they reminded me of puppies. There was one sea lion in the water wanted to jump up in the worst way. Then, I assumed there's the older sister who was trying to bite him from jumping up. Witch. haha

I was in full tourist mode: I ate at Boudin Cafe, went to Ghirardelli Square, took a boat tour of the bay, had dungeness crab for dinner and walked from one end to the other looking inside all the different shops. 

I never knew, having a perspective from being there that the cable cars start here and then go downtown. It was fun to watch them rotate the cablecars and hop on once I bought my ticket.

There was an area explaining the history of Fisherman's Wharf and they had different fishing boats used over the past 100 years. 

Lots to do, lots to see and always be aware of your surroundings. What I did notice after about 5 minutes? There was no police presence. No police on bikes, no police cars, no police on horseback, nada. 

Interesting.
author: Bill S.

description: This is a must visit place when coming to San Francisco. While I do agree with other reviewers when they say this is a tourist trap. It is so only if you let it. It has lots of charm. Lots of restaurants, stores and places to see, but you dont have to spen a lot or shop at every store. We basically came and walked around all day, eat at a rowdy restaurant that overlooked the water, and overall had a great time. You can also see hundreds of sea lions just sleeping one on top of the other on these wooden pallets. It is the coolest thing I've seen. Great place.
author: Tairyn A.

description:
Coming here since the 80's there hasn't really been much change other than the aquarium. Too much of a local there isn't much to see or enjoy anymore. 

There are really no special events that draw people here other than being a tourist spot.
author: M C.

description:
Ahoy! Not visiting Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco is like going to Vatican City and not chilling with the Pope. Okay, not quite, but Fisherman's Wharf is a must if visiting the city by the bay! Yes, for the most part, the wharf is still a tourist trap filled with 5 for a dollar postcard shops & 3 for a Hamilton t-shirts, but it's what you find in-between the obvious is where it's at! 

You'll see & smell the best clam chowder (chow-dah) west of Boston, of course, it would be sacrilege to not eat it from a sourdough bowl! You'll see & smell the seals (RL animals in the semi-wild) that call the wharf home for part of the year. You'll discover more than Ghirardelli chocolates here, more like Ghirardelli everything - it's where it all began! You'll smell & smell the seafood market and street entertainers that always seems to be in a spunky mood! You'll be able to take a selfie at the historic crab sign and other wharf landmarks! How about visiting the 3 generations Alioto's restaurant?

Have you been to Pike's Market in Seattle? It's like that, but more fisherman raw! Think Quint in Jaws! Just so much to do, but if gawking people and fish just ain't your thing head to Pier 39 just steps away aka the retail hub of the wharf! Maybe the Cannery Shopping Center, Ghirardelli Square, a Ripley's Believe it or Not museum, the Musée Mécanique, Wax Museum at Fisherman's Wharf, the San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park, etc. All part of the wharf! How about jumping on a ferry to the infamous Alcatraz? Yup, you can do that too! 

Lastly, it's easy to get to Fisherman's Wharf. Catch the historic cable car or the historic F line and it drops you off steps from the fish & crabs. The regular Muni too! If you plan to drive the street meters are insanely expensive, so I'd suggest parking in the designated lots. And no, you do not have to be Black Beard or Capt. Ahab to enjoy the wharf... the crowds, the smell of fish, heck just cherish the joys of being a land mammal... thar she blows!
author: Eric R.

description:
Plenty to do and plenty to see. Many stores, restaurants, and activities to do! We went on a Monday morning so it wasn't too busy but people were already starting to cram the boardwalk. 

The boardwalk itself is nice to walk along. There are more then plenty of shops to shop from and plenty of museums to visit. Some exhibits are free and of course  there's the museums where you have to pay. So be on the lookout!

It does tend to get chilly so take a light sweater!
author: Christa M.

description:
I know this is San Fransisco's Time Square, but I freakin loved it. Reasons it's better:

1. You don't have to worry about cars
2. Or hear them, you can hear music, laughter, sea lions, arcade games, sizzling food
3. I really didn't get accosted for money, or have a costumed character punch me in the face. Instead I got to see a hot shirtless guy with a British accent do acrobatic stunts behind a carousel.

Yeah it's crowded and full of screaming kids and not a true representation of the city, but there's a good amount of fun to be had here before you move on to other things. I really loved the Mirror Maze and the Musée Mécanique (that alone is worth coming out for). Plus you get a great view of Alcatraz, the water, and some sea lions. It's worth a visit.
author: Luci B.

description: Yes, this is a tourist trap but I enjoy coming here when I'm in the Bay if for nothing but the view. There are great views from the Wharf of the entire Bay and Alcatraz. There are countless souvenir shops and restaurants to go to as well. I am sure the locals don't come here but I still enjoy it for the views of the Bay if nothing else!
author: Sam T.

description: Tourist spot for sure, but you'll kick yourself if you don't check it out. A myriad of bars, shops and restaurants; no matter what you're seeking there's a strong possibility you'll find it here. Yes, there will be a huge crowd here pretty much no matter when you come so plan on committing multiple hours if you want to see most of what The Wharf has to offer.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf is a famous San Francisco neighborhood bordered on the north and east by the waterfront, the west by Van Ness Ave and the south by Bay St. This area is a well known tourist trap and you will almost never find locals hanging out here unless they are playing host to visiting friends and family.

The most famous attraction in the neighborhood is Pier 39, which is full of expensive touristy garbage that after you have seen once, you have no desire to see again. I would still argue that it's worth experiencing at least once just to say you have been there, but its not a place that you will likely want to visit over and over again. 

There are no restaurants and coffee shops that interest me in this area and the only time that I end up here nowadays is if I am taking a long walk along the waterfront and walk past it. If you happen to be walking past here, I will note though that Pier 39 can be fun to walk along later  in the evening after the crowds have left.
author: Regina W.

description:
I personally do not understand all of the hype about Fisherman's Wharf.  Personally I'd heard of Fisherman's Wharf but wasn't quite sure what was there or what to expect.  

First of all it is nicely located right near Ghirardelli Square, Pier 39 is down the road, but honestly I would not park and walk that far, and cable cars run right down to the wharf.  

I noticed there wasn't actually much to do.  There are plenty of restaurants to eat at and a lot of food stands.  Honestly if you don't like seafood much the smell is a little overwhelming.  I found myself holding my breath a bit when walking by.  There are a lot of souvenir shops but I noticed all of the souvenir shops pretty much sell the exact same things.  It's like there is a monopoly on San Francisco souvenirs and everyone has to buy them from the same distributor.  The only thing you can do is browse for the best price because you are looking at the same things.  Also oddly no one carries plus sized clothing.  I guess because there are so many hills in San Francisco everyone is fit but hey some tourists would like a plus sized hoodie.

Parking is crazy.  It is very hard to find a spot even a Thursday when we were there.  We ended up finding metered parking a few blocks away but at $4.50 per hour it's high. That's basically 8 cents per minute.  That quarter isn't getting you much parking time. 

I don't think I'd visit again on any future visit to San Francisco.  I really didn't enjoy Fisherman's Wharf that much and would rather spend my time elsewhere.
author: Ashley E.

description: This place has so much energy as well as natural beauty from birds and animals. Lots of street performers and shopping available as well!
author: Holly F.

description: The sea lions chose the best place in SF to sunbathe. Having been to San Francisco years ago, I mainly remember the sea lions and Ghirardelli  Square. SF is a great city and a must visit for everyone.
author: Matthew H.

description:
It's world famous and touristy! I've been here multiple times and in order truly say you've been in San Francisco you must stop here once. I enjoy the clam chowder here, but it's always so crowded with so many people at all hours. There's never any seating and im usually eating my bread bowl standing up. Another time I stopped by here I decided to try the lobster roll. That was a mistake on my part, it wasn't that great and it was expensive.

If you're looking to sit down, do yourself the favor and only try the clam chowder bread bowls and nothing else or you'll be throwing your money away. Walk over to the Boudin Bakery which has plenty of seating and it's just as delicious. 

There are many tourist shops here and the Penny Arcade is close by as well. If you've never been here then stop by and take that experience of Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Karen C.

description:
Lots of local SF flavor packed into this area.  Bring your walking shoes because there is plenty of ground to cover. However, if you've never had a cable car ride you'll definitely have the opportunity right here at Fisherman's Wharf...they actually have their own station. If eating is your thing, this area has great for foodies. Everything from churros, popcorn, seafood off the pier, sports bars, sweet treats, ice cream, beignets...a plethora of waterfront restaurants. 

Activities for all to do. Live music, street artist, bicycle rental, souvenir shops, Bay Aquarium, skateboarding...you name it! 

~Christy
author: Christy A.

description: I've lived here for almost 45 years and it's only fair that I write this review with the eyes of a tourist and also from the perspective of a local. As a tourist, it's a magical, beautiful, glorious awe-inspiring food filled paradise, albeit freezing cold and foggy and windy. But when you're on vacation and are bundled up walking along the water and ducking into seafood places, cracking into crab dipping it into butter, and breaking sourdough bread, maybe sipping on a hot drink at a local bar in front of a hot roaring fireplace, do you care if it's a wee windy or foggy? Not really, you're with your people and in one of the best cities of the world. It's got a character running deep in its veins with a gypsy like wanderlust ... who doesn't fall in love with S.F. via Fisherman's Wharf? Anyone immune to its charms isn't mortal. There's the bells of the cable cars in the distance and ice-cold ice-cream sandwiches, knick knack shops on every corner, tie dye t-shirts, the smell of pot in the air--the hippie era is alive and well thank you very much. It's love and peace all the the way. Now for my eyes as a local: It's freezing and I hate it, it's foggy so I can't see in front of me, I need to wear a hoodie to keep the cold out no matter if it's summer, the crab is overpriced and I'm gluten intolerant so forget about the glories of the bread. Also I don't drink so a bar sin't gonna do jack for me. And here the biggest doozy: the parking. There's zero parking spots on the streets and how much does it cost to park in any of the adjoining garages? It'll set you back a days worth of wages. It's obscene the cost of owning a car and god forbid, needing to park it near Fisherman's Wharf. But if you're a tourist, you'll likely not have a car and if you Uber or taxi, no worries. No matter, if you're a local or tourist, one of the joys of the wharf is the ferries, being ferried back and forth across the water is a joyous thing, experiencing the water up close, it feels like an adventure, and if you're doing it with kids, mores the better. It's not fair for me to complain about the weather because this is not the fault of the Wharf--it just is what it is, and the wharf is pretty damn all shades of awesomeness.
author: Ranjan P.

description: While visiting San Francisco on a work conference I spent a lot of time at Fisherman's Wharf. So much to do and see! Being next to water is always so peaceful and serene.
author: Joiya A.

description: This place is a great hot spot to stay in or definitely visit when in San Fransisco. There is a weird 1940's museum that's free and super cool, TONS of fresh seafood to eat, lots of chain places too, Ripley's, Madame Tussaud's, and its on the water. On a clear day you can see Alcatraz. Definitely come by here. Oh and it's also where a lot of tours dock.
author: Kristy T.

description:
What a great spot to visit...tourist or local.  Whenever I visir SF I make sure to visit Fishermans Wharf.  I enjoy the local seafood...Of course you have to get the Sourdough Bread as a Bowl..w/Clam Chowder..if this is your thing?  

There is a lot of local flavor...street performers ..local artisians ..just a cool scene.  

The place can be touristy..but if you want to do some great people watching while sampling some good seafood..this is your spot.  

Pro:  Short Walk to Pier 39 & Ghiradelli Square. 
Con:  Can be a tourist trap..ask locals of best spots to get some food.
author: Shane J.

description:
Touristy...cheesy...entertaining...dungeness crab heaven...NOSTALGIC!

What else can I say that my fellow Yelpers haven't already.  I echo many of the reviewers' opinions about this local hot spot.  Being a local and growing up on the other side of SF in a quieter neighborhood aka the Avenues/Outer Richmond, I don't like coming here unless I have out of town friends who want to see a mix of tacky and weird attractions all in one place.  Beware of scammers, purse-snatchers, and thieves in these areas.  Okay, you've been warned.  Have fun sightseeing!

For the locals, remember when Hard Rock Cafe was on Van Ness, remember when Cobb's Comedy was here.  Remember when there was a club called Dirty Martini.  Remember when the Wax Museum wasn't owned by Madame Tussauds - thanks to the Fong family for all the unforgettable memories.  Remember the original Bush Man...RIP.  Remember when there was no Musée Mécanique yet, it was still at Cliff House.  Remember when Hooters was next to In & Out, bad combo lol.  Remember when Bubba Gump Shrimp Co. opened - it was a big deal.  Remember Ana Mandara.  I can go on and on and on...you get my drift.  

'Til we meet again ~ cheers and see you on Yelp!
author: Christine R.

description:
Fun place to spend the day... or evening!

Although I've been to Fisherman's Wharf many, many times in which all times were during the day this is my first time ever to spend New Year's Eve at the famous Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco. New Year's Eve was bustling with plenty of both tourists, out of town folks (like us) and locals. Many souvenir shops, restaurants, and entertainment tours/activities were even open late on New Year's Eve.  

Over the years I've had a chance to enjoy some of the Bay cruises: Red and White Fleet, Alcatraz Tour, Angel Island State Park Tour, Hornblower brunch cruises: the San Francisco Belle and California Hornblower, and even sailed on a boat named "Kitty Kat" for an eco whale watching tour. Along Fisherman's Wharf I've stopped and enjoyed some of the street performers, they come in different forms of entertainment like musical talents, acrobatics, artists, street dancers and circus-type performers. If you enjoyed the show do drop a few dollars on their collecting bins. At the Wharf there are plenty of restaurants to enjoy. Endless! 

Also around this time every year around the third week of January enjoy the arrival of the sea lions. These San Francisco residents began showing up at Fisherman's Wharf area shortly after the Loma Prieta earthquake in 1989 and they've been a fixture since. Find them on the western side of the pier. 

San Francisco can be very expensive depending on what type of activities you want to do but I always enjoy breaking away from the valley (especially during hot summer months) and enjoy a day here at the Fisherman's Wharf. There's plenty of things to do in this popular San Francisco tourist spot and there's always something for everyone!

Review #0636
author: May A.

description: True landmark of Sf. You got the bush man, the seafood smell, thebusy vendors, the boats the water.I got the fisf and curly potatoes with a beer las night at 10 from one of the many vemdors and it was one of the best late dinners i had standing:))).Also do not forget to visit the ship museum which is very interesting.
author: Cristian A.

description:
Fisherman's wharf is not a single tourist attraction. Fisherman's wharf is a neighborhood consisting of many tourist attractions, local businesses and the docks which house many commercial and charter fishing vessels. The boats are all well-maintained functional and very colorful. They are a joy to see. If you are into ships the Wharf houses The Maritime Museum and a fleet of historic vessels. Near the museum you can pick up a Powell & Hyde's cable car and ride to Lombard Street, Chinatown or Union Square for $7.00. 

The food in Fisherman's Warf is of the charts, Great breakfast places like Eight AM and the Hollywood Café, Burgers, Mexican and wood fire cooked pizza at the Carmel Pizza Company.  They have Boudin, the original sourdough bread bakery, fudge and ice cream shops. 
Then as you should expect, there is the seafood. The massive catches of Dungeness crab provides fresh product to many restaurants and crab shacks like the sandwich places on Taylor Street.  Great chowders are available pier 39's Chowders and Chowder Hut on the Embarcadero.   Italian cooking influenced seafood is evident at Capurros, Pompeis and Cioppinos which features it namesack San Francisco original fish stew. All are located on Jefferson Street.

The hands down biggest edible attraction is Ghiradelli.  A must go for super fresh delicious chocolate.  They have a square on the hillside with a beautiful mermaid fountain and a lot of nice shops. Souvenirs and shopping are everywhere.  They are especially abundant on Jefferson Street and Pier 39.  And speaking of Pier 39, it is the coolest place to spend time being entertained.

There are many hotels right in Fisherman's Warf and everything is compacted so tightly that is an easy walk to most places.  It is a place where you can easily spend a week exploring but now for the cons.  It is very expensive to do just about anything.  The neighborhood is dirty and littered. There are way too many homeless and panhandlers.  Despite them the area seems very safe. It is fun.
author: Rich C.

description:
If you're a tourist then it's definitely something to see and say you've been there. Lots of good seafood. 

Not as many street performers like in Santa Monica but very crowded on the weekends.

It's cold by the pier so bring a jacket.
author: Wendi J.

description:
Super duper touristy cesspool if you will.
This is what comes to mind when I think of the wharf... or even San Francisco in general.

Lots of bums, lost of pan handling, lots of typical touristy families, lots of sewer smells too.
Plenty of spots to eat, things to do n see; the aquarium, the view of Alcatraz on a clear day, you know, normal stuff.

The city is artsy and certainly has its famous spots that all seem to be reflected in the wharf like a big ol' melting pot.   Not my cup of tea from what I remember.  Wax museums, Ripleys believe it or not, any tourist trap you can think of really.

Grab the historic ol' cable car and make a stop at the wharf I guess, hit the pier and take it all in, it worth it to see for yourself but it's not somewhere I'd go too often.
author: Doug W.

description:
YELP 100 CHALLENGE 2017 - PART 3: 39/100 

Synonymous to, let's say, the Eiffel Tower in Paris, The Wharf is an absolute tourist spot in California. 

And because it's a tourist spot, everyone pays tourist prices. Yeah, everything is slightly more expensive but the experience is top notch. The view in itself is magnificent. The abundant number of eateries. The tours (Alcatraz is a MUST!) and cable cars. They even have an aquarium! There's just that specific San Francisco feel when you find yourself around this area that you can never get anywhere else. 

It's a great place to just chill even for non-tourists like me. I can kill an entire day just walking around, looking at shops, watching the seals, maybe get a clam chowder at one of those stand-only spots, etc. Hubbers and I certainly enjoy exploring this place over and over again. 

So, yeah, come on down! Just be prepped for the above average premiums on everything!
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Love it always and forever!
The view of the bay tells you what San Francisco is considered the second prettiest city in the World next to Paris! Seeing the Golden Gate while engulfing in urban seaside pedestrian accommodating fish cuisine coupled with traditions surf and turf with old school appeal mixed with outside seating  Ocean view chef quality seafood fusion establishments that seafood and Ocean view livers would request as a last meal if they needed such a choice! Truly, if you live in San Francisco and can afford to you'd go here often to wallow in the atmosphere that makes SF so wonderful!!! Some of the tourist attractions like Ripley's believe it or Jot and the chocolate specialty shops are terrific! I will lust some favorites soon as I have sampled many and eaten at over 10 restaurants here just to review! I will amend a list soon!
author: Brian D.

description:
Restaurants, shops, street performers, museums, the aquarium, piers, boats, tours.... This area is packed with things to fill your day. Put on your walking shoes and enjoy! Some parts get a bit more into "tourist trap" territory (for example, I found Pier 45 to be quite entertaining but Pier 39 was like stepping through a portal into Orlando). 

If you're in San Fran, this is one place you can't pass up!!
author: Lindsey G.

description:
All right, come on now. Ya know you love it. Ya gotta go at least once. Ha! I have been several times. Yes, of course we know it is a tourist trap but you only live once. Yes, it is crowded and cheesy and full of idiotic photo ops. YIPPEE!!!!!!!!! Yeah, we know. However, a trip to SF would not be a trip to SF if you have never participated in the fun stroll through the Wharf. We were leaving Scoma's and we drove right into a wall of bubbles. Ha, they were coming out of a clown car.  I mean, let's be real.  How often in life can one say that?

Our advice. Eat some bread, slurp some of the world's best Clam Chowder, get some chocolate in the square and just relax, calm down. and enjoy a life adventure. Have a ball.
author: Mary S.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco is a touristy but fun place to explore. Rather than being an actual wharf, Fisherman's Wharf is a waterfront area spanning several city blocks which include:

* San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park
* Ghirardelli Square
* Hyde Street Pier
* Seafood Stands next to the iconic Fisherman's Wharf sign
* Pier 39
* Many restaurants and shops
* Over a dozen hotels

Maybe I'm spoiled by the City of Monterey where there's an actual wharf with multiple restaurants handing out free samples of clam chowder. You won't find that in SF. Here you are not ON the wharf; you are IN the wharf. But walk around and explore; there's plenty to do and see.
author: Anson W.

description:
Fisherman's wharf is great for the abundance of fresh seafood options. 

As a Southern California native, this area is a must. The only downside? It's starting to remind me of Venice Beach. For those of you who don't know, Venice is a beautiful area down by the water, with a strip of restaurants and shops. Sounds great right? Well, it's also filled with street performers, druggies and very aggressive homeless. Fisherman's Wharf, I am saddened to see this area slowly turn in to that.

It's so gorgeous down here I hate that I find myself not wanting to walk down here by myself anymore. You can see the Golden Gate Bridge, the Bay Bridge, City Views, Alcatraz, Angel Island, Sausalito, etc. There's SO much to see and do in such a small area it's just filled with people who try to take advantage of tourists. Unfortunate :(

I'm not saying I will never be back, because I will. I just won't come alone. But then again, it would be a sin to come down here and indulge on all the fresh delicious seafood alone.
author: Zoe F.

description:
Great place to visit with many great places to eat and awesome views of seals, Alcatraz out across the water, museum, park, the hills of SF and much more. You can take a tour on a boat. Tickets are sold on site. There is a merry go round on site and comedy act was taking place when I visited. 

I am glad that I got an opportunity to experience Fisherman's Wharf, and you should too!
author: Marivell A.

description:
Tourist place in San Francisco. I'm glad that we got there early to beat the crowds but by the time we were leaving it was super crowded. Lots of fast food type seafood places,  the antique arcade was cool and so were the views of alcatraz. I know one of main attractions are the seals, but I passed on that. 

They have shops that if course are overpriced because of the fact that it is a tourist trap. But it was a nice experience with the kids.
author: Kat R.

description: I don't know what the hype is all about, unless you want to be surrounded by slow moving tourists and buy a bunch of souvenirs, like any other boardwalk attraction. If it's your thing, then this is a place you should visit.
author: Ellen L.

description: What an exciting shopping and dining venue here in San Francisco! This place is blocks of restaurants, eateries, souvenir shops, and museums. A very popular tourist site and Ghirardelli is just a minute walk away. The energy is exciting and vibrant. If you don't like crowds, this may not be for you.
author: Noel I.

description: So sad. This used to be a fun place to visit. Now it is a filthy tourist trap, crowded and junky. I would advise you to avoid it.
author: Mary Lee V.

description: What is their NOT to love at Fishermans Wharf? You have yummy food, great atmosphere, bars, shopping and much more. I don't get to come here often, but when I do their clam chowder in a bread bowl is a must!
author: Rachel A.

description:
This is probably very touristy for the visitors. But to us locals, this is part of our home.

And I have some very fond memories of visiting this place after school, or after catching a Matinee Play here in San Francisco.

It's a great place to visit, and hang out. There is probably nothing like this from where most people hail from, so enjoy it for what it's worth. If you're on vacation, or just visiting; just take in the sights and the activities and enjoy life. 

Moments like these pass too quickly and you miss out on what's important.

Besides, if you're a Pokemon Go buff, this places rules! Best Pokemon Go spot for rare water Pokemons! LOL
author: Stephen A.

description: Nicks is a great spot for oysters & Cali crab (cheapest out of all of them when we went there) and service was quick + efficient. Pricier than other places if you drive along the Bay Area, but they were delicious
author: Stephanie Z.

description:
Probably the number one location in SF for tourists. It can get pretty hectic and crowded, especially on a weekend.  There are so many touristy spots here though, that you won't leave without seeing something interesting. 

While the bush man may be dead (RIP my old friend) , there is still plenty to do and see here. Restaurants, souvenir shops, themed shops, etc.  Basically there is a lot to see, so choose where you stop by wisely. 

Overall, I enjoy this spot and you can't go wrong with a sea themed location.
author: Benny H.

description:
Overrated tourist place. There are filthy "Johny on the spot" bathrooms, the vendors sell over-process tasteless sea food. 

The only thing I liked was the Ghiradelli ice cream shop about 1/2 mile from fisherman's wharf.
author: Abhi K.

description:
Had to come to Santa Clara for a week long training a couple of months ago. When we were done on Friday got to spend  half down down by Fisherman's Wharf and Pier 39. 

What's not to like: cold beer, crab, clam chowder, seals, Alcatraz island in the background, shopping, souvenir's, and other fun things to do. There are a ton of restaurants to eat at grab an appetizer or even a full meal. And they have some of the most insane sunsets & colors in the sky you will see in all of the Bay Area. Seal watching is pretty fun as well, believe it or not.  

Seriously this whole area is a lot of fun. My only regret is not have more time down here to explore and hang out. Will definitely be back here the next time I'm in town and when I can bring the wife with me next time. 

Till next time San Fran! 

Justin
author: Justin M.

description:
If you like fresh clam chowder in a bread bowl then you should definitely stop here! I'm not particularly a big soup kind of guy, but I do enjoy some. One of my favorites being clam chowder. Put that in a fresh sourdough bread bowl and you have a happy man! 

Basically it comes down to this: Great Clam Chowder Bread Bowls = Happy Men & Women!
Hit that "like" button if you agree! See you on the wharf.
author: Neo N.

description: TOURISTY AS F, but a must go to while in SF.  The sea lions, the shops, the pier etc.  Got to go!  Pro Tip: take the cable car or deal with some crazy hills!
author: Adam B. J.

description: Great spot for kick back and chill out.  Obviously overcrowded but what can u expect?  The soups are pretty expensive but then again, it's SF, what can u expect?  I'm making it sound more negative than I should.  It really is a cool place to hang out, walk, chill out.   Check out the arcade museum!  Games from 4-5 different decades!
author: Nestor O.

description: The Fisherman's Wharf along with Pier 39 was the first place my husband and I visited when we arrived in San Francisco. It was a nice experience and lots to see with good food. It has tons of shops, restaurants, souvenir shops, tour places and etc. Everyone in the family can find something to do here. It was definitely a nice experience and I will enjoy telling people that I have visited this area. Overall, it's a nice attraction and a good place to visit if a tourist in San Francisco.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
A must see here in SF but parking can be a nightmare. Got here early to park way up the street in a metered parking spot n walked down to the wharf by Ghiradelli Square. This area isn't the safest especially at night. I would advise you not to go alone here. Saw many homeless and not so safe people and sure enough after we left, some one was murdered here :( wished they can revamp this area since its a major tourist attraction. 

We wanted to visit the Naval museum and Subs but ran out of time. We rushed to the end where the seals were, looked at all the eateries and shops. Walked the boardwalk. Bought some clam chowder in a bread bowl and expensive salt water taffy at the candy store. Things were all overpriced but very appealing. It was a happening place. Food was definitely more balanced in price by the boardwalk end than the front part next to the square.

Nice stroll and fun atmosphere but can get chaotic when it gets really busy. Worth a trip if you have never been. Seals are cute to watch. Alcatraz more be seen off the boardwalk shore. Fun to watch seals swim close around there.

Had a fun walk but plan to spend more than couple hours to really look at everything n eat there. Next time fisherman's wharf!
author: Grace L.

description: Well what's bad to say. Busy, can be smelly but delish. So many places to grab a fresh catch in a sandwich or a salad. So many shops and people milling about, checking it all out. Bars and restaurants to try. A beautiful view. You can take the trolley car near here and walk everywhere in the city. If you get tired, call Uber and they'll be to you in less than a few minutes. There is usually someone performing also and a crowd watching, just a really great community feel down here. If you have never been, you have to go just for a few hours if that's all you have.
author: Valerie M.

description: Wow what a great wharf. We just attended the opening of the one in DC which pales in comparison. A little bit of everything here with stores, restaurants, shows, and attractions. Very impressive. I wish I had the time and stomach to enjoy all the food it had to offer. Be ready to walk if you want to really enjoy it.
author: Gary G.

description: I mean.... it's the fisherman's warf! Don't expect 5 star dining. But if you know where to look there is a ton of hidden gems here, beyond the sea of tourist ofcourse :)
author: Jeremiah S.

description:
You can't visit San Francisco and not stop at the Wharf, it is iconic and the thing to see here.
Plenty of easy parking and much to see from gorgeous views to tourist shops, so many dining options, there is really something for everyone.
Fun way to spend the day a must see!
author: Nijole T.

description: A great place to start to explore the Wharf.  Iconic.  So much to see, experience and most importantly EAT!!
author: Spencer J.

description:
#146/2016

There are two sides of the Fisherman's Wharf coin: The loud, carney-style PIER 39 with its chain restaurants (Hard Rock Cafe, Bubba Gump Shrimp), oddball stores (Left Hand World!) sandwiched by the quieter, historic and working man's Wharf that's home to real fishermen and the historic ships at Hyde Street Pier.

I prefer the quieter, authentic Fisherman's Wharf: Strolling down Hyde Street Pier to take in breathtaking views from onboard the tall, masted ship The Balclutha; wandering the path along the waterfront with the backdrop of the Maritime Museum; having a cup of chowdah at The Blue Mermaid Cafe. 

You'll find locals taking their out-of-town guests to PIER 39 and on occasion, it can be fun to see the city through visitors' eyes. 

Don't forget to do the classics like enjoy a walk-away crab cocktail and take the tour to Alcatraz. The Aquarium at PIER 39 is good for kids and Fog Harbor Fish House is a view restaurant that actually serves very good food.

Warning to non-locals about parking: Meters, if you can find one and manage not to hit a meandering pedestrian, are so expensive and tickets so likely, do yourself a favor and take the MUNI F line. 

Meters are enforced 7 days a week until 7pm (or later) so pay attention to the signage or better yet, just don't drive. 

A short walk from that loud epicenter at PIER 39 is the other side of the Wharf- better classified as The Embarcadero- that houses the excellent Exploratorium and local transportation hubs like the Cruise Line Terminal, Bauer's Limousine and a smattering of expensive restaurants

(though the second location of Queen's Louisiana Po' Boy restaurant, eminently affordable, will open on Pier 33 late summer 2017).

There's a section of the Wharf for different moods: Touristy and frenetic or dreamy and reminiscent.

Flip a coin if you can't decide which to visit.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
While super touristy, I still love the nostalgia I feel when visiting Fisherman's Wharf. Days as a child eating clam chowder in a bread bowl, picking out a shell necklace or a bag of salt water taffy, Pier 39 is definitely a place one would venerate as a San Fransisco landmark. 
Most days there's a two story carousel for rides, an arcade, various stores for purchasing sweatshirts, tshirts, sweets, tchotchkes, etc. There's a decent selection of restaurants, ranging from seafood and pasta to sugary sweets and ice cream. 
Go take a peek down behind the pier at the sea lions laying around with an air of insouciance. They bark at each other, occasionally push one another off the pier, Alcatraz off in the distance. 
Fisherman's Wharf is definitely that quintessential SF day trip.
author: Danielle G.

description:
My first thought when I stepped off the bus and on to Pier 39: "Am I at a tourist Hellmouth?" My gosh, I have never seen so many people packed into such an area--by choice! I don't remember it being so busy here 15 years ago, but now, (if you have claustrophobia) you may not want to come here.

So why was I here? I bought a San Francisco CityPASS, and that included two items at this location: the Blue & Gold Fleet Bay Cruise Adventure, a ferry that takes you to the Golden Gate bridge, to Alcatraz, and back. And then there was the Aquarium of the Bay located near the entrance. I'll review those separately.

What to say about Fisherman's Wharf? Oh yes, there is a lot of people here. My advice, go really early so that there aren't as many people. This place has many things to do: restaurants, tourists shops, dessert shops, ferries, attractions. You name it they probably have it.

If I had to suggest one place to go in here, it would be Magowan's Infinite Mirror Maze on the second floor somewhere on the middle right of the whole place. It's $5 to go in this mirror maze, and it was totally worth it for the fun. If you finish they have no issues with you going through again. It was surprisingly not busy when I went and infinitely more enjoyable with less people.
I think I did what I had to do here. Fisherman's Wharf truly is the definition of a tourist trap, and I'm glad I checked this off my bucket list.
author: Benjamin B.

description:
I have only visited this place twice and I love it! Being from Alabama I have never experienced anything like this. I love the city life and all of the touristy things to do. My boyfriend was born and raised around this area so he showed me all of the ends and outs and it made me fall deeper in love.  

I am definitely a tourist for life so this was the perfect place for me. I really enjoyed the Crepe cafe which was super packed but their service was pretty fast! I also tried Trish donuts which gave me a sweet tooth overload definitely a must try as well. 

There is also a Ferris wheel with free side shows that are pretty cool. All in all if you have never experienced anything like this you must visit here! It is a great place to talk selfies lol and just take in the view. It's a great experience.
author: Teryn G.

description: A sad spot of embarrassment for San Fran.   Dirty.   Crappy touristy stores and restaurants.   Upsetting and sad to see so many homeless.
author: Suki F.

description:
I was completely disgusted by Fisherman's Wharf. Aside from the plethora of homeless and beggars on various corners, the restaurants and shopping is so touristy tacky that I would not possibly want to return. This is the Times Square before it was cleaned up,  Hollywood Boulevard, or just about anyplace that tourists gather to see what they want to see. I was very disappointed watching the massive seagulls divebombing for dropped French fries, the bums begging for handouts and the greasy smells from the fry-o-laters.

There are a couple of highlights. The Boudin shop where they make sourdough bread. Uh. That's about it.

I would not return.
author: Bruce K.

description:
Another must stop for me. Such a tourist trap but I love coming here for some reason. 

Terrible parking and traffic. Metered parking. Always crowded. 

Great place to have a nice stroll and see the docks. 

Took my dogs with me but it was pretty difficult to control them with all the smells and people. 

Nothing beats the smell of the salty ocean and fried seafood in the air. Fun to grab a chowder bowl and people watch!
author: Kevin W.

description:
Beautiful place and a must-see if you are going near the harbor/waterfront!
There are numerous stores selling chowder, crabs, and other seafood, so you can take a stroll and sample some of them. 
The area is very busy and there is lots going on. Make sure to get some photos with Alcatraz in the background!
author: Amelia J.

description: Fun area to walk around, eat, or just hang out by the water. Nice walking place with cute shops, bars, and restaurants. The restaurants are on the expensive side, very touristy - really long waits (45 minutes - an hour minimum). Pier 39 has an awesome doc where you can see dozens of sea lions sun bathing and talking to each other. This area is extremely crowded so be prepared to not be in a huge rush to get places. Lots of fun street performers and even the Ghirardelli factory is in the area. You can also find the boat to Alcatraz on Pier 33.
author: Alyssa B.

description:
Yelp 2015 Challenge #364/365

Fisherman's Wharf, synonymous with Pier 39, is the huge area that has the range from ghirardelli Square all the way to around P39. 

What can you do here?

Well the Ghiradelli Square is the place you can get tons of chocolate. You can get a sundae. You can meet people, eat chocolate with them. Ugh their chocolate. Sooo good.

Pier 39 is one of the bigger places (you can also get a Yelp Check in offer). There are tons of places to shop, buy hats, shirts, etc., souvenirs. Jewelry? Looks good. You also can stop by madame tussauds as well!

You want food? You got Boudin SF. They have their clam chowder bread bowl which is so fantabulous. Omg like I really feel like this would be something I'd eat a lot. Bread and clam chowder? YUM. You can also go to the side vendors and get their seafood as well. It's fresh, definitely fresh. LIKE THEY JUST WENT AND CAUGHT THE SEAFOOD :3

Parking is difficult, so if you have one of them SF car parking places app which tells you the lowest price for the time and day, definitely use that! You can park at the official FW parking garage and get a few hours for free if you can get the voucher from the FW area w/ the Yelp check in offer.

Red and White fleet takes you to check out SF Golden Gate Bridge, and Bay Bridge as well (along as alcatraz).
author: Raymond L.

description:
If you went to San Francisco and told people you didn't visit Fisherman's Wharf, they'd recoil in shock.  So, it's almost an obligatory stop.  But be warned, it's mostly tourist schlock.  That being said, there are some valid reasons to venture into tourist central. 

1. See the sea lions. 
2. Book an Alcatraz tour, well worth it.
3. Catch the ferry to Sausalito. 
4. Take a sailing excursion on the Bay, a quintessential San Francisco experience.
5. Visit In-N-Out burgers to see what all the fuss is about.

Some might add a visit to Boudin's bakery, the original home of Sourdough bread, but that's pretty touristy itself.  And I can't speak to the Aquarium since I've never been.

But you will find all the usual t-shirt shops, tacky souvenirs plus restaurants like Hard Rock Café and Bubba Gump Shrimp Co. that thrive on tourists.

Go ahead and visit Fisherman's Wharf, just be a little discerning about how and where you'll spend your time.
author: Will T.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf is a fantastic place to visit when you are traveling in the City! There are so many cool places to sit and look at the views like Alcatraz, Angel Island, Golden Gate Bridge, Coit Tower, and on a clear day from Pier 43, you'll be able to see the San Francisco Oakland Bay Bridge.  There's also lots to do when you get to Pier 39!!

There are tons of shops here so you will find plenty of souvenirs for everybody. Definitely pay a visit to Ghiradelli Chocolates. It was founded here in San Francisco over 160 years ago. You will also have tons of sidewalk eateries including clam chowders and fresh crabs. If you prefer fine dining, you might want to try The Franciscan Crab Restaurant. It has been a part of Fisherman's Wharf since the 1950's! The first time we dined here was when I  was eight years old with my parents. Lots of good memories.

Lastly, One of the coolest part about Fisherman's Wharf in my humble opinion, are the street performers. They are so talented and truly, will inspire you. 

Until then, Cheers! ~ :p
author: Edwin R.

description:
There's no hiding that Fisherman's wharf is a place for tourists and not so much for fisherman anymore. The docks themselves are full of stores and restaurants and the like. There are still boats docked here but I'm sure they are private boats that don't do much fishing. Well I could be wrong, what do I know?

Besides the last trip I had only come as a kid on a field trip or nearby going out on a cruise ship. It' a busy happening place and can be fine to spend a day at if you want to shop, walk and eat with the bay as your backdrop. Plenty of people want to do that so that's why these places exist right? Tourist away!
author: Desmond F.

description:
Nope, much like Ghirardelli Square, this is more of an experience to check off a tourist list rather than an experience to savor and enjoy. Jam packed with people and overpriced food and goods, the whole Fisherman's wharf is a tourist trap, through and through. Hordes of people that clump up and make walking difficult, traffic at a constant standstill, and the seagulls! So many everywhere. Anyway, it's fun to see the sea lions lounging and fighting, but it may take 5 minutes before you can elbow your way through to a good viewing position. Eventually though! 

I don't want to be super negative about Fisherman's Wharf, but it didn't hold much value for me, and I can't see it or the surrounding area being a place tourists would want to visit. Try walking around Haight or Japantown or 9th and Irving, they're usually less touristy places with many interesting things to do and see and shop for!
author: John B.

description:
One of my favorite things to do in San Francisco is just walk up and down the boardwalk, through piers, tourists and shops, and enjoy the ocean view. It's a beautiful place with the sea lions and some parks, and the streets full of people are always fun for me.

The Pier contains various restaurants, souvenir shops, cafes, and confectionery stores. They also have various food stalls that sell hot dogs, candy floss, and everything else that inner kid in you desires. If you are lucky, you will find yourself holding a wonderful sourdough bread bowl of the famous clam chowder. I suggest going to the website link I have provided to read more about Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Steve N.

description: Fisherman's Wharf is definitely a must visit whenever you're in San Francisco. Best way to visit is uber/Lyft unless you don't mind waiting, searching, and paying for parking. There's so much going on here; from street performers, to great restaurants, the vintage arcade, pier, and WWII ship and submarine tours. You won't be disappointed stopping by. Really plan to spend a bit of time here or else you won't get the full enjoyment of this place.
author: Cesar S.

description:
It's kind of a must see if you are in San Francisco. Right by the water, Fisherman's Wharf is a great place to hang out and spend money. Yes, the shoppes, restaurants, and bars are pricey but it's worth the dough. There's so much activity, history, and personality - what's not to like?

The food is awesome and there's a huge selection. From the little seafood carts run by a family of cooks to the big restaurants there are plenty of options for all tastes. I love the inexpensive clam chowder - New England of course - so much yes.

There are street performers, museums, an awesome view of Alcatraz, history, bars, candy shops, clothing stores, and of course plenty of places for souvenirs. There's activity and life all around. You can never go wrong with a visit to the Wharf.
author: Richard R.

description:
At any given moment you will encounter one of the following: the strong scent of marijuana, the overwhelming smell of sewage, and the alluring aroma of food. Fisherman's Wharf was my first stop upon arriving in San Francisco over the holiday weekend. After such a long drive up from Big Sur I couldn't wait to experience the legendary Fisherman's Wharf and picturesque Pier 39. Unfortunately, every other tourist had the exact same idea. Traffic was a nightmare and don't even get me started on parking. On the bright side I had a loooooot of time to Google parking options in the area. 

PIER 39 has convenient visitor parking in the PIER 39 Garage, located directly across the street from the Entrance Plaza. The PIER 39 Garage is open 24-hours a day, seven days a week. Summer Parking Rates: Weekdays are $10/hour (maximum daily rate of $50) and weekends/holidays are $12/hour (maximum daily rate of $60). Visitors who dine at participating full-service PIER 39 restaurants receive ONE HOUR OF FREE validated parking in the PIER 39 Garage. Participating restaurants include: Bubba Gump Shrimp Co. Restaurant & Market, Chart House, Crab House, Eagle Cafe, Fog Harbor Fish House, Hana Zen Japanese Grill, Hard Rock Cafe, Luigi's Pizzeria, Mango's Taqueria & Cantina, Pier Market Seafood Restaurant, Players Sports Grill & Arcade, Swiss Louis Italian & Seafood Restaurant and Wipeout Bar & Grill. Be sure to ask your server to validate your PIER 39 Garage ticket. Multiple parking validations cannot be combined. Limit one parking validation per vehicle. To avoid auto break-ins, take all valuables with you and check that your vehicle's doors and windows are locked. This is also the parking garage that fills up very very quickly so have an alternative in mind.

Tips:
- Have someone in your car use Google or a parking app like SpotHero to locate the nearest, cheapest parking while you are stuck in traffic
- Have someone in your car use the app OpenTable to make reservations at a local eatery if you do not want to waste your time and parking money waiting for a table
- Bring a jacket or sweater since it does get windy and chilly 
- Wear comfortable walking shoes because there's a good chance you will be parking far away
author: Jennifer G.

description:
My husband loves fresh fish, what better place to get it while In San Francisco than at the wharf.  Great place for souvenirs, sourdough bread, clam chowder and fresh fish. 
You can't talk about the wharf without talking about the street performers. Best one was the English guy who juggles and balances himself on cups. He's going places.
We were able to jump on a boat and circle Alcatraz and go under the Golden Gate Bridge and make a wish so says the captain of our charter boat.
All in all a cool place to hang out.
author: Tish W.

description:
This is a must go place or must visit place if you are in San Fran. The name pretty much says it all. You want good Chowder than you have to come here. Parking is not free anytime. So parking could be an issue if you are in this area. 

There are a few unique or specialty stores in this location. Such as museum or hippster shops etc. to even specialty candies store.

You can see the Alcatraz jail cell from Fisherman's Wharf. There are a lot of souvenir stores in the area. 

I personally enjoy roaming around in the area.
author: Denise W.

description: My mum died from leukemia back in 2008 and she really wanted to go to Fisherman's Wharf. My partner and I were lucky enough to go when we were in San Francisco for Pride. River loved the fresh seafood options and I loved the view overlooking the ocean. Some of the food was very salty so I liked that we were given constant refills of water. Still a great place and I'm glad we were able to go.
author: Maria P.

description:
Great place to walk around and explore. Pier 39/FW is a tourist trap, so heed with caution. Definitely stop by if this is your first time, but if you have been before you may want to skip. Everything seems the same as it was a few years ago.

Do not succumb to the food shoppes in the area, while they look great, people were saying things taste strange. Perhaps because they were sitting on a counter all morning? Who knows!

Don't forget to stop by the sea lions' corner. You'll be amused and entertained for a while. Once you've had enough fun, move along towards your next destination.
author: Arturo B.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf is worth seeing at least once when visiting San Francisco. There are plenty of shops and restaurants to check out when you're here!
