My favorite spots are Pier 39, Alcatraz, and Ghirardelli Square. It's fun to just walk around, watch all the street performers, and get clam chowder in a bread bowl. Fisherman's Wharf is a bit of tourist trap so we can stop by any of the gift shops to pick up souvenirs for family and friends. 

Parking can be a challenge here. We came here at the end of our summer vacation and fortunately found parking right away. Parking at Pier 39 is usually a safe bet, but we were happy to find parking below Ghirardelli Square on this visit. We also went on a weekday to avoid those crowds.

I wish we had known about the aquarium and museums when we were at Fisherman's Wharf. It will give us something to look forward to the next time we're here! 

,
author: Tami D.

description: I absolutely loved the day I spent at Fisherman's Wharf. There is so much to see and eat with bayside restaurants, museums, attractions, and boat tours - I took a one-hour boat tour under the Golden Gate Bridge and around Alcatraz Island on the Silver Fox for only $15/person, which is a better deal than the $30 fare I have seen online and around the site! There is a lot of foot traffic, especially in the seafood markets where smaller businesses are cranking out fresh, succulent seafood such as (seasonal) Dungeness crab, squid/calamari, clams, mussels, clam chowder in bread bowls, and more. I highly recommend the Dungeness crab if they are in season! They are out of this world. Not even exaggerating. One restaurant I suggest is Cioppino's - please check out my review of this place!
author: Annie C.

description: Fisherman's Wharf (of which Pier 39 is just a small part) is one of those must-do activities on any visit to San Francisco. Sure, it's a tourist trap and it's mostly restaurants and shops overcharging you. However, it does offer beautiful views of the Bay, the classic clam chowder in a sourdough bread bowl, various boats offering Bay cruises, street performers, and more. So, don't build your entire San Francisco trip around the Wharf, but definitely spend a morning or afternoon down here taking in the sights, sounds, and tastes.
author: Chad K.

description:
Came here last weekend with friends, had a great time. 

It's always crowded, and there's bird poop on the ground too. However, I still love it. It's so lively here. There would be random street shows going on, there's people painting beautiful pictures right in front of you. Make sure you get some good clam chowder from here as well. 

One of my favor spot in San Francisco.
author: Ruby K.

description: Idk why people hype it up so much...it's basically just shops and restaurants. Souvenir shops are expensive...not really worth it in my opinion.
author: Laura S.

description:
This review is for Tourists.  Locals, if you really need to read a review of Fisherman's Wharf, you probably need to explore The City a bit more.  Yes, I know, there will be plenty 'o push back for a 5 star Fisherman's Wharf review.  Bring it.  

San Francisco isn't just the City by the Bay, it is a city built because of it's maritime geography.  Gold wasn't discovered in SF.  It just made its way down so that it could be connected with the rest of the civilized world.  The culture of The City is one that has historically been tied to the water  As a tourist, there's any number of great places to visit in San Francisco.  At least some of your time should be spent in this area because there is little else like it.  You will see beautiful views, you will see Sea Lions and Fishing Boats, you will find Bread Bowls full of Chowder.  You will find people from all over the world who may be experiencing their first visit to the United States.  You'll also find a lot of people trying to cash in on it - and this can include a lot of types.  There are no shortage of tourist traps.  But, there is a lot of good.

One thing that makes Fisherman's Wharf a no-brainer for Tourists is that there is something for everyone.  A family can come and everyone can have fun.  People of all ages can find something interesting.  And, there are so many beautiful things that you can take in.  Just be smart about it.  Don't spend your day looking for some lame t-shirt.  Never get a t-shirt on vacation.  Never.  Seriously.  And don't get junk.  Don't do that anytime.  If something is a chain, only eat at that chain if you will NEVER have an opportunity to do so at home.  I met someone who went to Bubba Gump Shrimp who lives a mile from the Mall of America in Minnesota.  What are you thinking?!?!  If you're here from another country, you can do better than Joe's Crab Shack or Applebee's, but at least it's novel.  (Great moment - Group of Texans get of a bus and a young man in his early 20's says:  "That Applebee's is downright majestic." with a gleam in his eye. ... Yeah dude.  Probably the most expensive you'll ever see.) 

Things you SHOULD Do:
*Learn History.  I highly recommend utilizing the fact that there is a National Historic Park here.  Hit the Visitor's Center, Maritime Museum, Hyde Pier, Boudin Museum (up stairs at Boudin), Pier 39 Historical Markers, Embarcadero Historical Walk, and the Ghirardelli Marketplace has some really cool info about chocolate making.  
*Take in the views.  Aquatic Park has great views of The Bay, Hyde Street Pier and Alcatraz.  The section of Fishing Boats on Jefferson is great on a nice day.  Sneak in around the far side of the Crab Stands to get a different look at the boats (this is the actual Fisherman's Wharf).  There is a nice promenade from Pier 43 down to Pier 39.  And, the views from the upper-deck of Pier 39 are cool, particularly by the Sea Lion Visitor Center (great view of the GGB).
*Have one classic Fisherman's Wharf meal.  If you are going Crab Stands do actual Crab, a Crab Sandwich or Chowder.  Crab isn't cheap, but you will likely never sit at a Crab Stand and eat Crab a second time.  Sandwich:  Sabella and LaTorre.  Soup:  Crab Chowder at Nick's Lighthouse.
*Sit Down Meal:  Scoma's or Alioto's
*Go to a bar and talk to tourists.  Gold Dust is great and has a storied past (albeit at a different location).  Buena Vista is the home of Irish Coffee in the US.  Castagnola's has really fun live music, especially when Paul is playing.  Jack's has tons of beer to try and also live music.
*Musee Mechanique.  I will say no more, but you're welcome in advance.
*Two local street acts:  Bushman and old time magician Jerry Roy Salazar.
*See the bread made at Boudin.
*If you want to hit one shop:  Frank's Fisherman.
*If you are going to get something SF to wear:  San Francisco Giants cap.  Instant Baller.

Things you Should NOT Do:
*Buy a T-shirt or any lame trinket.  Teach your kids now.  Quality.
*Be hard-sold.  There are some hard sellers.  Don't do it!
*Eat at a chain or at Pier 39.  This would be like going to the Louvre and looking at Dogs Playing Poker.  You're in SF.  Use Yelp wisely.  Reach out to an Elite - we'll tell you what's up.
*Avoid any place with an employee in a bad mood.  If you're at a place with a service industry person in a bad mood, that place sucks.  A lot.  And, feel free not to tip those folks. 
*Give money to anyone.  Trust me.  It's not heartless.  People come to Fisherman's Wharf to pray on gullible tourists.  Also don't feed Seagulls.  
*Walk five-wide on a sidewalk.  And, don't do that any other place either, tourists.  Some of us have some place to be.  Also, you don't get 5 minutes to frame your photo on a busy sidewalk.  More than five seconds, I'm photo-bombing you.  And also, if you're in line for 10 minutes at In-and-Out, could you know what you want?  There are like three things on the menu.
*Bad VPL.  Seems alarmingly prevalent.
*Dodgers Gear.  Sad  :(
author: Adam S.

description:
Another day more fun!

Again another fun place to visit with the shops and restaurants.
Easy place to get to, by bus or cable car.
Just soak up the atmosphere and enjoy!
author: Rain B.

description:
Fishermans Wharf is in the heart of tourist attractions.  It's in the middle of the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz, Ghirardelli Square, Coit Tower and Pier 39.  If you ride the Powell/Hyde cable car line, it ends there by the wharf.  

The wharf has restaurants, souvenir shops and tour companies.  Some of the restaurants on the wharf are just ok so make sure to do some research.  Like many tourist spots there are street performers to entertain.  

This spot is very busy with walking tourists as well as traffic.  Although it is worth the visit especially for the views over the water.
author: Bethany E.

description:
This is a must if you are visiting San Francisco. You can walk around to all the shops and restaurants that are there. They have the menus posted out front so you can decided where you want to eat and what you want before you go in. You really can't go wrong at any of them if you want good fresh seafood. Some of them have the crabs and catch of the day outside on ice to see. You can walk along the entire Embarcadero area and feel safe. 

We were on a cruise ship so we walked from the ship all the way to Ghirardelli Square. They have the chocolate store there as well as some other very nice shops. You can also catch the Cable Car at the 'turnaround" across the street. There is a very nice park you can stroll through and get some great views of Alcatraz. You can also catch a street car or bus along the route. We can't wait to go back.
author: Richard F.

description:
So much to see, smell, taste and take pictures of here! The entire Embarcadero area is a must visit for any tourists and visitors of the Bay Area. There are many great opportunities for photos of the San Francisco Bay, great seafood restaurants and plenty of souvenir shops to roam around in. I can't begin to tell you how many restaurants and gift shops there are here. For dining, you can't go wrong with Fog Harbor Fish House, Crab House at Pier 39 or La Mar Cebichería Peruana. If you're seeking a seafood snack, stop by Chowders for some ... well ... chowder! In addition, there's an In-N-Out within the area and towards the end is Ghirardelli Square for all you chocolate lovers. 

If you plan on roaming around the wharf for a long period of time, don't forget to bring those comfy shoes/sneakers because there's plenty of real estate to cover! Also, be prepared for the wind sometimes by bringing a long sleeve shirt or something to put over your short-sleeve tee. One final note, if you decide to drive here and don't want to pay an arm and a leg for parking, skip the parking garages and look for street parking. Every time I've been here, there were always plenty of metered spots nearby.
author: Chris E.

description:
DO NOT come here during any holiday...especially for July 4th.

We came here to hang out during the day and hope to watch the fireworks at night. First of all surrounding parking lots were charging $60 flat rate. So many people were taking pictures of the rates because it was so outrageous. But we knew we didn't have a choice because we saw another lot charging $100. 

Besides the weather being cold and windy.....there are way too many people. All the restaurants were jam packed. The fireworks were supposed to start at 7pm. But they didn't start until about 9:30. We were cold so decided to huddle up in a restaurant.....any restaurant. It seemed every restaurant we went into were super crowded, with no seating and no service. We even went inside Starbucks to use their facility and they required a receipt. We didn't mind buying anything except the line to buy a drink was about an hour's wait. 

It took forever for the fireworks to start. When it did start, we couldn't see the fireworks that well because it was super foggy. We decided to leave about 15 mins early before the crowd because we knew the traffic getting out of the area would be a nightmare.  WE FAILED.  It took us another 2 hours to finally get out of the parking lot, the streets which most of them were closed off, and going around thousands of people walking in the streets holding up traffic.

Overall the fisherman's wharf is a fun place to visit during non-holidays (although Pier 39 has better attractions and restaurants). Please stay away from here unless you live within walking distance during the holidays.
author: Sharr K.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf is a sea-side boardwalk with a lot of stores, including seafood restaurants, touristy clothing stores, and some other ones! 

You can easily spend day weaving through stores and checking out new places to eat. I personally loved this candy shop with lots of purchasable memorabilia from the 1900s! I wish I remembered it's name!

Walk a little further towards the Navy Pier, and you'll find Pier 39 with ships from WWII in the water! There's a building in front with lots of arcade games from the WWII era! And they're all just 25-50cents!!
author: Vaishu M.

description:
Really great place to spend time 

Love all of fishermans wharf 
The sea loins at pier 41/39 

Street performers 
The vibe is really great 

Fresh air by the water with views at the docks 

Really a great place 

Just wish they had specific smoking areas not everywhere
author: Ruby P.

description: Try the app Parking Panda to get cheaper parking rates. There is a lot to do and great seafood to eat. I'm told there is some guy who dresses like a bush and jumps at you when walking by. I didn't see him
author: David W.

description: A lot of things to do and see. Brought the family and we had a great time. San Francisco is kinda expensive though, so plan on spending some cash. It's inexpensive to get there as far as airfare is concerned, but the hotels, food, attractions and tours add up quickly.
author: Clint C.

description:
One of San Francisco's must-go-to's!

You can park your car in a parking garage nearby and get your ticket validated for one hour in participating restaurants.

Fisherman's Wharf has various restaurants and bars as well as souvenir shops. Like most reviews have stated already, this is a tourist trap.

If you go to the side of the Wharf, you can find seals relaxing on the floating boards.

What's really cool here is that there's always a talented street performer in the middle of the entrance of Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Aj C.

description: Been here so many times.. I lost count. It's a nice whole strip to walk and see SF. They have street performers here sometimes. I always take people from outside of the bay area here. Great tourist place with good restaurants and outside food stands. I would get Clam chowder here~
author: Yennie L.

description: Perhaps it's because I'm not a San Francisco native that I give this place 5 stars.  But this place is GREAT!  There's a bunch of street performances (for tip), music, food, shopping and touristy photo-ops!  During my tour of SF, I spend the most time at Fisherman's Wharf and couldn't finish everything I wanted to do under 2 hours.  It's a must-see attraction and worth the hype!  Again, this could be because I'm straight out of LA and I don't see sea lions hanging on a pier every day.  I walked here from the top of Lombard Street, which is only about a 5 minute walk, and I saw plenty of parking in their lots...just wasn't sure how much it was.  I'm sure you can also Lyft here for pretty cheap.  I can't wait until my next SF trip!
author: Jennifer T.

description:
This is a must go place when you're in San Fran. It was a beautiful day when we went. You have many options to choose from when ordering your seafood. We ordered the clam chowder bowl and it was top notch delicious. People are very friendly. It met all my expectations- liked the atmosphere and the vibe, good music and the smell of the water was the cherry on top.
It's everything that you would associate with the name fisherman's wharf.
author: Marley B.

description: Had. Great time here with my wife. Did some shopping and watched the seals play. The coin operated museum was super interesting and fun.
author: Kyle W.

description: Better than i expected! Bring so many memories! I had such a good time here, so many things to do from restaurants, shops, and activities. We liked it so much we went back a second time during our stay in San Fran! Will definitely come back!
author: Chau Q.

description:
There's always lots to do & see! 
Here's some tips & helpful info:

Metered parking $4.50 per hour. 2 hours max. Credit cards accepted
(SFPD will closely monitor this.)

Parking at pier 39 garage
$9 per hour
1 hour free parking with validation from a restaurant ON the pier
Bring your parking ticket with you to pay on your way out.
Park on level 3 or 4 to walk across the walkway to Pier 39

Aquarium by the Bay:
$22-$23 adults 
$14 for children 12 & under

15% off at Pier Market, crab house or grill out with purchase of a ticket to the aquarium

It's always windy by the bay, so bring a jacket.

Fisherman's wharf: average food price $10 per person + drinks

$7-$9 Clam chowder at any of the restaurant with street side service
$8 fish & chips 

Other restaurants available:
* Rainforest cafe: great for the kids
* Joe's Crab Shack
* Applebee's
* Boudin: be sure to check out the animal shaped bread
* McDonalds

* Lots of touristy places for souvenirs (postcards, really?!) magnets, T-shirts, Jackets & sweaters (in case you forget yours you can always buy a "I  SF" sweater & local tours and bay cruises.
* if your planning on being in SF for 3 days you can purchase unlimited cable car rides from the tickets to the aquarium or check out https://www.sfmta.com/getting-around/transit/routes-stops/powell-hyde for more info
* Check out the seals (yes. They smell)
Street performers as you walk
* Ripleys Believe or not
* CVS & 7-11 for your basic needs

* Just an FYI (& where this area loses one star) be prepared for the crowds & go to the restaurants for bathroom breaks.

Otherwise have fun & take lots of pretty pictures by the Bay
author: Riz B.

description:
Definitely a must visit spot each time I'm in SF~! 

I love coming to the wharf because you can spend a few hours just checking everything out! My favorite things about the wharf is:
+ The shops
+ Souvenirs
+ IN-N-OUT
+ Clam chowder
+ Sea Lions
+ Street performances
author: Ariana M.

description:
Dirty, expensive, and overrated!  If you love homeless people begging you for money while your trying to migrate into one of the Wharf's many tourist traps then this place is for you.  You can buy many of the same items at local stores for less money.  The food is very below average and expensive.

We ate a few places on the Wharf and were not impressed.  Not sure what the draw is here!
author: Le C.

description:
I love this tourist trap. 10/8/16 on an odd Saturday evening. Fleet week is in full swing and the city is packed with tourists. 

So many great restaurants and attractions to choose from here for a great memorable day.

I grew up with my family going to Alioto's every once in a while. So I'm partial to that restaurant but probably biased. Great views, the best crab ever and beautiful ambiance and top notch service. Street food is cheaper and crab seems to be similar quality?! I love walking past all those boiling pots of water where they throw live crabs in. Can't get fresher than that.

Sure parking is expensive and you might not want to drive here yourself. I suggest you Uber on in from your hotel.

Taking time to see the street performers and people watching is a must. I like the old arcade with the ancient Laughing Sal. Be sure and have a penny pressed of her for .50 as a souvenir. Maybe look for a sailboat ride under the Golden Gate.

The wax museum is similar to the one in Vegas and I would suggust you avoid chains such as Bubba Gumps. You can get that even in Puerto Vallarta. Its less interesting. Don't go to Denny's or McDonalds either. That would be sad if you are a tourist - and I'm assuming you are if your reading this.
author: Stefan T.

description: I loved this area. Cool vibes and creative souls surrounded the place. It was a little dirty, but it was a nifty place to catch a part of the Frisco culture. You will find hidden gems around, so be on the lookout. It is a little crowded and touristy, but has a really laid-back vibe. This is definitely a place to visit.
author: Ina M.

description: Eclectic array of various seafood, pastry, and sweet shops. You'll be sure to run into local talent along the piers and the sounds of sea lions in the distance. Be prepared to walk, so good shoes are best to enjoy the full experience. It's crowded throughout even weekdays due to travelers from across the globe coming to visit. It's a must see, if you're in the area. Pier 39-41!!
author: Tiffany L.

description: I've been there with my family a lot. Love the sunshine, food and sea there. If you are thinking about places for taking your partner to go, it is denifinitely a good place to consider.
author: Ylbb L.

description: Another MUST for any tourist.  The wharf is filled with restaurants, shops and people watching.  We killed a few hours walking around and enjoying the day.  My biggest warning is that parking can be a challenge.  Just throw yourself into the pay lot across the street.
author: Chris G.

description:
WOOHOOO, you know what you are getting when you come to Fisherman's Wharf. It is a HUGE tourist trap with hella crowds and the smell of seafood everywhere. And don't forget Boudin! 

Seriously though, even though everything at Fisherman's Wharf is overpriced, I do suggest coming to check out the Wharf once or twice in your life. Even though I DESPITE tourist traps, you don't know what you'll see here. The last time I was out here, there were dancers performing on the street, a guy on a huge unicycle, and other amazing things. You get an experience even without spending a penny. 

As others have said, Fisherman's Wharf is home and it's quite amazing that the city has something like this to draw in people from far off.

Have fun and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
It's very touristy, overcrowded sometimes, but still very fun for a first time visitor. It's easy to pay a lot of money for overpriced souvenirs, just walk a few blocks away and you'll see the prices drop. 
Boudin Bakery is one of the highlights of that little area for eating some classic sourdough. 
Parking here is horrible. Do anything you can to use public transit or at least Uber/Lyft in to town instead of driving.
There are always street performers, musicians, and various acts going on. Definitely worth spending some time walking around. It's a great place!
author: Denae L.

description:
Sigh - it's turned into a circus. Too many people, just not my thing anymore. I've come to Fisherman's Wharf many times over the last 30-40 years, and it just slowly degrades - mostly due to the hoards of people. The hoards of seals are fine - they just hang out - but the people don't act as well.

The place grows, the businesses prosper, and it is still a place to be. Me - I try to find the wonderful within what is there - and I won't mention anything specific, but there are still a few gems that are indeed discovered, but haven't caved to the tourist.
author: Dan D.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf makes me smile... Granted it is a touristy area, but it's still pleasant... Getting a chance to see The San Francisco Bay and Alcatraz Island from just steps away in the area is pretty cool to me. I could just stand around staring for a while. 

The area comes equip with all type of eateries from Johnny Rocket, In N Out, local establishments and so many others. In addition to eateries there were many locations for tourist style shopping, galleries, museums, and more. You really can get a lot done in this area.


Parking in the area is available, for a price of course. But Public Transportation is very easy to get to in this area.
author: Shercole K.

description:
Yes, touristy, but also a pretty good time and fun place to check out.  The street entertainment is always "interesting" and on a beautiful day the views are amazing.

It's a great place to grab some clam chowder in a bread bowl, people watch and take in the local flavor.

Be sure to wear comfy shoes.
author: Lucky S.

description: Nice place to go with your family! Loved it , surely will visit again  went to the chocolate factory, all the stores.. really clean and pretty!
author: Erika C.

description: Went back today and I do not recommend Nick's Lighthouse located at Fisherman's Wharf. The customer service was awful. The woman that was at the register was so rude. Also, I went back today to try the clam chowder and I felt like crap after that chowder.
author: Mailoha A.

description:
Checked in on May 31, 2016.

It might be one of the more famous stops in San Francisco, but I found it a tourist trap!  I was not impressed by the tacky souvenir shops, the restaurants piled on each other.  It was an eye sore.  I'm sure that if someone wants to eat seafood, there are other classy places in SFO.
author: Anjali A.

description: Fisherman's Wharf is a fun place to visit. Views of San Francisco Bay including the Golden Gate Bridge and Alcatraz. Near Ghirardelli Square there are historic ships that you can explore. Lots of shops and restaurants line the Wharf and you can't miss the famous Pier 39 - stop to say hello to the Sea Lions.
author: Debby W.

description:
I live in the city and coming here makes me still feel like a tourist. All the unique tourist shops are there to browse around in. Then you have the breadbowl food. The only In-n-Out Burger location in the city. People, people... annoying street performers. The guy that hides behind some branches pretending he is a bush and then jumps-out at you and scares you. 
Walk all the way to the end and you have Ghirardelli square for desserts.  Keep on walking until you get to the Pier and walk up the pier to get a fantastic view of the Golden Gate Bridge.

Little gems and cheap thrills are things like the submarine or the super retro arcade - must sees.

The cable car lines are long but they get you to Union Square on a roll or coaster-like ride. Or you can use the streetcar that will take you along the Embarcadero and all the way down market street.

Go get lost in one of the millions of novelty shops here.
author: Khash C.

description: There is a lot that you can do here for us tourists, and most of them are pretty fun we spent about two days in this area and I enjoyed all of it. But make sure you have an idea of what you want to do while you're here!
author: Chase H.

description: Every time we visit the Bay Area, the wharf is a must stop on our list. I love everything about it except the crowds, parking, and a few weirdos. Only thing I can control is the parking, since it is next to impossible, we take the ferry over from Jack London Square, and it lets us off right at Pier 41 and picks up from same location. It is so many places to eat here, and you really cannot go wrong with anything because one thing is for sure, the seafood will be very fresh. They have a ton of cheesy souvenir shops, street performers, museums, and plenty of activities to do. Bike rides, Segway rides, lots of different tours, and boat excursions. There is a lot to see, just depends on how much walking you want to do. If you ever visit San Francisco, this is a must do at least once.
author: Simone T.

description:
Yes, it's a very touristy area - but hey, if you're a tourist, how can you not visit this place?

I came here on a beautiful weekday afternoon, and took the Powell-Hyde cablecar from Union Square, so it was like killing 2 birds with 1 stone kinda thing in terms of getting the tourist attractions out of the way. The Wharf itself has a LOT of touristy places (very similar to Times Square), which you can probably do better skipping out on, but it's cool to walk around and see all the hustle and bustle happening around you. Many gift shop options for you to buy souvenirs for your loved ones, but do yourself a favor and utilize Yelp to your advantage in terms of choosing a place to eat in the area.
author: Tashnuva E.

description:
First off It is packed, as in it can be hard to walk in areas.  It is filled with Tourist trap places, shops selling junk souvenirs and a few gems.  Enjoy the crowd,  take a boat to Alcatraz,  go to the end and walk out the pier for the views and pictures.  Then keep going around the old military base until you get to the Marina...I am missing walking in San Francisco.  Its a great city to walk in.

You can get to Fishermans Wharf by foot (I like walking down through China Town and Northbeach.  You can also take the historic streetcars.  Or you can take a cable car.  (ok you can take a bus or drive, those options just aren't as fun)/

Fisherman's Wharf is a place to let yourself be a tourist.  Eat at Boudin (I like their chili in a bread bowl) or at In and Out,  have a sundae at Ghirardelli Chocolate,  check out tours (you are on vacation) and don't miss the street entertainers,  or the national park visiter center... 

The Fisherman's Wharf area has plenty do to keep you busy for as much time as you have.  Just remember there are lots of great neighborhoods in san francisco I could say the same for.
author: Mark B.

description: After 50 years it's still one of my favorite spots. Yes it's full of ticky tacky shops and mediocre restaurants, but there are a few good ones. Find one you like and grab some 'to-go'. Ignore the tourist traps, sit and chow down in the harbor watching the fishing boats rock 'n roll. Check out www.pioneerseafoods.com if they're in port, then walk up and over the hill to Fort Mason and beyond. Just my 2c.
author: Patrick M.

description:
The atmosphere of Pier 39 is more what I imagined Fisherman's Wharf to be like but they are waaaaay different. Fisherman's Wharf is literally a small street with stalls to buy seafood.

The food I might have wanted to try but it's hard to muster up hunger with all the nasty bird poop and giant mutant seagulls begging all over the street. If you must go to the piers, skip this and go to Pier 39 instead. I suggest parking at Ghirardelli Square in their garage because it wasn't very crowded and then walking to the wharf.
author: Christine S.

description: Such a cool place, I've been to the pier in Seattle, and this spot reminded me a lot of the PNW! the open air feel, and being close to the water. You never know what you'll see at the Wharf :) , I hope that I get to see it at night with all of the signs lit up... I'm a sucker for pictures. I have to say if you want an easy day of just strolling, and seeing what there is by the docks ( in the way of fresh fish) I would say that you can't really beat this spot. There are a few parking decks close by, and the prices are pretty reasonable for those. There are many places to eat at the wharf ( just take your pick on the type of food you want) and there is something for everyone there.
author: Stephanie K.

description: Brought back a lot of memories. Enjoyed the clam chowder, have to come back for the lobster roll.
author: Fau Z.

description: Tourist trap.....prices for anything in the area were horrendous. I walked all over the wharf and it smelled of something wicked. If your ever going to San Francisco in the future, don't call me for company :).
author: Rick T.

description:
Someone referred to this as SF's answer to Pike's Place in Seattle.. Hmm.. Kinda, I guess. Both very touristy, obviously. But offer cool attractions and great food. So yeah, in those ways these places are similar. 

We went to FW on a windy, but sunny day. You can spend a whole day shopping at nifty stores or eating a swanky restaurants. But even if you're not looking to spend a lot of money this is a fun place to people watch- if the weather is nice.

 One thing that separates FW from Pikes Place is the street performances. Some pretty spectacular stuff happens right there on the sidewalk, so keep your eyes peeled!
author: Jacob H.

description: Came here for the clam chowder a while ago on a trip and I have to say the clam chowder here is amazing I will come back for some more very very soon!
author: M Z.

description: This is Times Square. Apparently, decades ago, there were cool artisan booths. Now, it's all graphic t-shirts and assorted expensive tourist apparel. Probably worth a visit when you first visit SF - just to check out In N Out, Alcatraz, sea lions.
author: Judy S.

description:
Who doesn't love Fisherman's Wharf?  There are steamy bowls clam chowder in sourdough bowls, sweet delicious lobster rolls, the crazy bush guy that jumps out and scared the crap out of my brother, sea lions sunbathing on the decks, seagulls bravely attacking people for food, Pier 39, and shops and restaurants galore!  

Fisherman's Wharf is a tourist spot with so much life and culture.  It's always crowded but beautiful weather and gorgeous skies always makes the foot traffic a little more bearable.  It's the Segway Tour people that makes me more enraged than anything.   It's fun and cheery in the daytime but the real magic is at night.  The night air is a little crisper and the twinkling lights makes everything feel more magical. What more is there to say?
author: Joyce W.

description: Absolutely worth the visit if you find yourself in San Francisco! It was one of those experiences that you have to give yourself if your in the area. I will say it felt like a little bit of a tourist trap so be smart about what your buying and don't go over board. Did end up purchasing a few decal shirts that were customized but they were not over priced and they were something I could not get just anywhere so it was worth it.
author: Lance P.

description: Unfortunately, only had about two hours to see Fisherman's Wharf and it is HUGE. Ideally, would have loved to spend four or five hours walking around. There are tons of unique shops to discover and the boardwalk has all kinds of interesting performances. There are also a ton of unique restaurants to try out. It does get a little crowded with tourists, but nothing too overwhelming. By far, my favorite part was Pier 39 where the seals go to sunbath. There were a ton of them just lying out because it was sunny day. I would definitely recommend an afternoon at Fisherman's Wharf on a sunny day if you have time. You are on the bay so bring a light jacket as it will be a little cooler.
author: Priya S.

description:
Reminded me of Redondo Beach except with more street performers.  If you want to do a tour of Treasure Island or any of the smaller islands on the bay, you can come to the wharf and buy tix from there.  

Lots of souvenir shops; yes, pricey but hey.  What can I say?

Lots of restaurants where you can get some of that famous clam chowder.  You can't be at the wharf and not get chowder.  

I would love to come back here and take a more leisurely stroll, discover and fall in love with the City.
author: Chris H.

description:
The Fisherman's Wharf is one of San Francisco's great tourist spots!

There's lots of restaurants, gift shops and attractions on this pier.

One of the great attractions they have is the SF Bay Aquarium! Before you enter the aquarium you pass by their gift shop where they have tons of toys even from Finding Dory!

The only downside to Pier 39 is the parking garage, especially on the weekends. One word of advice is to get there early or you'll be stuck trying to find parking. Also remember to get your parking validated when you eat at one of the restaurants!

Overall Fisherman's Wharf is one of my favorite places to visit when I'm in SF. Please stop when you get the chance you won't be disappointed!
author: Andrew L.

description:
What. A TOURIST TRAPPPPP. 

I was also approached by a creepy Indian dude who said I look like I should smile more. I was literally up for 30 hours and the trip to The Bay severely tired me out. Like damn leave me alone. Oh and he tried to sell me a sticker or something. 

Parking is literally the worst. There is no look and see at this place. They encourage you to pay absurd amounts of money in order to visit the place with caps up to $45. 

Generally comparing this place to other places, I rather visit any SoCal tourist beach traps than ever come here again. Traffic is horrible, bathrooms are hard to find, crazies are around, and worst of all parking is horrible. 

In this lifetime I shan't come to this place again.
author: Siamrath B.

description:
Eat crab. Drink cold beer. Repeat. Do. Not. Miss. Out. On. The. Crab! 

Touristy, but yeah I LIKE It...I like it A LOT. Not nearly as crowded and annoying as all of the over-priced Disney-like crap offered at Pier 39 just down the way. Crab lover heaven. drool ...drool......

Fun fact: "Did you know Fisherman's Wharf is the eighth-most-visited tourist destination in the country with about 10 million annual visitors?" - Nope, but I do now... so I learned from The Layover with Anthony Bourdain.
author: Dawn H.

description: Lots of entertainment and eateries and good buys. Bring all the snow gear you own cz it gets cold out here.
author: Maridel A.

description: omg we loveeeee it here, love to bring my kids here to walk the pier and enjoy the clam chowder...we love to enjoy the weather and get out of sacramento.
author: IslandGirl 3.

description:
We were lucky to book our hotel in fisherman's wharf, a lot of seafood restaurant and souvenir shops you can spend a good hour walking.
My tip don't buy sandwiches from the seafood restaurants  just across the street from the fisherman's wharf sign ( only soup is good no crab or shrimp sandwiches).
author: Hani G.

description:
A nice boardwalk area by the water is what the Fisherman's Wharf and its famous Pier 39 is....

What do you expect to find here is lotssss of tourists, expensive souvenir shops (try going down and inside street, they have better deals), cool street performers, lots of different things to eat (if you are foodie like me you will enjoying trying different things), many friendly locals and few not so friendly and sea lions!

Its quite a enjoyable place and very very good for a pleasant walk along the water. Don't just go to Pier 39... take a walk and enjoy the view and shops in the area. See if you can find Mickey and Minnie's mini size statues where the boats are parked.
author: Bilal S.

description:
Ah the infamous Fisherman's Wharf!  This place is definitely a must for tourist. It reminds me of Redondo Beach or the Third Street Promenade in Los Angeles.  

They have loads of gift shops and eateries here. The view of Alcatraz to Angel Island is spectacular.  How I wish these views exist in smoggy LA!  

Fisherman's Wharf is one of the prime locations close to fancy Knob Hill.  It's definitely a place to visit while enjoying the history behind it.

Parking is not easy to find, and the lots are not cheap. Way more expensive than LA.

From its sea breeze,  it gets gets cold there,  and can be freezing in the winter. Button up!
author: ED L.

description: Not a great place to visit, only maybe once ok, full with rude people, expensive items on pier 39, sick birds, heavy traffic around noon. Forget about the ghetto feeling up and down embarcadero at night. Few attractions nearby. SF stinks. Only go there once or if you really need to.
author: Marco C.

description: This is a classic tourist trap, but it's still pretty fun! There are a ton of restaurants and activities as well as some pretty amazing views of Alcatraz and the Golden Gate Bridge. My two favorite areas are Musee Mechanique and Pier 39, which has the amazing sea lions and is definitely a reason to visit in and of itself. I stopped here around 10 AM on a Saturday and it was pretty empty, so that seems like a good time to visit!
author: Kevin B.

description: A popular tourist spot, and it has always been packed no matter when you came. Lots of restaurants around.
author: Maruko X.

description:
Must see while in San Francisco!

Yes this is a tourist spot so everything costs more but it's worth it to at least check it out and take some pictures.  Get a small bread bowl filled with chowder and eat it on the pier. All part of the San Francisco experience.  Also this is a great spot to buy gifts for friends. This is also a great place to people watch as it is always packed.  I wouldn't necessarily recommend having dinner here as all the prices are increased. There is also a cute wine bar on the pier that has a great selection of California wines. There is also a trampoline bungee that is super fun!
author: Mac W.

description: Went there with the family for a little vacation and we all enjoyed it. The view of the bay and bridges also of Alcatraz. The wharf itself had plenty to do and good food. We did spend a lot of time watching the sea lions fight for a spot on the platforms. ( see video). Recommend it to all visitors. But it did get cold
author: Jeff C.

description: This is definitely one of the go-to tourist attractions for our out-of-town guests - it never gets old! After all these years, I still wonder how all the stands survive when they sell basically the exact same thing...haha! All the shops are nice to look at and we really enjoy visiting Boudin and seeing all the daily creations that they freshly bake!
author: Cathy W.

description: A must-go for anyone visiting San Francisco. If you get lucky, you'll see the sea lions swimming around and playing with eachother.
author: Kevin F.

description:
My husband and I visited Fisherman's Wharf two days in a row. The first day, an early Friday morning, the place seemed calm and serene. We were able to walk the wharf and wander at a leisurely pace. We stopped to see the sea lions on Pier 39 and had a wonderful view of them. It was an amazing experience to see and hear them barking. Honestly, this was the best part of Fisherman's Wharf. As the morning turned into afternoon, it started to get busier and became crowded. This was when we decided to leave and come back the next day. 

The second visit, a Saturday early afternoon, the place was packed. It was crazy busy - barely any room to walk, hard to navigate from shop to shop, and incredibly loud. We went to see the sea lions again and it was hard to find a space to stand. We didn't stay long as the crowds were overwhelming.

Overall, the best experience was the sea lions and I would highly recommend seeing them. I would recommend going early in the morning, preferably on a weekday, in order to avoid the crowds. The crowds really start to show up after lunch time and seem to be a constant on weekends.
author: Nicole B.

description:
We had a great time visiting Fisherman's Wharf!

This is a beautiful tourist trap with a lot going on and many things to choose from to spend your money and have a good time.  Various shops including a kite store (location!) along with theatre, boat tours, trolley tours, the Alcatraz and bay tour, and the aquarium.  There's also tons of shops, seafood stands, restaurants, an arcade, and much more.

We were there 12/14 and the decorated Christmas tree was gorgeous along with the rest of the holiday lights and decorations.

We had a blast at all of the shops and places we visited.

This is a great place to go for anyone regardless of age.  Make sure you wear your tennis shoes.

The parking garage is steep but you can get some of the time validated at a participating restaurant.  We went to the Hard Rock.
author: Sheri C.

description:
Eh. I have heard a lot of good things about Fisherman's Wharf; about the food, the fun, and the entertainment. When I got there, I did not really have any good food and didn't see any entertainment. All I saw was overpriced things to buy and nothing but TOURISTS. 

The one thing I really enjoyed was the view, however. There is a great view of both bridges and of Alcatraz island. Coming from Sausalito, you can get dropped off at Pier 33 (or 39 I think) and walk across the pier to try the food or just get a taste of the most touristy areas I have ever seen. 

Definitely a place you MUST go to if you haven't been, but I don't plan on going here unless I have to the next time I'm back in San Fran.
author: Melvin M.

description: We thought Fisherman's Wharf in Monterey was cool, we were wrrrrong, this one takes the (cup)cake.  Biggest, baddest wharf around.  Lots of cool eateries, touristy tchotchke shops, snacks places (ice cream, cupcake), tours to check out Alcatraz (or just see it from a distance on Pier 39, along with the Golden Gate Bridge).  We loved the Musee Mecanique and noshed on a cupcake from Cup & Cake Cafe.  We watched some street performers, snapped touristy pics with our selfie stick and overall had a good time.  It was a Sunday and very crowded. We parked in a distant lot (World Market Lot) for about $15.  It'll cost more as you get closer to the Wharf.  Check it out if you haven't.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
If visitors in NYC are turned on by Times Square, surely the same can be said for tourists checking out Fisherman's Wharf in SF. It is a hood that most San Franciscans avoid and is home to some the most popular businesses in the city. My two cents? Come by and bask in the tourist aura, reserve your judgements until the experience is fully embraced.

While it was established as far back as the Gold Rush era for commercial fishing, it still very much remains a spot where fishermen and their ships work today. The oodles of seafood caught from this part of town are still put on display and sold to anyone who is willing to buy some locally caught fare. Leave the fishing rod at home though, no one without a permit is dipping their hooks into the water anytime soon.

Understandably, there are cheesy chain restaurants, expensive ventures for the kids and family, and more people crammed into one area than all of the rest of the city. There will be lots of distractions, gimmicky souvenirs to be sold, but that's not to say it's all a bad time. Here's why:

* It is home to the only In-N-Out Burger (http://www.yelp.com/biz/in-n-out-burger-san-francisco) in SF proper. It's by no means the best In-N-Out, but if you can't head to Millbrae or Daly City for a vastly superior version, then this will just have to do.

* Enjoy watching some of the sea life and an incredible, brisky view from Pier 39. (http://www.yelp.com/biz/pier-39-san-francisco). One can catch some serious views of the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz, and the rest of the SF skyline.

* If there is one venue to hit up in FIsherman's Wharf, it's the Musée Mécanique. (http://www.yelp.com/biz/mus%C3%A9e-m%C3%A9canique-san-francisco-4) Unless you've been there 10x, it is a fun place to visit and peruse. It's even better with kids.

* Hit up the dungeness crab and other chowder stands (http://www.yelp.com/biz/fishermans-wharf-chowder-and-crab-sidewalk-stands-san-francisco) along the sidewalk if *you must* but know that the Codmother (http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-codmother-fish-and-chips-san-francisco) is your best bet for a quality seafood experience.
author: Jando S.

description:
Oh the Wharf, how I can never get tired of the briny smell of the air or the lively characters you see performing on the streets.. This tourist hotspot is fantastic, and has so much energy with all the different people, cool shops and delicious seafood restaurants here. There is so much to see, and if you can handle crowded streets and the bustle of this high traffic area, I definitely recommend seeing everything the Wharf has to offer, from the Musée Méchanique, to Boudin, the SF Dungeon, Wax Museum, and many more. 

Just be aware that parking and driving here is hectic. If you are on foot, I recommend coming from Pier 39 and walking through here to get to Aquatic Park and continuing up to Ghirardelli Square and Lombard Street. 

Overall, this area makes Pier 39 feel so much more calm and empty with everyone walking through here, but definitely don't be hesitated to come by, because there is something for everyone here! Just be sure to bring a decent budget and a good jacket because it can get windy. Most of the time, however, the weather is fantastic and it just contributes to an even better vibe in this place. Oh, and the briny sea smell? You'll love it! :)
author: Kyrie S.

description: A beautiful place to go when you visit San Francisco. So many places to eat, shop, look around. The history is very interesting and the atmosphere is a great place to be in.
author: Chris D.

description: OMG.  Fisherman's Wharf is so full of tourists, street performers, and junk for sale that it feels like a combination of Hollywood Blvd and Venice, but it's a cool spot for a view of Alcatraz, that iconic Fisherman's Wharf San Francisco sign, a frenzy of local food, and the always enjoyable sea lions at Pier 39.
author: Glen N.

description:
Out of all the piers I've been to, the SF Fisherman's Wharf is the best. Not only are there a bunch of things to do along the strip (Pier 39, Wax Museum, etc), there's a LOT of things to eat. The only downside is that there's a lot of people there all the time (which is the only reason why I didn't give it a 5 star). 

Food:
While there are Bubba Gump, Boudin, and Rainforest Cafe (etc) restaurants nearby, my advice is  skip all the restaurants and head a little PAST Pier 39 to that strip of small to-go "restaurants" (Not sure what that whole street is called) for some FRESH & cheap seafood. Sure, you don't get the whole sit down & service deal, but I'm willing to sacrifice all of that for some fresh seafood. Plus, they give you HUGE portions. Definitely go if you are a seafood fanatic! Note: there is A LOT of people there.

Sightseeing:
Besides the whole Pier 39 thing, there are a lot of cute little stores a little farther from that. For example, there's a really cool hot sauce place called Hot Licks. This place sells ALL SORTS of different hot sauces/salsa. They have a middle bar displayed with some hot sauces that you can sample! 

Overall, a really fun place to visit and definitely a MUST for tourists! But this place is probably NOT for people who don't like crowds.
author: Jovian L.

description:
Who goes to San Fran and not visit the FW? Not me. Although I'm as guilty as my friend Tommy was in not writing a review.  He's done his part and I can't twiddle my thumbs anymore without looking suspicious. 

Just like the best places to go, there is nothing more to say about Fisherman's Wharf that hasn't been said by everyone, so I'll just write about how I view this one of the magical place to go. 

The hustle and bustle of the tourists and locals alike always give me a sense of purpose from reaching all the best spots. Yep, more often than not, you have to be doubly patient and very aware of the signs and turns you make as the throng of street crossers can be very distracting. Let's not even get into parking fees as they can cost an eye and a tooth (I think an arm and a leg is so overused so I made my own).

I've been to Alcatraz from the Ferry building, feasted on fish and crabs after making our way up and down the boardwalk of a Pier 39. Watched the many performances as we moved along some more interesting than the next, earning them a few minutes of our time and a tip of course. I love, love watching the seals that are so graciously showy. 

Oh no, this is making me want to make that 8+ hour drive now. Hmmm maybe sooner than later.
author: Cristine G.

description:
Havent been here since 1989. Wow, what a shithole. 
Coming from the ultimate shithole downtown L.A, would never think anywhere in the US would have more trash, but this takes the gold. Extremely crowded, sampled few foods and wasnt blown away by anything. Bird shit, sewer smells, nastee as hell freak shows, but then again WTF can a tourist do during the day? Come early for metered parking, or its lights out muthafucka for $40/pop lots.
When your highlight of the day is the CVS pharmacy across the way, that shit just ain't right.
Basically only worthwhile thing I did was have a sourdough bowl of chowda, nothing else memorable, food, crowd, or shops.
Can barely look around cant stand anywhere from the herd coming at ya in every imaginable direction, damn santa monica pier is even better...can't believe I am saying that.
author: GG M.

description: Out of all tourist spots reccommended in SF, i would say WF is a go-to. Lived in SF my whole life and i never get tired of this place.
author: Stacey M.

description: This place is full of rude tourists, random side shows and homeless people. The shops are not worthwhile and only sell cheap tourist souvenirs. There are a lot of food places! This is the spot for clam chowder. It's good to visit once in your lifetime, but you won't be missing out if you don't.
author: Camellia P.

description: kind of seems tourist trappy, but there are some gems in the area. If you're looking for photo ops, then maybe worth a visit. but definitely go in expecting standard touristy stuff. Also driving around this area at the peak of tourist season is a bit of a nightmare.
author: Alexander L.

description: Every city has their version of a tourist trap, welcome to SF . Regardless it is a go to destination if your visiting to take in the crowds and piers and sea front restaurants. Plus you get great views of the bridges and Alcatraz island.....Parking is a complete RIP OFF, so if your driving....round the local streets and you'll find a spot. This place is happening on the weekends so arriving early is more beneficial to you.
author: N And N K.

description:
Don't think of this as a one-star review for Fisherman's Wharf: think of it as a five-star review for Uber.

Because -- unless you've desensitized yourself with years of vacationing in tacky beach towns, or monthly visits to third-rate amusement parks -- you are likely to have an allergic reaction to Fisherman's Wharf. 

Maybe it will come when you're trying to have a conversation, but can't hear your partner over the sound of a truly terrible street musician bellowing dated, cheesy top-20 hits. Maybe it will be the seventh time your child asks you for cotton candy. Maybe it will be the moment when a tourist on a bicycle plows into your kid and then bikes off without even checking if he's okay (not a hypothetical).

Whatever that moment, when your reaction hits, you will have the sudden horrible realization that there are six nightmarish, souvenir-filled blocks between you and the remnants of civilization. (Indeed, once you've made it those six blocks to the wharf, you may find yourself wondering whether civilization still remains, or whether we've collapsed under the weight of our own poor taste.)

And at that moment, you will thank god that you can dial up an Uber and get the hell out of Dodge. Uber, thank you for rescuing me during my moment of get-me-out-of-here panic!
author: Alexandra S.

description:
Must visit this place when you're around San Francisco!
The best clam chowder!
I just some seafood are hit-or-miss, but there's a lot of places to eat at!
Little stores, vendors/booths, entertainers.
Great for souvenirs too.
Touristy place and you're enough to find street parking.
Parking sucks.
We parked at a parking structure, stayed for less than 2 hours and we had to pay $14.
Ridiculous, but not as bad during the holidays!
author: Laramae E.

description:
The crab legs are amazing here!!!! It's so awesome how they serve the plate and they have such a unique rhythm when preparing it. We had to stand and eat because that's the whole environment. It gets so crowed during the weekend.

I hear many saying that parking was expensive, but may that it's just for the people who do not want to walk a short distance. I actually had to make a few turns to find parking but i ended up finding a structure and it was like $5 like two blocks away which it was so cheap!! 

There are so many things to do and to look at, many stores and especially souvenirs...
author: Jannie M.

description:
I don't think I've ever had more of an urge to tackle someone on a segway before. But for some reason, when I see the segway tours around Fisherman's Wharf, fists start clenching and I'm just itching for one of these tourists to just get an inch too close, so I have a reason. Oh, just give me a reason. Heh, I swear, I'm not angry or anything.

While I will agree that it's quite touristy here, you can find tranquil places to sit and enjoy the water. You have to go a bit further from the central part, but you can definitely avoid the crowds closer to Ghirardelli Square. I know, it seems kind of counter-intuitive to do so, but you won't regret it.

Blah blah blah, chowder in a bread bowl, blah blah blah. I prefer the In-n-Out actually. Heh. I love seafood, but hate the crowds. And I always feel like I'm being swindled, buying chowder in a tourist trap. 

I just realized all the advice I gave in this review was more or less to go to places away from Fisherman's Wharf. Well, I stand by it. Come here if you haven't been, but not quite the place to frequent.
author: Eric J.

description: Perfect touristy place for tourists and those who live in the area. Daytime or Nighttime this place is amazing. Shops are interesting here and food is good. The pier contains a ton of seafood restauraunts- keep in mind it's on water so it makes sense. It's two stories so be sure to walk upstairs as well to check out the shops. They do two staircases that play piano sounds as you go up. People always get a kick out of it. Towards the end of the pier you will find a merry go round + magic show for kids and towards the left you'll find sea lions! It's a bit expensive here in the pier so download their coupon book. Do try fog harbor and bubba gump if you have time. Trish's doughnut is amazing as well. I am in love with their sports store so check it out. Also do check out their chocolate store you will be amazed with what you find! Try to come during the holidays when the huge Christmas tree is up. Street parking can be tricky, but parking garage can be expensive to read carefully before you park. I normally take public transportation here and just walk. Everything is walking distance. Keep in mind it's a touristy spot so be patient where ever you go. I definitely recommend everyone to come here at least once. There's no place like this. It's easily one of my favorite spots in San Francisco. I know i'll be back here soon with either friends or family.
author: Danika P.

description: Great place to walk around with family. Parking is overpriced. My suggestion is to park at one of the structures across the street that charge $20-25 per day, instead of $45 per day in the lot in front of the wharf. Bring a sweater since it's almost always cold here.
author: Linda P.

description:
The Fishermans Wharf is right by the Exploratorium and various other tourist attractions so it's nice to stop by if you're near everything! The place is perfect for photos and has small, cute places like a bread bakery, trinket store, and chocolate maker! 

I think the most interesting thing had to be seeing the sea lions gathered along the wooden planks near the shoreline to sunbathe! All of them were laid flat and fighting over certain spots, we even see a mom and her pup snuggled up alone on one of the planks! Apparently they gather there every year and they've once hit numbers somewhere in the thousands at one point. Definitely worth seeing! 

Traffic going out to the city is absolutely terrible at night, so find some decent parking and walk there if you can!
author: Jimmy T.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf is one of the most popular landmarks in San Francisco. Everywhere you go there are tons of people walking, eating, shopping, enjoying the street shows, and other activities. On one end you have the popular Pier 39 and on the other end are restaurants and various stations of people selling crab or shrimp sandwiches. You can even buy whole crabs to eat or take home. In between you have many gift shops where you can buy souvenirs, schedule to take a tour of San Francisco by bus, bike, or little compact cars, various restaurants to grab a bite, and other activities you can do. 

Parking can be a real hassle here. There is a parking structure right across the street from Pier 39, but costs can definitely add up if you stay the whole day. Street parking is available but you have to get lucky to get one of these spots. If you do park on the street, don't forget to pay the meter.

Fisherman's Wharf is definitely a great experience if you haven't been here before.
author: Brandon L.

description: I could seriously watch the sea lions forever. I probably stood there and took photos for a good 30 minutes to an hour. I love them. Everything else in the area is super touristy and looks like a huge waste of money. But if eating at Bubba Gump Shrimp Co is your thing, then this is the place. There's also a zillion places to get all the cheesy I heart SF stuff, magnets and shot glasses. There's boat tours and carnival rides. It is kind of a must see.
author: Lauren N.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf definitely has more character than it's more popular sibling down the road at Pier 39.

This is where the famous "Bush Man" lurked before his passing last year (RIP).  Fortunately, he did have an understudy so be on the lookout for him.

Most of the restaurants are pricey and are usually tourist traps, especially along the waterfront.  Honestly though, this is probably one of the best places to get your crab fix, especially during crab season.  Also, there are some "hidden gems"  around the area to enjoy such as Tanquito, The Codmother, Carmel Pizza Company, and the Hollywood Cafe.  And of course, this is the only place in SF that has In-N-Out Burger.

There's also some interesting spots to check out like Musee Mechanique and the USS Pampanito.  The original Wax Museum is no more, but has been upgraded into a Madame Toussaud's so the quality is better.

As a local to the area, I still enjoy visiting The Wharf from time to time.  It's still very lively and worth checking out once in a while.
author: Rodney H.

description: A San Francisco must if it is your first time visiting. Other than that...tourist trap!! Unless you are craving a clam chowder in a sourdough bread bowl...or street food seafood. Fisherman's Wharf has lost it appeal for me. Not as clean as I remember it years ago. Too crowded & some of the seafood stands should review their hygiene manuals!! I canceled my order immediately when I saw the server grab money out of the tip basket & then not wash his hands, as he starts to prepare my clam chowder bread bowl, by grabbing the bread with his dirty hands!! I will say that strolling along the Embarcadero towards Pier 39 is a good time killer and Trish's Donuts is a must!!!
author: Cynthia R.

description:
It's hard to summarize this location.

I suppose the best that I can do is provide general comparisons. Fisherman's Wharf is not quite as trendy as Newport Beach but I'd attest to it being more so on a Santa Monica or Manhattan Beach scale.

There's quite a bit to do altogether, but eating is what comes to mind first. Without a doubt is everything here going to be overpriced, so if your pockets are stacked then knock yourself out....however if you're nickel and diming it, try keeping your hands in your pockets. As with anywhere in California, they tend to charge ....and UPcharge for EVERYTHING HERE. 

The location itself boast several restaurants (most are quite touristy), souvenir shops, and I believe they even offer an Alcatraz tour. 

Once again, it's a definite tourist trap and the prices are HYPER-inflated. I think that pretty much speaks volumes yet if you're in the area and find yourself with a surplus of time let alone a full wallet, by all means, add this place to your to do list.
author: Kenny G.

description: This place is full of things to see and do with great photo ops as well! Shopping, food, seal watching along with boat tours, bus tours and trolleys that all depart here or from a nearby pier! Views of Alcatraz Island and the Golden Gate Bridge! The sea food options looked delicious and I'm sure they're fresh! Definitely a must on the San Francisco to do list! For SoCal residents, it makes you understand the themeing at Disney's California Adventure so much more!
author: Sabrena M.

description: Every time we visit San Francisco, we come to experience the warf. You'll find interesting  people, great fun souvenirs, and fyn entertainment. Oh, and an assortment of delicious eateries. My teenage daughter loves this place.
author: E T.

description: Unfortunately, Fishermen's Wharf has gone downhill over the years. Still a great place to see the Sea lions but that's about it. The fried Calamari I bought was over priced and far too chewy to be enjoyed. Its infested with crazy people talking crazy $hit, homeless people sleeping on benches, normally used for paying customers to sit and eat and many of the outdoor food vendors are gone.The homeless people are becoming more emboldened and pushy. Not a cop or security officer in sight. Pelosi and the Mayor need to address this area. 28 bucks for parking for 3 hours! Sad, but we won't be going back anymore.
author: Rob R.

description:
Very touristy as you can tell by the numerous souvenir shops with cheesey tourist shirts. I've been here twice out of the 3 times I have been to san fran. I don't see the need to go again unless we go to Alcatraz. We had seafood and a clam chowder bread bowl at a nicer sitdown restaurant. Boudin's is also down here.
If it is your first time to San fran, come down here, get your breadbowl and a good picture.
It is walking distance to Ghiradelli square and/ or the windy road (brain fart, for got the name).
author: Vicky S.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf is arguably the most popular tourist attraction in San Francisco.  It's located along the city's northeastern waterfront, facing Alcatraz Island and the bay.  It consists of a collection of shops, restaurants, and other attractions such as a wax museum and a Ripley's Believe it or Not museum.

The big Fisherman's Wharf sign is located at the corner of Taylor St. and Jefferson St.

The restaurants in Fisherman's Wharf run the gamut from casual outdoor food stands like Sabella & La Torre (http://www.yelp.com/biz/sabella-and-la-torre-san-francisco) to fine dining like the floating Forbes Island restaurant (http://www.yelp.com/biz/forbes-island-san-francisco).  Gary Danko plans to open a restaurant in Fisherman's Wharf, not far from his nearby original restaurant in Russian Hill.  Fresh seafood is sold here and clam chowder in sourdough bread bowls are very popular (for good reason -- they're delicious).

Seagulls are ALL over the place, especially at the pier, because despite what the signs say, people still feed them.  Leftover bread is often fed to the seagulls.  It's hilarious to watch people bring food to the pier and try to eat in peace while the seagulls stalk and harass them.  I've seen flocks of seagulls aggressively attack unattended bread bowls.  It is a sight to see and causes an entertaining commotion.

A lot of retailers are gift shops and souvenir shops selling random merchandise and knickknacks.  If you're shopping for gifts of souvenirs, you can typically find the same or comparable items for less at a local Walgreens.

The pier is nice because it provides excellent views of the bay, including Alcatraz and both the Golden Gate Bridge and Bay Bridge.  It's also fun to check out the sea lions gather at Pier 39.

There are homeless people, the most "famous" one being the Bushman.  He sits on the sidewalk, hiding behind a bush, and jump-scares unsuspecting passersby.  I first noticed him when I was across the street and heard screaming.  There are videos of him on YouTube and he even has his own Yelp page: http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-bush-man-san-francisco.
author: Daniel B.

description: This place is real cool, chased some seagulls, walked everywhere all over, went inside some giant sailor ships, heard live acoustic music, purchased from the outdoor shops. Great place!
author: Mike K.

description:
Tourist trap!  Here is where you can shop, hang out, eat, and watch some free shows.  You can even watch some sea lions sleep by the dock.   

I guess the best part here is the clam chowder bread bowl.  Almost all the restaurants sell this local specialty - you just have to decide for yourself which one you like best!

Some cool stores include the donut store, where they sell cute powdered sugar mini donuts in buckets; the hat store (great for pictures); the candy store (something for all ages!); the crepe store (you'll catch the whiff of sweetness as you walk closer to it); and the magnet store (great for shot glass collectors). They have some souvenir shops for the Golden Gate bridge, too. 

Parking is the worst part in San Francisco.  Luckily for tourists, there is a Pier 39 validated parking structure (but it's still really bad).  You can park anywhere in the 5-floored structure for a free first hour if you leave before 6 pm  or free first two hours if you leave after 6 pm.  The catch is that you have to have it validated at a place listed on the back of the parking ticket.  Some places include Pier 39 Market, the arcade, Eagle Cafe, Fog Harbor, etc.  Street parking is never free around Fisherman's Wharf, and it's too hard to find a spot anyway.
author: Clara C.

description: Food was off the charts.  Whole crab, crab sand with boudin brd.   Oh my god best ever
author: Josh M.

description:
A nice walk with a great view and delicious food.

The location is convenient for tourists. It's right next to Aquarium of the Bay, Ghirardelli Square and other spots. The restaurants are obviously going to be a little pricey but there are other options.

If you're just trying to get the taste of San Francisco's clam chowder and seafood, just buy them through the sidewalk vendors/ stands. It will be cheaper and you'll get more out of your money. It will be as good as the restaurants!
author: Kathy M.

description: Fisherman's Wharf has many shops such as accessory store, suvenior shop, chocolate shop and so on. I bought a lot of stuff at there. For example, I want to bouhght Sanfrancisco jacket and shirt, but I didn't bought all of them because I had no enough money to bought them. Therefore, I bought pink Sanfrancisco jacket. If I go Fisherman's Wharf again, I will buy Sanfranciso shirt.
author: Soeun P.

description:
It's a tourist thing.  This area is a lot like downtown Gatlinburg except with sea lions and a large expanse of water. I expected it to be like Fisherman's Wharf in Honolulu where they bring in huge boat loads of fish, but saw no such things going on there. 

There were several decent restaurants - many with water views, a ton of shops, sea lions, Ripley's museum & a Madame Toussaud's in the area, and lots & lots of souvenir stands.  There are also a couple of pharmacies.  We visited the CVS a couple of times for snacks and toiletries and found the prices are very comparable to what we are used to in the midwest. 

There are photo opportunities all over; several areas offer fantastic views of the water, Alcatraz, Golden Gate bridge and San Francisco's crowded, towering neighborhoods.  Pretty flower beds abound.  You can catch several ferries and tour boats, tour buses, taxis and trolley cars from all around here.  Parking in the lots/garages is STEEPLY priced - at about $50/day.

This is the only place in SF where we actually saw families with kids.
author: M M.

description: Ya Gotta Do It! Yes, touristy but who cares! You have to go and get a clam chowder bowl and eat it with the fear of some daring seagull snatching it right out of your hands. Street performer played guitar and serenaded us as we ate on the benches and it was lovely. P.s. Make sure the bench is clean BEFORE you sit down. And take napkins.
author: Heather M.

description: The amount of homeless people with mental issues out in San Francisco is getting horrible. They like to bug you around his area and all over the city. Every shop here sells the typical horrible souvenirs. Very over priced restaurants and shops. Do yourself a favor and just make this a quick visit and walk through if you do have to come here.
author: Lisa H.

description:
Tourist Trap - Explore Elsewhere to Experience the Culture and Character of San Francisco. 

My mother and I visited Fisherman's Wharf briefly on the morning of July 31st. 
We arrived to Fisherman's Wharf harbour front area via the Powell-Hyde cable car, from Lombard Street at around 8 AM. Fisherman's Wharf is a huge tourist attraction in San Francisco, featuring specialty shops, restaurants, and entertainment. 

There were no people around during our visit, thankfully, (as I very much dislike crowds) because it was too early for the stores/restaurants to be open. However, I can only imagine how insane the crowds of tourists would be during late morning or afternoon! Fisherman's Wharf is definitely not a place I would want to be anywhere near during these times. 

My mother and I enjoyed a relaxing and quiet stroll throughout the Fisherman's Wharf area and along the waterfront which was nice, but despite that, Fisherman's Wharf would not be a place that I would feel a desire to return to for a second visit. Initially, we did not specifically plan to or intend on visiting Fisherman's Wharf, however, we just happened to be in the area while riding the cable cars and decided to briefly check it out.  

For me personally, Fisherman's Wharf was disappointing. My expectations were low to begin with and they were not exceeded. The streets along the Bay as well as Pier 39 were very commercialized and were lined with tonnes of specialized souvenir shops, American chain stores and mediocre restaurants catering to tourists and selling overpriced goods. It felt like a miniature Las Vegas. 

Fisherman's Wharf is an overrun tourist trap and was not worth the visit for myself and I would not return for a second visit. There are so many more unique things to do and interesting neighbourhoods with character to explore in San Francisco, that offer a far better experience, in my opinion. I much preferred shopping at unique, independent and local shops in Haight-Ashbury or the Mission and sampling authentic ethnic cuisine at some of San Francisco's many wonderful local restaurants. Avoid this area and don't waste your time here. 

Experience the culture and character of the city by exploring elsewhere to get a feel for the real and authentic side of San Francisco.
author: Brittany T.

description:
So much to choose from. They have everything here. If you want a tour of the bay,here, if you want to eat lunch or fine, here, if you want to shop, here, if you want entertainment, here. We did all of it. Had a great day. 
The reasons for the 3 stars is that for it being Fishermans Wharf the seafood was not that great. Also, there is only one restroom in the middle of it behind a restaurant.
author: Terry M.

description:
You...must....go!

Beautiful water and I sighted the Polarbear's club. Men in no suits swimming in cold water. Crazy! It was a chilly but wonderful 60 degree weather.

There are tons of shops, souvenirs, restaurants, food, and trolley cars to ride.
author: Ann P.

description:
Every great city for tourists has a tourist area with tons of tourist stores. Fisherman's Wharf is that and who doesn't love a few hours in a tourist trap when you're on vacation anyway?  The best part about this tourist trap is that there are lots of great restaurants and small cafes that sell Dungeness Crab and that unique San Francisco sourdough bread right on the street!  Buying crab and sourdough bread on the street can be found on the waterfront side of Embarcadero Street in the middle of the Wharf area.  

The Wharf area starts at Pier 39 and runs all the way down Embarcadero to the Cannery and Ghirardelli Square.  

A great thing about the Wharf is that it's safe enough to walk about late at night because of all of the tourists around.  The Powell St. cable car line dumps you off in the middle of the Wharf while the Hyde Street line drops you off closer to the Ghirardelli Square end of things.
author: Doctor G.

description:
If you want to experience San Francisco culture, this is the place to go. You will definitely get a taste of Bay Area locals and see street performers and experience great food as well. 

I usually never go here even though I live 20-30min away from San Francisco, which is mainly due to the high traffic on Embarcadero and surrounding streets and the massive crowds during the summer. 

Expect to spend all day in this area, fisherman's wharf, pier 39, Alcatraz and the ferry building.
author: Rochelle M.

description: awesome place to visit if you're in the bay area. alot of shops and restraunts to visit and eat. be sure to check out the actual fish market, it still operates! don't  forget to walk the streets and enjoy the busy walkways. seafood is king here, make sure you try the clamchowder. they're well know for that at the warf. downside is the homeless population in SF. i think it's part of their tourism attraction stay safe and enjoy your stay in SF
author: Jep A.

description:
I think it's pretty safe to to say that Fisherman's Wharf is probably the most touristy of tourist spots in San Francisco...other than the full house house, Painted Ladies, Union Square, and Golden Gate Bridge. Even though it is a tourist trap, it's worth at least a one time visit..you can't beat the fresh crab there and it semi has a Jersey shore vibe with the little gift shops near the pier. I love walking through the seafood marketplace where they will crack the crab on the spot for you and you can just sit there and chill with your family/friends over fresh crab and shrimp. It's a little tricky to find places to sit and eat but if you go near the water there are plenty of benches and entertainers for you to enjoy. 

There's always a lot of people there and again, similar to many of the touristy places around San Francisco, you never know who, or what, you are going to see. If you end up going to the t-shirt shop near the pier, they are wiling to do a little bargaining on their freshly pressed t-shirts so it's worth a shot. My sister and I were able to get two custom sweatshirts for $30 each =)
author: Vy B.

description: We like going here because it's lively and we like to try different restaurants and compare their New England clam chowder! On a sunny day it's also very pretty.
author: T L.

description:
Pier 39 and Fishermans Wharf is one of my favorite places to visit.  The smells, the food, the people...it is all such an amazing experience.  

You can get some of the most amazing seafood here.  Fresh fresh fresh!!!  I have visited many of the restaurants here and all but a handful are top notch.  Plus the fresh seafood you can get from the street vendors is amazing too.

The street performers are incredible and some...not so much.  The bushman is always fun to watch for a few minutes.  The silver and gold street performers are pretty interesting too.  This last time there was a guy who was playing 12 instruments at the same time.  He had designed a mechanism that allowed him to play and sing.  It was pretty incredible.  

The smells are awesome too.  You will be walking and all of a sudden get a wiff of garlic butter goodness.  Oh my!  

It is definitely a "must do" for everyone of all ages.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
One of my favorite tourist attractions in SF! For whatever reason, this place reminds me a bit of Seaport Village in San Diego.
