You have an endless amount of restaurants here! Every time I come here there is just way too much good food and I don't have nearly enough stomach to try half of what I want to! Tons of stores and shops to get both overpriced souveneers and some deals at some of the other shops!

Pier 39 is especially alot of fun! Aquarium of the Bay is located here. At Pier 33 you have the Alcatraz tours. There are always street  people performing shows and such.

At the other end you have a gorgeous view of the Golden Gate Bridge and you're also just steps away from one of the Cable car lines!

Evewrytime I visit SF, I spend at least one entire day here, and I have yet to get bored! Love this place!

5 stars!
author: Mike F.

description: So everyone made such a big deal about visiting fishermens wharf. Ummm my experience was mediocre. Nothing special really. It's a tourist trap! The highlight was eating seafood from the food stands. The food was delicious.
author: Eva B.

description: Samir was our waiter, and he was such an amazing person and made the experience great.  The food was really good.
author: Eadie H.

description: This is a tourist trap. As long as you recognize it for what it is, it's not bad. It's fun to walk around and go through the souvenir shops stores or art galleries. There's a bunch of sea food restaurants all over the place so just walk around, enjoy the crowd and take funny pictures. If you are going to Alcatraz, you would have come here anyway to board so enjoy!
author: Shayer S.

description:
Yes, it's a tourist destination.  There are chain restaurants and tourist shops aplenty.  The area gets crowded.  But there are also things to see and do that are unique and showcase local flavor.  There are tons of restaurants to choose from.  You have to try the iconic clam chowder in a bread bowl... It's amazing.  You can stop in Boudin and get some of their famous sourdough bread.  

You can tour the USS Pampanito if history piques your interest. The Musee Mechanique is a must see for all ages.  There are often musicians and street performers roaming about.  It's a great place to people watch.  I don't think it's somewhere you can plan to spend an entire day, but it's definitely a nice stop when visiting.
author: Kim L.

description:
SO MANY TOURISTS (yes, myself included)!! Definitely would recommend to visit during the week, so you have some space to walk and not be squished; plus bring a sweatshirt for night since it can get chilly.

There are some fun street performers and awesome seafoods all along the harbor!!! If you walk down to Pier 39, you might be able to see some sea lions on the docks; in early July, only few were there but supposedly during the fall and winter, there are hundreds barking and playing around!!!

Also, the only In-N-Out location in SF is located here!!
author: Andrew C.

description:
It's the Wharf. So much stuff is there. Great live performances, music, souvenirs, shopping, an old-style video arcade, etc. Then there are the sea lions (arf! arf!) and all of the other boat cruises that are nearby - walking distance. For that reason, just get to the Wharf a couple hours before any boat trip and give yourself time to kill two birds with one stone.

Anybody new to the city should check it out for sure. 
TIP: come on a weekday if possible. The weekends are an absolute zoo nightmare.
Give yourself plenty of time to explore... lots to see and wear comfy shoes and bring an extra sweater, too. As long as your prepared the visit to the Wharf can be really nice and happy.
author: Pamela M.

description:
DIrty, dirty and lots of seedy people. Yeah there are tons of tourists but it's like TImes Square on the water...20 yrs ago. 
It does have plenty of places to eat, shop or drink. It's nice to see for 10 minutes in your life to say you were at Fisherman's Wharf. But that was about enough for my wife and I. We liked Pier 39 better. Less crazies. 
Worth a stop, yes. Worth a return trip after seeing it once, nope. 
Plus it's very crowded with slow moving tourists...annoying.
author: Pasquale R.

description:
With the sounds of seagulls and street performers riding the snappy salt wind blowing in from the bay, it is the easiest thing in the world to spend a whole day at Fisherman's Wharf.  While always portrayed as a very touristy attraction, this bustling seaside area is fun and exercises all the senses.  

Walking down the main street provides a colorful view of souvenir shops, acrobatic performers, spray paint artists, seafood vendors, and restaurants.  On the far end is Boudin, complete with a sourdough workshop and store.  Nearby there is an avenue dedicated to shopping with some restaurants, complete with a Hard Rock Cafe. Piers stretching into the ocean allow even closer observation of the many sea lions that live in the area.  Crab vendors and saltwater taffy stores jostle for attention side by side, there is a battleship and accompanying maritime museum parked nearby, and the chime of the cable car rings in the distance.  Bigger stores dominate the other end of the wharf, and further on lies Ghiradelli square and a variety of parks and green spaces. 

As is true universally in SF, parking is a hassle.  There is a garage nearby but it's pricey, though not so bad if you are only visiting for a day.

Given the press of the crowds, I try to spend some time exploring the side streets, particularly for restaurants.  Scoma's and Carmel Pizza Company are examples of some gems found slightly off the beaten track.  

For an invigorating sea breeze and a quick fix of San Francisco, there is no better place to be.
author: Emily Y.

description: From small town in West Central, IL this was great! Such diversity in the shops and restaurants just a fun place to visit. A must see when you visit San Francisco.
author: Glenn W.

description:
One of SF popular tourist hotspots! Bring jacket to stay warm! There are tons of places to eat, most have some of same offerings like chowder, crab, oysters, fish and chips ( how they are cooked varies ). The gift shops has plenty of hoodies, socks and hats ! I picked up majority of my gifts from Pier 39, which seems to have bigger giftshop. The action and vibe of the area dies around 6-7pm

Pros: ArtattackSF gallery, many Bike rentals options, many food options, sourdough factory, and easy access to trolly cars (other modes of public transport

Cons: large homelessness population, dirty seabird droppings everywhere, some gift shops have redundant items found everywhere , EVERYTHING closes early like 6/630pm
author: Kristen M.

description: I have traveled throughout the world and this area has literally the most disgusting public restrooms I have ever had the displeasure to visit. I didn't want to let my kids in there it was so disgusting. Toilet paper, pads , trash all over the floor. Most stalls didn't have toilet paper ( luckily I had my young son so he didn't need any) no saop in the dispensers and the floor was littered with trash.
author: Cybelle M.

description:
The Wharf is a tourist trap. In San Francisco, I am a tourist so I enjoy walking around it. There are plenty of shops, food stands, and restaurants. One of the touristy things to do is eat clam chowder in a bread bowl. I thought it was amazing the first time I tried it. It lost its luster the second time I visited the wharf and ate it. I did not even try to seek it out the third time. If you have never tried it, I would still recommend it since it is part of the full tourist experience. If you enjoy short boat rides, I also recommend taken one from the wharf that circle around the bay. It takes approximately 40 minutes and costs about $30. The boat will pass right by Alcatraz then swing to and under the Golden Gate Bridge before returning to the wharf. I enjoyed getting up close to Alcatraz to see it from the outside and feeling the sea breeze during the cruise. I definitely enjoyed the experience once but there are so many other things to do in the city that I would not do it again. Another fun spot in the wharf is Ghirardelli Square. Of course, they are known for their chocolate. Their ice cream is also very good here. As a warning, parking is very expensive in the wharf. If you do not mind walking, park away from it on the street and take a walk. I took a look at the map and choose a random area west of Lombard Street and walked 20 minutes to the wharf.

If you are visiting San Francisco and looking for recommendations, feel free to message me through Yelp and I can share my itinerary, which includes my Yelp reviews. The information for an electronic copy can also be found via my Yelp profile.
author: Patrick W.

description:
I am a tourist, of course I have to come here every time we are in SF! Love it here! It's always so much fun!  Lucky each time the weather has been sunny and nice. And this is definitely a great place to have a fun date day in SF! 

Many tour guides on the streets to sell tours, just ask anyone, I am sure you can find the tours you want to go on, Alcatraz and bay cruise are always great choices. There are some museums such as The wax, Ripley's, National Liberty Ship Memorial, The Exploratorium. 

Other attractions like Anchorage Square, SF Maritime National Park, Ghirardelli Square, Pier 39, Aquarium of the Bay, cable cars. Lots of food stands, gift shops, restaurants or bars. I like it how we can find many things to do, places to eat during the day, also restaurants & bars to have drinks in the evening! 

I might consider to stay at a hotel near fishermen's wharf next time! I just want to explore everything around this area!
author: Mimi L.

description:
Not a lot of fishermen at Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco these days, but there are plenty of tourists ... with shops & eateries fishing for business. In my mind, Fisherman's Wharf is just a small section near the terminus of the Powell-Hyde Cable Car line, but the reality is that the unofficial Fisherman's Wharf stretches from there all the way to the Embarcadero & the Ferry Building.

Driving to and around Fisherman's Wharf is never recommended. Take one of the Cable Car routes for the SF experience or hop on an Electric Street Car with a MUNI Pass. Parking is anywhere from $8 to a gazillion dollars depending on when & where you park, but it's no fun navigating the tourists & traffic to get there.

Get a map and make a plan if you expect to see everything along Fisherman's Wharf in a day because it's a series of piers and areas that will wear you down by nightfall.

 * Pier 39 is in the heart and packed with tourists, shops, & sea lions
 * The small Aquarium of the Bay is at Pier 39
 * Pier 43 and Pier 45 give great picture spots of the Bay and Alcatraz
 * Alcatraz Tours depart from Pier 33 near the Ferry Building.
 * The Ferry Building is like an active mall with stalls selling anything & everything
 * Madame Tussauds and Ripley's Believe It or Not? are between Pier 41 and 43
 * Boudin Bakery near Pier 43 is Sourdough Central for Bread Lovers
 * Grab some bread and hit the nearby Seafood Stands for a stand-up meal
 * On Pier 45, board U.S. submarine Pampanito & liberty ship Jeremiah O'Brien
 * Hyde Street Pier is home to the San Francisco Maritime National Historic Park
 * If you have energy, keep going to Ghiradelli Square for chocolate
 * Musée Mécanique at the entrance to Pier 45 displays tons of old music machines
 * Restaurants are a mix of chains and tourist favorites. Have fun with it.

Fisherman's Wharf is a must-see tourist attraction for all San Francisco visitors. Because of the variety of sites, sounds, smells, and seafood, there is just about something for everyone.
author: Michael S.

description:
In every major city, there is a super touristy place that as a local (or soon-to-be in this case) that I absolutely love. For San Francisco, Fisherman's Wharf is that place.

The biggish crabby sign is iconic and impossible to miss. The tens of food stands and restaurant serving fresh seafood, where they basically peel and prepare your crustacean and shellfish dishes in front of you expertly and efficiently, then you proceed to savor (or devour) while standing near the tiny front of the stand. 

The rest of the wharf is much like a chaotic fair of a mixture between delicious smelling seafood and the salty breezes from the ocean. The famous Pier 39 is also near by, providing another fascinating place to people watch and seal watch at the same time.
author: Sharon Z.

description:
I love fisherman's warf, so much to do!!! There's so many attractions and a great view to see Alcatraz. I love it!! 

There are mini shops you can go into and buy, from souvenirs to socks and jewelry. 

There are so many FOOD!!! I must try them all. Dryers I've cream, their waffle cones smelled so good and all we did was walk by it. The mini donuts, were amazing!!! I only got 6 mini donuts but I wish we got a bucket for only 10$. You have regular sports bar, to boudin, and fine dining with an amazing view of the sea. 

Attractions include: aquarium, merry go round, huge ass claw machine, magician entertainment for the kids, and like a laser tag kind of game.

I'd like to come back with my family or friends, it's a must go before you see a goats game!
author: Ameenah M.

description: The Sea food at fisherman's warf is over-the-top amazing!  I've eaten food here a handful of times including: seafood chowder (amazing), calamari (amazing), lobster roll (double AMAZING).  Parking is atrocious so be careful where you park.  I didn't pay attention and no joke I paid $50 when I left the lot after spending 2-3 hours at the wharf.  We also went on a ferry ride and that was super beautiful.  Its def worth visiting while visiting San Fran.
author: Nicole Y.

description: I have been fortunate to visit here a couple of times and I feel like this place has been so commercialized it has lost much of its authentic charm. I am pretty sure the fisherman coming into the port with their big catches of the day weren't hitting up Applebee's afterwards. Yes, I am a tourist but this place is super touristy. Probably a place you visit once for an hour or two and then move on.
author: Christine H.

description:
How can you give this place anything less than five stars? 
This place is so much fun. This is an active wharf, where sea lions hang out on the water. Fishmongers sell crabs and shrimp that've been just hauled out of the bay waters. Musicians perform along the seaside, putting on free shows. 
Yea, it's a bit on the touristy side, but it's still lots of fun to see all the cool shops, restaurants, and places to take pictures. There's so much to do along here- Giradelhi Square on one end, the bay on the other- it's a really nice place to hang out!
Watch out- there's giant gulls and seabirds looking for a free handout. They're mean!
author: Curt C.

description:
OK.  So les-b-honest here-- Non bias opinion, 2 words: Pier. Tourist.
That about sums it up folks!  It's a pier just like any other, it stinks a little, fish & beer maybe? It isn't a lavish pier, this isn't Santa Monica PIer, it's just a regular ole' pier.  It has tons of shops near the doc and if you walk more towards the inside of the streets you'll find a lot of other entertaining stores around!  The best part it watching the water and being able to view Alcatraz from here!  You can take a ferri across the water and tour Alcatraz as well!  Secondly, if your a tourist you should stop by, but really, if you've already been.... there's no reason to twice.  

Food suggestion: Gourdinos (spell check) Whatever, it's the first food stand (nearest to the street) it starts with a "G".  Doesn't look like much but it has the best food from all of the stands... We got the small cup of lobster claws & BUTTER SAUCE worth dying for.... Checkity check it out!
author: Nai Q.

description:
Yes, this is a tourist trap but if you are going to be in San Francisco I think its worth stopping by here at least once.  Then you can decide for yourself if it warrants a second visit. In addition to being a hub for local flavor there is also some history in Fisherman's Wharf. Here are a few thoughts on what to do, where to shop, what to eat and some lodging options. 

What is there to do?
In addition to being a hub for local flavor there is also some history in Fisherman's Wharf.  Given that, I do think Fisherman's Wharf has its place on a San Francisco itinerary.  Foodies will appreciate checking out the crab stands and sourdough bread at Boudin.  History buffs will like the ships dotted along Hyde Street Pier.  Patriots and military buffs alike can tour the USS Pampanito and USS Jeremiah O'Brien.  Kids and adults may have fun checking out vintage coin-operated machines at Musee Mecanique.  This is also a good launching point for bicycling across the Golden Gate Bridge.

So many shops, so little time . . .
Well, unless you are looking for junky tourist stuff you can skip most of the shops.  One that seems better than the others is Wharf Central in The Cannery.  They have some nice books about the area and carry some better brands like Roxy and Columbia.  

What should I eat? 
Of course in addition to the attractions in Fisherman's Wharf there are tons of places to eat.  If you're not adventurous then this is where you find chains.  But if you are reading this review, I have to assume that you're willing to try some local eateries.  Blue Mermaid Chowder House and Bar instantly comes to mind.  

Lodging in Fishmerman's Wharf?
On at least a few of my trips to SF I have stayed in San Francisco.  I like both the Argonaut and The Tuscan.  The reason I like staying in this area is because there are grocery stores and drug stores close by so you can grab a soda or snacks for your hotel room.  Also, staying in Fisherman's Wharf is convenient to transportation like the Powell and Hyde Cable Car Line, the Powell and Mason Cable Car Line and the F-Street Street Car Line. 

Bottom Line: Fisherman Wharf offers a lot more than crowds and junk shops.  http://visitfishermanswharf.com/
author: Courtney K.

description:
TOURIST CENTRAL!

Being a resident of California for about 10 months, am I allowed to say that? Oh well, I did :)


But yessss, this is where all the tourist go as a part of the SF experience. For a Saturday night, it was busy but not as busy as it usually is.

They had the usual familiar restaurants: Applebee's, Chipotle, Jack in the Box.
They also had IN N OUT, so if you are wanting to kill two birds with one stone, I guess Fisherman's Wharf is the place to go. Grab a burger at IN N OUT & stroll the Pier while watching the sea lions, lol.

There are your vendors, as you would expect but WATCH OUT FOR THE BUSH MAN! lol. He got us good! He hides behind a freakin' bush & jumps out from it. Sacred the CRAP out of us. Don't know what concept he is going for because does he scare people just for the pure joy of it or does he expect people to give him money for getting the poop scared out of them? lol. 

Lots of sites to see & a ton of restaurants that were super themed. Just sayin' 

I'd like to come back & explore more :)
author: Camille C.

description:
Another landmark where you have no choice but to join the tourists...I always gotta go to Boudin for my Sourdough fix, but I don't bother with any of the seafood stands or touristy shops for the fact that I'd rather prepare crab, lobster, and shrimp myself at a fraction of the cost, and the touristy shops don't have anything I'm looking for.

I also have flashbacks of the worst dinner EVER here at Alioto's 8...don't know if its gotten better, but I'd rather not find out.. some of the street acts are cool though, and I love seeing the "bush man" scare the crap of the most unsuspecting tourist...ALOHA!!!

YELP 365 CHALLENGE-(257/365) "Tourist Trap"
author: Nelson Q.

description:
Dan Fransisco is a beautiful city full of wonderful little spots that inevitably become a tourist destination. Fisher and Warf is no different, but still a nice place to visit. There are street performers, artists, and lots of neat people watching to keep you entertained. There are unfortunately lots of tacky tourist trap shops, but if you like to buy Alcatraz shot glasses or t shirts with silly slogans, then you'll be in heaven perusing the many shops along the way. With a little patients you can find some wonderful shops and restaurants that aren't tacky or a chin, and you won't regret be disappointed! 

There's a ton of small seafood shops, so if you love fresh fish and crabs be sure to bring lots of cash - a lot of places don't take card. 

Sadly, the bush man passed away last year, but there are still lots of fun street performers to watch. Dollar dollar bills are your (and theirs!) best friend, so have a pocketful!
author: Melinda R.

description:
EXTREMELY HIGH CRIME. DO NOT USE your iPhone when walking around since theft runs rampant here. After using my phone I put it in my front jacket breast pocket then five minutes later I noticed it was gone. It was Friday at around dinner time. 

This area has some restaurants but they are chains or have only average food.

We walked around briefly after dinner and the streets were pretty dumpy and run down. I couldn't wait to leave.  This is a tourist trap and you will get robbed if you take anything of value out. 

San Francisco is a great and beautiful city but people at the sprint store told me that people love stealing iPhones here and 30% of his customers show up to replace a stolen iPhone.
author: Camille L.

description:
What's not to love about Fisherman's Wharf?  For me personally, I simply love the sensory triggers: The smell of the area - the harbor, ocean, oil, and wood piers.  The sounds - the seagulls, sea lions, and ships, all while eating hot clam chowder out of a sourdough bread bowl or chowing down on some fresh dungeness crab dipped in butter.  Total heaven for me.   

Other highlights are the infamous "bush man" who scares people along Jefferson across from Joe's Crab Shack, a personal favorite of mine.  There's an In N Out burger close by, a Hard Rock Cafe, Ghiradelli Square, and shopping at Pier 39.  Guardino's at the corner of Jefferson & Taylor has the best dungeness crab and clam chowder, and they even sell their soup in a can.  The hoard of seal lions that can usually be seen on the floating wooden pallets west of Pier 39 is definitely a sight to see.  I'm not sure as to when they're there or not as I've experienced two scenarios - a sole lion plopped into the ocean as soon as we got there, leaving the place deserted, and another time when it was 100% occupancy with noisy barking and stinky air.  Super cool.
author: Vince N.

description:
Very touristy! But at least the area is okay to walk around and explore.

Be patient as you try to get a picture of it's famous, iconic logo as people do have a history of hanging around that sign.
author: Alexander H.

description:
Not sure if anyone else is in this predicament, but I was in San Fran for a couple of days for meetings - and I only had about four hours to explore the city.  

I used up about two of those hours to walk up and down Fisherman's Wharf.  Here you will be surrounded by Tourists, but across the street from a lot of office buildings if you want to be around actual residents.  Food-wise there are the usual touristy suspects -- Bubba Gumps, I'm looking at you -- and also a lot of SF-specific places (see: The Crab Station).  

The views are great - you can see the bay, parts of the Golden Gate bridge, some other bridge, and Alcatraz.  This is the place where you depart on cruise ships or other, smaller bay tours.  You can grab a small boat (max 6 people) and do a one hour boat tour of the bay for about $30/person.  

All the way at the end of the Wharf (closer to the GG bridge), there is a little sandy area where you can go dip your toes in the water.  I found this to be a cute area (not anywhere near as annoying or crowded at NYC's Times Square), and would recommend a visit.
author: Dione D.

description:
Kinda fun, kinda crowded. Lots of people.

I was gonna try the clam chowder at the fish house upstairs but decided I was craving a hot dog. Oh well, enjoyed my clam chowder at the Splash Cafe in Pismo Beach anyway, on my way back to LA. That's the place for chowder.

The line for the restroom is super long. FYI. I didn't even try. Lots of activities but I think the fishermans wharf is more for family with kids. I couldn't take the Crowd for very long, decided to walk back pass the other piers and then to Union Square again.
author: Helen D.

description:
Had a great time visiting the Wharf.
Great tourist area to visit and lots to do and lots of things happening down here.
You can shop or tour virtually anything around here.  Try one of the seafood stands around here for good decent priced food.  Only downside around here is finding parking and paying such a high rate for it.
author: Matt S.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf is touristy to the max. Only the great views (if the weather is nice) of Alcatraz and the sea lions saved it from a lower rating. Also it's a short walk from the Ghiradelli chocolate factory. 

There are a lot of food vendors and restaurants so you don't go hungry especially if you're craving chowder or lobster rolls. Also Pier 39 makes you feel like you're at the carnival with the carousel, kiddie rides, and snacking options. 

Like most tourist spots you only come here once to say that you did but will never return if given the choice. The crowds, traffic, and disgruntled street performers put a damper on the experience. One performer ended his routine early, then told the audience that it was their fault for being unenthusiastic about his act, and walked off. He certainly gave everyone a show with that fit.
author: Eugenia L.

description: Spent a lot of our time in SF in Fisherman's Wharf. Originally from Long Island, I am a seafood and seaside lover indeed. There are so many options for seafood here, it is really difficult to pick a place to eat! In addition to the restaurants, there are a bunch of seafood vendors where you can get seafood on the go at a reasonable price. Excellent chowder here, just about every place serves it! Plenty of shops here and cruises around the bay leave from here as well. Shops sell a lot of touristy, SF gift items like t-shirts and jewelry. Excellent place to walk around, enjoy a drink, and grab a bite to eat. Visited here almost every day during our trip. Definitely very chilly though, be sure to bring a jacket!
author: Stephanie A.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf is where it's at when you're in San Francisco. Now it's necessarily not going to be the best place to go to if you don't like crowds or fish smell.

Parking here is not too bad compared to the city. There are some areas where you can park on the street but if I were you, I would just park in a parking structure to avoid getting your car towed.

There are many things to do here; get a clam chowder bowl or any animal designed sourdough bread at Boudin, watch the seal at Pier 39, walk to the Ghirardelli factory & get yourself a bag of chocolates, see Alcatraz from a far, get a good view of the bay area, and etc. Definitely worth a visit when you're in the area!
author: Anne L.

description:
This place is beautiful. 

Once you've parked and closed your eyes as you paid the parking fee, this place can make you feel like a $30 holiday rate isn't so bad. 

The amount of restaurants and little shops throughout this wharf makes it so much fun just to walk around and people watch. The closer to the piers you are, the more high-end the restaurants are. Mainly because there are more tourist attractions there and it isn't abnormal for prices to be a lot higher. 

The further down you walk, you'll start to find chain restaurants like Applebee's, McDonald's, and In N Out. All of which have much higher prices as well. 

This main road is very busy. It is always full of cars stuck in traffic. So make sure you avoid this road when looking for parking. My advice is to do your research before making the trip. Find out where parking lots are located and what their prices are. And don't be afraid of walking a few blocks to get to the wharf. 

Everyone should experience this place. The food, the ambiance, and being a tourist again. This place is full of adventure and fun things that you can't do anywhere else.
author: Kimberly E.

description: This is a must-see when touring San Francisco! The food, people, entertainment - all colorful and memorable. There are a ton of homeless people around so be careful.
author: Matthew P.

description:
Magnificent & brilliant, you can spend ur day there enjoying in several activities. 
- Eating seafood with a great seaside. 
- Enjoying the view by looking at Alcatraz island.
- Take a tour in Alcatraz island.
- Buy medals, t-shirts form the gift shops. 
Have fun \o/
author: Mohammed A.

description: I visited here because I wanted to be able to say that I've been. It was very crowded, touristy (people trying to enlist you for their tours, overpriced souvenir shops, beggars and chain stores), and simply not that attractive or pretty or in any way. I wish that I had stopped into the famous Boudin shop for a sourdough bread bowl, but I had already spent $8 on an incredibly tiny cup of crab meat. As in, the little cup that you would get soy sauce in with a Chinese take-out order. The crab was, of course, delicious and very fresh! I'm glad I went, just to see what the place was like, but I can't say that I'll ever go back.
author: Jordan T.

description:
When I go visit a city I am always looking to get out of the tourist areas and truly experience what the city has to offer. My husband and I decided we were only going to spend a morning doing the tourist thing and the rest of our trip we would see the real SF. The Wharf itself is walkable in less than 30 minutes.Pier 39 is the main area and has all of the shops located on it. You can also see the sea lions there and try out some of the sourdough bread and chocolate shops. In-N-Out is also located there, the only one in the SF city limits I might add. The Wharf doesn't have access to BART, and to get there and back, you have to take the F bus line.

If you must see the Wharf you can also stop by Lombard Street, Ghirardelli Square and even walk to the Palace of the Fine Arts/The Golden Gate Bridge viewing area (it is a 2 mile walk, just to be warned) to have a whole day filled with tourist activities. After that I suggest going to see the real SF and all it has to offer.
author: Courtney D.

description: I  had a great time while in town for a Stros game vs Giants.This place was very reminiscent of the Kemah boardwalk but offered more choices for dining and entertainment. Wear a coat  or pullover while visiting. I froze my butt off just wearing a t shirt.
author: Romero L.

description: Last time we came here in May, and again in Thanksgiving long weekend. It feels different coming back here in winter. And, we'll def miss how fresh all the seafood is here and of course the yummy sour dough!!!!
author: Yolanda S.

description: This is ok place and most of the shops are selling less quality souvenir in very expensive price. Nice walking place with lots of people but don't expect too much. Parking on street are cheaper then parking lots.
author: Atiq K.

description:
I sometimes like to hike from downtown Market Street to Fisherman's Wharf whenever I'm in San Francisco. I prefer to come here during low season including weekends and holidays, so I can avoid the crowd.

I used to go to San Francisco a lot when I used to live in Reno. My friends and I would drive down every month just for the heck of it.

It still looks the same as I remembered it except for a few new shops.

I always have a great time at the Wharf and Pier 39. I Love watching the Sea lions, but I witnessed one of the ghastliest things here a few years ago. This pelican ate one of the smaller birds at the wharf! The kids watching were mortified! You know how big their mouths are. It just gobbled the whole thing with one swoop! Pretty traumatic sight even for an adult like myself.

However, the place is still fun, and there is no shortage of places to eat.
author: Michael F.

description: I was told to definitely come here during my time in San Francisco, but I'm not sure it lives up to the hype. Fisherman's Wharf is busy and crowded. Be prepared for some difficult parking situations (we were lucky and found a street parking spot for $2/hour over Memorial Day weekend just as someone was leaving, but I'm SURE that's not always the case). There's plenty of restaurants and food stands that sell seafood (lots of fried options, also their signature clam chowder in bread bowls) that are slightly on the high side in terms of price. I was also underwhelmed by their shops, which seem to cater to tourists sell either cheap trinkets or expensive crafts. They have the Musée Mécanique, which is a museum with old fashioned arcade games which I thought was fun to go through. Out on the piers and the main street, I was probably approached 5-6 times whether I wanted to go on an Alcatraz cruise, so that got old after awhile. I did really enjoy watching the sea lions sunbathing, playing, and fighting though! It's nice to just walk along the shore, and the crowd thins out once you get past the main part of Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Yum, Yum, and more Yum. A Wharf is one of the few places where it's "okay" that things may smell a little fishy. When visitors think of San Francisco they think of fresh crab, clam chowder in bread bowls & shrimp cocktail.  You can get all of that and more at Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco. 

If you're not interested in eating from the food stalls, you have plenty of restaurants to choose from as well.  There's the Fisherman's Grotto, the ever famous Alioto's and legendary Scomas only a stones throw away. No matter the time of year or weather conditions, the Wharf is always filled with locals, tourists and day trippers. There's plenty to explore from shopping to eating to site seeing.  It's always fun to watch the street performances although last week we lost the "Bush Man" who was always fun to watch scaring unsuspecting folks.  Harmless fun that had a way of making any vist to the City a little more memorable. 

So if you're planning  of a trip to SF yourself or showing around some out of town guests, the Fisherman's Wharf is a must visit stop within one of my very favorite Cities.
author: Christie B.

description:
Over-crowded tourist spot, but a must-go if you're ever in SF.

Avoid driving here at all cost. Traffic and parking is horrible. Bus/trolley is the way to go. If you're going to the Ferry Marketplace, I recommend parking near there and then using public transportation to get to Fisherman's wharf. 

Walking down the row of food stand is extremely fun & chaotic. Stop by random stands and get a little bit of their best.
author: Elizabeth K.

description: Yay! If you're imagining touristy San Fransisco with fish and chips, the sea lions, the salty sea air and souvenir boutiques, then this is your one stop shop! In a group, or all by yourself, this visitors attraction is great for all ages! The ferry boat is near by, you can catch a pedi cab, and watch the street performers, its all right here! Just be sure to pack long sleeve (at all times of year) and your camera!
author: Casey S.

description: I visited this place over 20 years ago and it's among the places I had visited with open air markets since I did the open air markets in Seattle, New Orleans, Chicago, and San Francisco. You get a nice view of Alcatraz in the San Francisco Bay and the place is lined with lots of restaurants mostly steak and seafood places and small shops. I still have my souvenir coin from the Guinness Museum at Fisherman's Wharf. You will enjoy the shops and restaurants if you're from out of town.
author: Nafeesah A.

description:
Stating the obvious here, indeed it's a pricey tourist trap, but you still can't help but think it's also a pretty cool place.  I really like the delicious seafood, especially the Dungeness crab and the clam chowder served in a sourdough bread bowl.  I agree that when they start price-gouging on the parking there, that's just not right.  You're better off just either parking outside the city and taking the BART or a taxi (or even an Uber or Lyft car) to the place; after all, when you start having to pay $60 for parking, then we're already beyond reasonable.

I grew up in the Bay Area as a kid and have very fond memories of this place, but I never really noticed how expensive it was until a few years ago.  Around the area, you might find some cheap t-shirts and cheesy souvenirs for sale, very cheap and of dubious quality, but around Fisherman's Wharf, that's when you start paying like $10 for a portion of Dungeness crab or $8 for a bowl of clam chowder, though they are delicious.
author: Jerry I.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf is tourist central. Parking is an expensive nightmare ($20-$40 in a parking garage) and it is always incredibly crowded.

It's got some cool things to see, the aquarium is neat and there's tons of shops to buy your SF souvenirs. Yummy snacks and restaurants populate the big wharf as well. I believe they do kid shows at the end of the wharf too, so this is a fun place to bring your kiddos.

I would have given this place 5 stars the first time I visited, but now that I've taken various family members here on several different visits it's lost a lot of it's magic to me.

Come here if you've never been, you will enjoy yourself. But once or twice is enough in a lifetime.
author: Emily G.

description:
Was just here two days ago with my boyfriend and his exacts words, "My most favorite place in the world". Haha but I have to say, I agree with him. Every time I visit SF I have to stop by this place for some fresh steamed crab! But I love the place solely for its fresh seafood! I love how they have a row down the street of just different stands of fresh crabs/lobsters/clam chowder and just so much more! This place is perfect if you're in SF on a cold day.. Eat their clam chowder and have a steamed crab while you're at it! Simply delicious! 

Quick tip! Each stand has a restaurant behind them and you can just eat inside instead of standing out in the streets and trying to eat a crab!
author: Lynn T.

description: My favorite thing about the Fisherman's Wharf was the market and Musee Musique. Honestly I preferred Pier 39 over the Wharf. Two completely different areas though. One is more touristy and one is more for the seafood foodie. If you love your crab though you will have to check out the wharf and crab a big boiled crab. They're absolutely huge!! Yum! For shopping though take a 2 minute walk to pier 39.
author: Mo M.

description:
The Wharf has to be seen when in Frisco, the restaurants, shops, tourist, the aquarium, all these attractions have to be seen. Pier 39 is home to all the sea lions on floating wooden docks, they are very entertaining, a bit loud at times, but a must see.

There is quite a bit to see at the wharf. Neat ships, shops, lots of unique people, cool little attractions, the sea lions and of course good views of the Golden Gate Bridge and Alcatraz.

One thing that you have to consider is parking, always a huge issue in San Francisco. For an half a hour stop at the Wharf be prepared to pay as much as 8$
author: Lee P.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf was, hands down, one of the highlights of my trip to San Fran. I love this place. It's a must-do if you are a tourist visiting and, if you live in San Fran, well then you are simply lucky as and I envy you!

It's easy to there - just take the F-Cable Car from Market St and it's a nice ride (can get quite bumpy but well this is San Fran!) as you get to go along The Embarcadero. I think you could also take the Powell/Mason Cable car off Powell St station and walk a bit but don't quote me on that..

When you actually get there, there's plenty to do and see! We arrived a bit early in the morning to see the Sea Lions and we were not disappointed, they are pretty cool. You can also enjoy amazing views of Alcatraz and the Bay. 

There are a lot of shops so you won't run out of options when it comes to shopping - the NFL shop is one of my favourites, they sell sports merchandise (incl. College gear). I also received a complimentary discount vouchers booklet when I checked in on Yelp so that was cool!

In terms of eateries, well there's plenty and the prices are really affordable as well. Make sure you try the Chowder (it's so good!). We had it at Chowders and it was very nice and I also had it at Boudin and theirs was really good as well. 

No matter what you are after or feel like, may it be a walk, shopping, some R & R with stunning views of the bay, brekkie, brunch, lunch, dessert or just a bit of fun; Fisherman's Wharf has all of this and I miss it!
author: Kevin S.

description:
If you gave the Tenderloin five stars for the human misery but knocked off a star because the prices weren't high enough, well, my friend, this ashtray of a tourist attraction is for you.

There are things worth visiting in and around here - the Musée Méchanique, the sea lion marina, the aquarium - but as a destination in and of itself, euuuugh. This is a tourist leg-hold trap.
author: Rob C.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf is an area that hosts a variety of shops and restaurants. Many of the shops are what you would find in your the mall, and many of the restaurants are chains. It's kid friendly as there are plenty of activities and toys for kids. 

In other words, it's very touristy!!! Not our kind of style, but as our first time in SF together we visited and took pictures by the big captain steering wheel :)
author: Felicia L.

description:
Would I go back? Nope
Am I glad I went? yes!

I was a tourist! it's what tourists do! When in Rome...ahem...in San Fran you MUST do as TOURISTS do! 

It's a nice spot to come walk around, meader in and out of shops carelessly and take a lot of photos! I think we were in and out in no more than 30 minutes. I planned it right before my "after lunch, before dinner nap" . Worked out beautifully. Took one of the very cool SF electric buses from the farmer's market to skip the long walk. 

There weren't that many seals there as I expected but it was still cool. It's also a very kid friendly place with lots for them to do. 

A tourist type of place but still charming.
author: Brenda P.

description: We have been here a few times.....I checked in at  twice and have not done a review.....Yelp caught me and told me you been here twice write a review OK, If you visited San Francisco Fisherman Wharf, pier 39 is the heart of the wharf, there is something from everybody from tours to Alcatraz and the other Islands in the bay, galleries, cruises, bikes, scooters, cars, and Segway rentals, wine tasting, galleries, fishing, street performers, restaurants, hotels, and shopping, to get an awesome experience is to walk or run from pier 39 along the boardwalk to the Ferry Building for sure you will see something you would want to do, eat, or see.
author: Tommy M.

description:
Wow, quite a bit has changed in the last several months at Fisherman's Wharf. There is now two-way traffic on Jefferson Street and part of the road near The Cannery and Anchorage Shopping Center has gotten a huge makeover; new brick street and wider sidewalks for pedestrians! No more of those rough roads and narrow beaten asphalt sidewalks along that stretch. Although change is hard to get used to, this certainly is welcoming and a great addition to attract more tourists.

It's definitely a great place to hang out in San Francisco, and I don't get to make it up here as much nowadays, but it's nice to walk around every now and then. Lots of museums and attractions along the Fisherman's Wharf to see and explore! If you love food, then you'll likely enjoy the various restaurants and eateries offered around here. Parking can be a nightmare especially if you park in the center of the action, but I sometimes park about 3-4 blocks away and just walk over from there. Other alternatives include taking the MUNI F Line Historic Streetcars (oh, those are so lovely and amusing at the same time) from any point in Downtown SF.
author: Paul N.

description: I guess you should check this out if your in SF.  Lots of shops, people, places to eat.  It's pretty civil, there is a Musuem ,Naval, here and there are always street musicians and entertainers to amuse you.  It's a nice afternoon to walk around, and near the pier 33 for even more of same.
author: Nick S.

description: This place is overly touristy.  However it's cool to see the sea lions.  The restaurants and vendors have plenty of seafood.  The gift shops are pricey.  It's on the water and there's plenty to do.  You can see Alcatraz and take a ferry.  It's a nice area.  Theres a museum, too.
author: Andy S.

description: This is probably my favorite place to go in San Francisco. It is a place I visit everytime I go up north from LA. There is so much to do here and it's a long side piers, you can see Alcatraz, several gift shops, places for dining, and live entertainment
author: Diana V.

description:
It's pretty much agreed that any SF tourist should come visit this place. First off, I highly recommend that you find street parking because it's cheaper. The parking garage by Fisherman's Wharf can cost as much as $33 for the night! You're better off paying with quarters for a cheaper price.

But other than that, there's so many shops and eateries here! A great place for sightseeing and also there's a place for you to ride the cable car if you wish. There's street artists and vendors nearby.

If you go to Pier 39 at night, you can see the sea lions howling and splashing in the waters. I'm not sure if they're there during the day, but this is another nice spot for walking around.
author: Eva L.

description:
This is just an iconic place, you hear all your buddies tell you to "Be sure to get yourself to Fisherman's Wharf" and when you ask what the heck there is do there, they'll probably just tell you... "You eat and play". 

That's true. But let me give you a few extra details. 

Start at the Aquarium on Pier 39 and make your way to Pier 43. You'll hit many food places and shopping places along the way. Some fun ones include: doughnuts, the Lefty Store, the sock store, Ben and Jerry's, etc. It's fun to cruise the decks and be total tourists. 

Another fun activity is visiting the sea lions, they're "toats cray" as the hipster chicks would say. But it's fun to say you've done it. 

As you make your way along the pier, watch out for the psycho birds that divebomb your head and the people scouting for your money. Some straight up tell your that they're soliciting for weed and beer... Classy. 

It's busy but fun. Do it just to say you have! 

TIPS & TRICKS: 
* Rent bikes and ride along the road. You'll get from place to place quicker and there are places to lock them up in case you choose to sightsee some more. 
* Usually a man hangs out on the other side of Pier 39 (when you head to Pier 15) and he does some fun sketches of you/you and a buddy in San Francisco for cheap.
author: Haley N.

description:
Another hot spot of attractions for tourists here in San Francisco. There is an aquarium, a carousel along with an arcade here. There are some good places to eat at and stores to shop at. It is also good for sightseeing and taking photos for memories. Angel Island, Alcatraz Island & Golden Gate Bridge can be seen from a distance. Good place to go to if you have family visiting! But certainly, this place is always crowded with tourists.

Driving here? Don't even consider, it's either street metered parking or public garage parking. Public transportation is the best way to get here since the F Market Streetcars stop right in front, Powell St Cable Car lines, bus routes 39, 47 & 8X all stop within a distance from here.

Parking: -1 star & Crowding: -1 star
author: Bennett W.

description:
If you're visiting  San Francisco then this is the place to go. You also get a taste of Bay Area as well when there. With restaurants, shopping, and even events to do such as the aquarium, tours, bikes rides and more, you can surely make a day of it.

We enjoyed the views of the water and had plenty of places to sit and relax privately. It's a long stretch of places to walk to and from and very exciting to see what San Francisco is all about.
author: Samantha L.

description: Everytime I visit San Francisco, I make it a mission to visit this touristy part of the Bay. First and foremost is the food, I never leave Fisherman's Wharf without having a bite of fresh shrimp, fish and calamari. That's the number one reason why I come back to visit and sightseeing, shopping for friends and family, free entertainment (live music, tourists and the sealions).
author: Paul B.

description: This area is a must see when touring SF.  They have quite a few shops, and plenty of restaurants to choose from with a good variety of cuisines. We went two separate days and there were plenty of SeaLions to see and laugh at, and also a good place to get pictures of Alcatraz. Pier 39 is great, but also are the shops along the streets.  Bring plenty of cash.
author: Jeffrey G.

description:
Ok, so we all know this is a tourist trap. I'm aware, and I accept. That being out of the way, WHY would the City of SF just seem to leave this magnet unguarded and unkempt? From the piles of litter to the complete lack of any authoritative presence, Fisherman's Wharf is a small fiefdom left to the whims of the trinket hawkers, chowder mongers, talentless buskers, and resident homeless population.

I love atmosphere, but there has to be a line someplace if SF doesn't want their guests to feel as if they've just been duped into visiting the crazy cat lady version of town. Honestly, one is forced to consistently convince themselves, "Oh, this can't be it. There must be something else around the bend" only to find out they may have just passed the comparatively best part of the wharf.  

Maybe the Wharf was the place to be 20-30 years ago, but much like that paint color you picked for the living room in 1986, what is hip and fun then...is dirty and off putting today.
author: Bob H.

description:
This is a great little tourist area! Love how it's so open and with great views of the water it's a nice place to casually walk around and enjoy the weather! 
They have your typical tourist shops, and restaurants. 
When we were walking through a magician was soon tricks fun to watch for a moment!
author: Allison P.

description: Definite tourist trap. Tons of people, hard to get around. Make sure you use the restroom before you leave home/hotel. You WILL wait on extremely long lines otherwise, men and women. Really nothing special to see. Not memorable and not a location I'd go out of my way to visit. Plan on super expensive parking or an extremely long Uber trip as traffic is really heavy. Overall, not worth it.
author: J P.

description:
Ordered at Guardino's---
My husband and I were very excited to come here since I really love seafood, especially crabs and oysters. But I am very disappointed with our orders. We ordered clam chowder $6 for 8oz, lobsters claws cocktail $13.95 and the lobster sandwich $19.95. 
Prices are high, but we were there to spend money on whatever entices us. (Looks can be deceiving. Haha)
Lobster claws are fresh but quite rubbery in texture. Lobster sandwich is bad. It's like shredded lobster with some chunks of claws mixed with tons of mayo. And the bread is just tough. 
Clam chowder so far is the best tasting of all. Not so thick nor thin in consistency and the flavor is just right. It's enjoyable to eat even when with the fairly hot weather.
Might go back for the clam chowder. And taste some of the deep fried dishes (I am not really a fan of deep fried anything)
One employee(man) at the Crab Station is kind of rude. We were trying to order oysters but instead told us that we should wait for the next one on shift because he was on his break. He was the only one around and he's actually not taking his break so well because he's intently fixing their condiments. We didn't get to order.
author: Kam V.

description: This area was very entertaining with the street performers, penny arcade and restaurants where the crabs are being prepared by nimble "chefs" ripping off their claws. There is seating but very little with shade. We have been fortunate to be here on sunny days but unfortunate to be able to get out of the sun. Quite a few people find their way onto the wharf with the submarine and squat with their crab sandwiches on the shade
author: Sue L.

description: Super touristy but Sometimes that's just what the doctor ordered. It's a good place to start your San Fran exploration journey. Lombard street is near not too far away if you drive.
author: KD J.

description:
This is one of the most touristy spots in San Francisco.  And, as a tourist, that means I just had to check it out!

I enjoyed walking the wharf along the water, but I wasn't too overly impressed by the choices here.  It felt a lot like an outdoor mall.  We didn't eat lunch here, but there were LOTS of seafood restaurants to choose from.  There are also tons of spots to shop, which was another thing we weren't too excited about doing, but we browsed in a few spots we were interested in looking into (poster shop, etc).  It was a very busy August day, so that meant there were lots of tourists like myself wandering around.

Pier 39 was probably the best part about the Wharf, since you could stand by the water and check out all the sea lions sunning themselves.

Overall, I am glad I checked Fisherman's Wharf out, but I am not sure I would return.
author: Sonya L.

description:
One of the most touristy spots in SFO boosts -

* A lot of decent seafood restaurants
* Good views of the harbour
* Lot of shopping spots 
* A great place to visit with family and friends

Overall a decent place to visit in town!
author: Vineet S.

description: I love visiting the Wharf. There are so many great fresh fish and seafood restaurants and so many stores to shop at. This is a must when visiting San Francisco. This is a touristy area, but well worth it if you want some fresh food and touristy sights. It is also the lead in to many other great attractions and tourist sights in San Francisco.
author: Tina S.

description: A really fun way to experience SF. Great shops and places to eat. It is touristy, but an awesome place all around.
author: Jordan B.

description:
It wasn't very busy at all. We parked, which was kinda pricy, $15, but expected.

We walked about a half mile down the pier, saw sea lions, people watched, and looked at cool attractions.

It was a really lovely day to do it. I definitely think that if you go to San Francisco that you have to go to Fisherman's Wharf. If you don't, you've missed out on a "tourist" monument.

This place has great views. Really. You have to go.
author: Kira W.

description:
Smelly (a mix of urine, sewer and fish), crowded (with rude, strange characters), cheap (most stores sold nothing but cheap souvenirs not worth a buck), and dirty.  

In fact, in the kite shop, the scent of sewage blew through so strongly that the cashier lit a scented candle that was for sale next to the register only to be reprimanded by another clerk a few minutes later for lighting something that was meant for sale.  When she explained that the sewer scent had been overwhelming, he simply replied, "Welcome to San Francisco!"  

I should mention, however, that the kite shop was the ONLY store worth going into.  
Good luck if you go; enjoy the circus.
author: Lacy W.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf is a tourist Mecca. All of the sea lions, kitschy views, bike rentals, cheap snacks, gaudy t-shirts, chowder in bread bowls, and boardwalkin' you could ever dream of. It has its charm and all, but the mob of visitors is always a bit much to make it worth an elongated stay. 

Some cool things in the area: 

In-N-Out
Museé Mechanique
Pier 39 (for the sea lions)
Any shop with terrible knick knacks for gag gifts

One of my favorite things is taking a pedicab down Embarcadero to see the landscape of the wharf. You'll get to see some great parts of the skyline and the bay. Plenty of spots to stop and grab shots of Alcatraz.
author: Benjamin G.

description:
Why does everyone make it a point to come here? It's a tourist trap. It's stuffy and especially overcrowded on summer weekends. It gets so crowded that you can't even walk without having to stop every couple steps. But if you must come down here, avoid all the chain restaurants, and venture just a little further away from the main pier for some entertainment, shopping and chowder. Maybe catch a crew dancing, singing, or some dude preaching to religion and that it's the end of the world.

Beyond that, I don't know what all the hype is about? Two words, TOURIST TRAP!
author: Jason P.

description: Homeless haven. San Fran needs to do something about the hordes of mental/homeless people hanging around the city. They are ruining the place. The wharf is still a good place to hang out and get souvenirs.
author: Chris N.

description: You definitely should stop by the Wharf when you're visiting San Francisco, though it is definitely a tourist trap and can get very congested. Stop by, enjoy some seafood, look around, and move on. Lots to see in San Francisco!
author: Matthew C.

description: So many great stores and little restaurants with great food always great and crowded on a sunny day. But be sure to bring a camera and take pictures because well there's so much to do!
author: Addison M.

description: scomas was terrific..going back on ash wednesday...just took the behind the scenes tour of alcatraz...well worth the time and money
author: Larry G.

description: Classic San Francisco tourist spot. Probably worth going to see for a few minutes but that is all you need. Consider it a tourist trap. Was busier than Times Square and a lot of people are off in their own world just wandering around. Not a good place to spend time at if you are looking to cover any ground at all. There are lines for everything, traffic is terrible, it is commercial, corporate America at its worst.
author: Nick H.

description:
A must do if you are in the area. The sea lions are awesome and there are a lot of stores and restaurants. 

Parking is a little expensive. We paid $17.95 for 3 hours in a parking garage but saw a sign that would have given us 2 hours free with validation. Get something to eat and have them validate your parking. It will save you some $$
author: Jesse P.

description:
This was one of the highlights of my vacation trip. Most of the restaurants that I wanted to eat at were here (see separate reviews on that), a lot of touristy things to do etc. I am allergic to sea food, however, there was a lot of non seafood things to participate in.

Firstly it's windy so if you did your hair nicely the wind will ruin it. Don't bother finger combing it...it will get ruined in a few seconds. I have short hair, therefore, I could not tie it back so my best friend when talking to me felt as though he was talking to a harry Muppet.

It's not cold, however, if you have short hair the wind will or can give you wind burn in your ears, therefore, wear ear plugs so that your ear drums don't hurt.

Most of the stuff here are tourist attractions and geared as such. There is a cheesy portion of the Wharf that is circus like. Reminds me of the tacky walk way at Niagra Falls in Ontario.

Be prepared to spend 3 hours and walk a lot of hills to get there.
author: Shila B.

description: Only went bc it was must, apparently. Too crowded too enjoy.. Tired clam chowder at one of the restaurants, was good. bought souvenirs at the shops and left.
author: Brianna M.

description: Fun, family, a getaway for all for a day or weekend if you want to cruise or tour. Always love the wharf, food, festivities, enjoy the beauty of San Francisco.
author: Phil H.

description: Fisherman's Wharf was the first tourist attraction I visited in San Francisco. The wharf quickly became one of my favorite places to enjoy down time. I went on two occasions and it was very busy (Friday & Sunday). I like Fisherman Wharf because it has a lot of attractions, shops, restaurants, and street performers on the pier.  It's not many things you won't find at Fisherman's Wharf. The scenery is priceless on a sunny day (great views during sunset). There are sea lions at Pier 39. Bring comfortable walking shoes. If you're a tourist, definitely put Fisherman's Wharf on your bucket list.
author: Dominic B.

description: We love to see food vendors outside of restaurant Row. Enjoyed a wonderful calamari salad that was not fried calamari. Purchased some San Francisco sourdough bread at the Boudin bakery. Had fun purchasing postcards and people watching. It was a very relaxing and enjoyable time.
author: Eugene C.

description:
Great place to spend a day in the city.   

I did just that the other day.   Only this day it was raining.  
That does not preclude me from enjoying the day, though.
A bit of rain just means less people and less problems finding
a parking place...  conversely, there are no street performers
out either.   I miss that part of the Wharf.   They add so much
to the experience, that I miss them when they are not there..
the bush man, dog man, the musicians, the break dancers, 
the silver men....    The one constant, come rain or shine, is
all the good food and chowder.  My favorite chowder is from
Pier Market on Pier 39!  They also have excellent seafood.

Escape the rain by taking a ride on the F line trolley.  You can't
miss the historical trolley cars rumbling down the tracks along the
wharf.  For the measly amount of two bucks (75 cents seniors/disabled)
you can ride round trip to the Castro and back.   Great way to
relax for a bit.

Ahhh... the food, sights, sounds and smells of the Wharf.   It's sure to lift
your spirits!
author: Dale N.

description: Love coming here and enjoying the scenery. Great place to bring the kids and enjoy some yummy food & treats. The sealions are so fun to watch.
author: Liza P.

description: Busy area, wear or take a jacket, stop in for a drink at any restaurant. They aren't cheap but all helpful and full of atmosphere.   Loved the calamari we got twice from an outside vendor. Fun place to walk around and enjoy your friends or family
author: Janice K.

description: I don't care that this is a so called "tourist trap" this is a must see for any first time visitor!  I have always heard about the famous Fisherman's Wharf and seen pictures but never got to see it firsthand.  It can get extremely crowed but it is a lot of fun walking around seeing the sites and taking everything in.   There are cute shops, small restaurants, fresh seafood and a beautiful view of the ocean.  You get to see amazing views of Alcatraz Island, you can see the Golden Gate on one side and the Bay Bridge on the other.  Definitely visit Pier 39 and watch the sea lions- you can get lost in that for hours, especially if you aren't used to seeing them.  Ghirardelli is also right within walking distance and a cool site to see.  Obviously with any touristy site like this, it can get crowed and overwhelming, parking will be expensive, street performers are looking for money and the you will cross the occasional homeless person.  However, if you go in knowing it's a tourist trap and set the expectation right, then I highly recommend it for anyone visiting the city for the first time.
author: Jennifer D.

description: Definitely a must-see tourist attraction when visiting San Francisco. The location is a little inconvenient being that you have to search for free parking or just suck it up and pay the parking fee of $15 in one of their many parking lots located around the area. Being the cheap person that I am I saved my $15 and parked a couple blocks down and just walked to Fisherman's Wharf. As soon as we arrived, the smell of seafood and salt water filled my senses and at that point I wanted to dive into a nice warm clam chowder bread bowl. There were so many food vendors to choose from at the wharf which was great. However, the food was pricey especially since most of the dining restaurants offer and sell mainly seafood. If it is your first time in SF, this area offers good food, entertainment, tourist shops, and an iconic view of Alcatraz Island in the distance for some great pictures and selfies.
author: Elaine T.

description:
No self-respecting tourist - i.e. yours truly - can claim they went to San Francisco and not stop by Pier 39!

I came by this afternoon to enjoy the city sights and work on the "Vacation" part of my working vacation and have to say I had a great afternoon. This is like Bayside in Miami, only better! From what I understand, it was the old port of San Francisco and you can still see both sailboats and the ocassional steel ship.

You can catch a tour bus in which to check out the city, enjoy yummy crepes, seafood, or tourist trap  (there, i said it) food and buy the ever important souvenirs for friends back home. Don't forget to check out the sea lions as they chill and tan on the pier, with their ocassional Chewbacca sounds as they fight for turf! Check out Alcatraz too. It's clearly visible on a fogless day like today.

Being Halloween, I got to see quite a few people dressed up as well :)
author: Sergio F.

description: I love Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco. I know a lot of people call Fisherman's Wharf a Tourist trap, but I don't care. This place is a lot of fun, and it just so happens to be the gateway to San Francisco.
author: Kenny T.

description: It is a little difficult to really rate an experience for a tourist attraction, but hey, let me give it a whirl.  Loads of people.  Yes, there were hundreds of folks milling about and very little English could be heard.  Loads of shops.  Yes, there were many different shops all selling the same thing..crap knicknacks for different prices.  Loads of places to eat.  Yes, there were also many restaurants abound.  All selling crab, fish and shrimp meals and all had the same Sysco food items for purchase.  This is a tourist paradise.  One which I will not frequent again.   I felt like I was trapped in an amusement park with only one ride.
author: Jens B.

description: I love this place so much. Too bad its always crowded and the traffic is horrible. Filled with people that are out of town (including me haha) but my family and I tried coming back for a second time just to finally park and walk around since the first time we ended up making a u-turn and leaving since it was packed. This place is really great to visit and a go-to place. Just be prepared to pay $3.00 for every 20 min of parking as a last resort if you can't find parking.
author: Jethro M.

description: Yep, a serious tourist trap. But if you space visits out every 10 years or so, it's fun to visit. There is some serious seafood going on here and the prices aren't bad at the seafood stands. Too bad there is nowhere to eat that food. Otherwise, you'll have to pay a bit more to eat at a place with tables.
author: Nora S.

description: This is one of the spots we wanted to see while on vacation. We both agreed that we thought it would be bigger - it was smaller than we expected. The birds get annoying after awhile and many of the food options didn't look that great or were super expensive. Glad that we crossed this off out list though.
author: Carrie W.

description:
I went here with my fiance on 4th of July as part of my required tourist sightseeing.  It's a nice strip of little shops that sell San Francisco t shirts and souvenirs as well as plenty of chain type restaurants. I'm not really too into either of those things but if you are, it will be heaven.  

This is definitely a tourist trap, but I was there for the views.  You get a great look at Alcatraz, and the hills just south of the Wharf.  It really gave me an appreciation for the elevation changes in the city that I really love.  You can also check out some historic ships along the pier that are run by the national park service.  

If you come here for the touristy shops and things, stay for the great views.  Also on a side note keep your eyes out for any out of place bushes.  The bushman hides and tries to scare tourists as they walk along the wharf. 

http://youtu.be/SnY5-ota3SI
author: Alex K.

description:
I love the entire embarcadero area. Full of energy, restaurants, shops, and view of the bay. What's there not to love...except for the horrendous torrent of tourists (like myself) :-) 

In any case, you cannot visit SF without checking out this area. Try some clam chowder, lobster rolls. Also an amazing place to watch July 4th fireworks. I recommend watching it from the top of the parking garage, where you can catch two simultaneous identical shows just off-shore.
author: James W.

description: My girlfriend and I had a fun time walking through a Pier 33 and Pier 39. Boudin's clam chowder and sourdough pizza were delicious, the Alactraz tour was very fun, the boardwalk had a ton of shops to explore, and the Ghirardelli Square is merely minutes away.
author: Brian A.

description: What I don't get is why the tourists are choosing to eat at McDonald's, In-n-Out, and Applebee's when they are surrounded by hundreds of delicious local food. If you want to eat your Big Mac so much, go home to whatever city you came from. You're useless foot traffic in this beautiful place. The wharf could be so much more fun to hang out in if tourists weren't so busy NOT looking at where they're crossing in their hurry to get from the parking lot to the McDonald's.
author: Samantha C.

description: On the last day of my San Francisco trip, we decided to do something super touristy, since our SF-local friend had shown us a couple pretty obscure and cool local spots. Since my friend also wanted clam chowder, Fisherman's Wharf and Pier 39 it was! On a Monday, it was still quite crowded so I'm sure it gets pretty crazy on weekends. Fisherman's Wharf is purely a tourist trap, but still quite fun to look around at interesting things. Worth a visit while in town, especially if you've never been!
author: Ivy W.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf is the equivalent of Chicago's Navy Pier, but better.  There are lots and lots of shops and restaurants along the way, and we enjoyed taking a morning stroll through the fog before our Alcatraz Cruise.  Pier 39 is where it's at!

It's free to wander, but don't wander all day!  It's a touristy area, so you better make sure you open your ideas and head off the beaten path if you spend a few hours here.  This isn't all San Francisco has to offer.
author: Angela P.

description: Great tourist attraction!  So many shops and restaurants to visit with a beeeeauuutiful view. It's a lot of fun to hear different accents from people from all over the world.  A must-visit place for anyone visitng SF!
author: Karen K.

description: Foods are great specially the clam chowder served in a bowl bread. Perfect combination. Price of foods are average a lot of varieties to choose, one day is not enough to fully enjoy what the wharf has to offer. A lot of activities to do and suitable for all ages.
author: David T.

description: There was fresh seafood everywhere, omg it was all around me. It was a fantastic way to introduce my family from Texas to the pier and welcome them to the bay. I had a wonderful time and in my opinion if you don't want to go big on restaurants here, grab yourself something fresh from the waters, the food at these spots is delicious and the prices are decent it won't take much to fill you up and make you smile.
author: Hector R.

description:
When showing friends and family San Francisco for the first time, we always have to take them to Fisherman's Wharf.  Okay, we do not have to take them....but we do.

Fisherman's Wharf is just one of those many landmark places in San Francisco.  In our experience, the best time to go is Monday through Thursday.  The crowds have not been nearly as chaotic as compared to weekends.

Enjoy the experience and bring your camera.  Plenty of photo opportunities.  Bring your walking shoes and don't let the crowds overwhelm you.  It's actually kind of cool just to find a spot away from the pack.....look back and just people watch.  Also, there are awesome views of Alcatraz  and the bay if you walk farther along the pier.  Have fun!  We always do.
author: PatrickJ T.

description:
I used to work at the Starbucks on beach and Hyde and I truly believe this area is my favorite.  It might be touristy sometimes, which makes the wharf lively.

On Saturdays and Sundays, there are a lot of street vendors that sell trinkets and paintings.  Some of them are really good if your into that stuff.

This place definitly makes my top 20 places in San Francisco which you can read here

http://www.thealldayblog.com/the-choose-your-own-adventure-1-day-all-day-trip-guide-to-san-francisco/

I share with you some photos and videos of the wharf if your interested on how I perceive the Fishermans Wharf.

-Mike Le All Day!
author: Michael L.

description: Well, we stopped just for quick bite and end up getting a fresh crab sandwich and some other recommended dishes. Not bad at all. It tasted good and the bread had a fresh made feel. I enjoyed it :-) we also met one of the older employees, can't remember his name but he is been working there for 30 plus years. A really nice Hispanic guy who talked about the history of the restaurant and how things have changed over the years... I May come back again :-)
author: Miguel S.

description:
Pretty much like Santa Monica Pier or Redondo Beach Pier. Very lively with many stores to check out. 

The sea lions were the best. So hilarious and cute! They were ar-ar-in' all day. It was pretty amusing to just observe them.

Couldn't stop taking pics and videos D:
author: Ayumi S.

description:
Tourist trap for sure, but I enjoyed my time at Fisherman's Wharf. I felt like there was more breathing room than downtown San Fran which seemed very congested to me. In fact, if I were to stay in San Fran again, I'd probably stay around Fisherman's Wharf. It's pretty easy to drive around and get back into the city.

They have a good selection of restaurants. Lots of souvenir shops which we didn't go into. We strolled on the boardwalk to get from Pier 39 to Pier 33, and yes there are several cruise tourists who are walking around with their luggage. 

We got great views of the city and a decent view of the golden gate bridge even though it was foggy. We had a clear direct view of Alcatraz though.
author: Vim I.

description:
Stopped by yesterday and was very impressed with how clean, enjoyable and expansive it is these days.  As many times as I have watched The Bush Man on youtube, he actually got me!   

The ship collection was incredible as always and transportation to and from better than I have ever seen on the public rails.   Totally awesome experience.
author: Greg D.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf is such a tourist trap, but at the same time, it's a fun place to be because there are so many shops, restaurants, things to see, and thing to do. You can go to the aqarium, go out to Alcatraz, watch street performers, go shopping, eat seafood, etc. 

Even though I've done a few of the mentioned above activities, I still like coming here to people watch, eat seafood, and take a walk in the fresh air by the bay. The street performers are pretty neat; there's a really talented artist that uses spray paint to make paintings!

Parking is always difficult to find in SF or it's expensive, so it's nice that Fisherman's Wharf is easily accessible by public transportation. Take the bus and you can walk through Fisherman's Wharf and even to other piers. You can also take the cable cars and the stop is only a couple blocks away.
author: Katherine S.

description: The sea lions at Pier 39 are cool but I have to say this place is WAY too touristy for my liking.  One of the things I like most about San Francisco is its unique character but at Fisherman's Wharf you start to feel like you're in Disney.  I  also wouldn't recommend eating here as there were mostly chains you can find anywhere or restaurants that have tourist trap written all over them.
author: Julia D.

description: Very touristy! But what do you expect. I would much more recommend pier 39 instead but very cheap very good food.
author: Casey W.

description: Honestly, Just come here once to say you have been here and don't come back. My dad and I were on vacation and we were just exploring and ended up in Fisherman's Wharf and it is one of the scariest places to be in my opinion. My dad lived here for many years before moving to Los Angeles and was depressed to see this area go down the drain. There are so many homeless people asking for money and getting into fights over their "turf", the food carts are really shady, parking is ridiculous, and the area is commercialized. If you do want to come down here, be very aware of your surroundings.
author: Elizabeth S.

description: So many places to see, so many interesting shops, and so much good food! If it's your first time in SF, Fishermans Wharf is definitely a must-go! My boyfriend and I came here one time and a couple hours wasn't enough! We recently visited again and it was a blast going to all the unique shops and exploring all the food they have. Also, the Ghirardelli Factory is within walking distance!
author: Hana B.

description: Loved it definitely different from any pier I've been to, Chicago or California. Pretty nice loved the atmosphere and that there are so many little shops things to do and performances
author: Jewels V.

description: I came to visit this place because it was highly recommended when visiting San Francisco. I also pictured it to be a lot bigger. For it being an outdoor seafood type of place, it was very clean. From a certain area, you can view Alcatraz. They have a lot of shops across the street from the Wharf that sell souvenirs, etc.
author: Jojo G.

description:
What can I say, about this places that hasn't already been said?
Tourist attractions around the world have alot to compete with....
Be it the restaurants, the shoppes, the people, or the sea-side.

Kill yourself right now, if you haven't been...
Unless this is on your Bucket-list, visit then kill yourself later.
author: Michael R.

description: This is a mega tourist attraction. I dont understand why anyone would have anything bad to say. If youre a tourist, go here! Have fun getting ice cream, and watching the sea lions.. take a stroll down a bit further to get one of the best lobster rolls around! the clam chowder is outstanding, and the views are great!
author: Dalia G.

description:
This place is gross and it smells like stale lady parts and reaks of chain restaurants and poor examples of badly executed notions of Americana. 

When I think of my city and where to avoid, this tourist trap is basically at the top of my list.

Also, one time I took a friend visiting here and against my advice, he ordered a street crab sandwich. He was legitimately sweating and pooping all day. Like, I was competing with every toilet in sf for his attention.
