Half a star for the seals at Pier 39, because they are fun to watch when you are stoned. Other half of my forced star goes to the view out on the water, I guess it is pretty... But there are plenty of places that have pretty views in SF, so... Suck it, fisherman's wharf.

In sum - don't go here if you hate cliches, and don't eat here unless you like sweating and pooping without restraint.
author: Valerie H.

description: A tourist trap, but fun. If I'm visiting with the kids, I'll bring them; they enjoy the spectacle.
author: Derek F.

description:
All the souvenir shops are located in Fisherman's Wharf.

Other than that, there's not much else other than seafood restaurants.
author: Vira P.

description: Nothing so special about the wharf here in San Francisco. Typical restaurants I've seen across the country and other boardwalks. More than half of them don't even serve fresh local seafood. Save time is fine local favorites within the city to do actually serve fresh local seafood, it's worth it.
author: Abdul W.

description: This place is always hustling and bustling, its the epicenter for San Francisco also known as a tourist trap.  I love the wharf, don't get me wrong but some of the restaurants are not that great and is clearly over price.  I prefer to eat at the little street stands as opposed to the restaurants.  Lots to do on the pier, you can do tours and take the ferry.  I just think its picturesque and pretty, definitely a sight to see.  I tend to rollerblade and run along the pier now that I've been living her for almost a year.
author: Angela V.

description: I had to take stars off because most of the food is overpriced except for Boudins. The food here is not okay because you get less for a lot of money. Most of the time I left this are with an empty stomach if I chose to save money. Lucky for me I am not that type of food person. Other than the food it is A okay because there are plenty of fun activities for you to do.  Even if you have nothing to to there are always entertainers and seals to make you happy.  If you are on the go there are many tours you can take here. As always take the public transport here.
author: Michael W.

description:
Fishermans Wharf is definitely one of San Fransiscos main tourist attractions. 
Tons of shops that suck us tourists in to shop, shop, shop till we drop. 
And really yummy eats as well. 

It can get really chilly here so layer up! 
People complain about parking but I found free parking a block away!
You just have to be willing to walk and anything is possible.
author: Jackie R.

description:
A trip to San Francisco is not complete without visiting the Wharf. On our trip here, we first went to Alcatraz, and then took a short stroll to the wharf. Beautiful sunshine, coupled with a light breeze made for the perfect day. 

Lots of touristy shops selling postcards, and San Fran memorabilia. There's also the bread factory, and also lots of stalls selling fresh food. We had clam chowder in the sourdough bowl, and shrimp salad roll.

A great place to spend some time, and soak in the whole atmosphere!
author: Vincci L.

description:
It's a tourist trap...but one I don't mind getting trapped at. If you want souvenirs of a trip to San Francisco you'll find lots of things to choose from here. Take some time and walk around and explore. Did you see the sea lions? Definitely recommend taking the time to find them...and bring your camera when you do. 

I had the good fortune of standing at the end of Fisherman's Wharf and watching the sun set behind the Golden Gate Bridge. It's another one of those things that if you ever experience it you'll never forget it. 

Travel tip: I never drive myself in San Francisco. I hail a cab or I use Uber. Unlike some reviewers I've never had problems catching a cab from Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Shawn J.

description:
A definite tourist spot. Take a cab/bus/trolley here or else finding parking is either impossible or expensive!

Plenty of restaurants, plenty of bars, plenty of souvenir shops. 

You can't come to San Fran without stopping here and the seafood is super fresh!
author: Harlow H.

description: Yes its crowded but a lovely walk and a great way to see some sites. Seeing the ships and the views is pretty great. This is my view of just wandering through the area - I review restaurants on their own and most of the offerings here are chains and such anymore.
author: Mikhail H.

description: Fisherman's Warf is one of those classic san Francisco places you must visit. I do not eat any sea food but my mom does and she said everything tasted great! It was clean and not super busy that day so that was a plus!
author: LeeAnne B.

description: I really like coming here. Definitely a must come if you are visiting SF. I like walking around the pier, watching the street performers and buying food at the food stands.I love clam chowder and obviously they sell good ones here. Be sure to get the bread bowl definitely better than the cups! But watch out for stupid seagulls they might wanna steal your food. I've also tried raw clams and oysters, fried calamari, and squid salads from multiple stands. They are decent, but I would stick with the chowder. Also make sure to check out Pier 39 and Ghirardelli square. Tons of restaurants and shops to choose from!
author: Juan F.

description:
Love the idea of this place, you feel like eating, boom there is food, you feel like a much needed walk after eating a bunch of stuff, boom there is lots to walk, feel like seeing ships, boom you have ships, feel like a tour, boom you have many to choose from.

Places is great to visit each and every time you are in San Francisco, you have lots to cover people, you will not be disappointed in the choices and feel of it.
author: Sal M.

description: Fisherman's Warf is a fun touristy place to go.  That is, if you've never been there before.  There are a lot of little shops selling souvenirs and food.  I'm trying to think how to best describe Fisherman's Warf and I'm having some difficulty.  I suppose the main attraction is the seafood.  I've only been here two times and I think that's enough for me :-)
author: Vince M.

description: Took my kid and 4 of her 16 y.o. buddies w/ the g.f. to see S.F. and  the "wharf" one day last Easter break. This is what America has come to. It's all there. A gov't developed tax enhancement center disguised as a point of significant cultural and/or historic interest.  These public types that chair the committees developing these places all go to the same conventions and same workshops. Go to any "cultural point of interest" anywhere in the U.S. and they are identical. Right down to the doorknobs on the filthy restrooms. Like a big box shopping center only with dirty restrooms. Junky overpriced restaurants, cultural diversity as in homeless types peeing everywhere, dirty disgusting restrooms if you can find one, interesting exhibits as in identical junk made in China any place you look. It's the stuff rejected by Walmart. And a few pictures that weren't censored of times gone by, portraying the beginnings of our new-found "social enlightenment" as envisioned by the tax enhancement groups. Supposedly taken at the place you're visiting but I'm no longer convinced. A huge void. Culturally and historically especially. Lots better off to go camping in any Walmart parking lot. More of the culture to see, more to look at, and better food- all lots cheaper.
author: Matt P.

description: Touristy but still fun.  Lots of novelty stores, shopping, some entertainment, and of course lots of places for food.  Watching the sea lions seems so mesmerizing.
author: Jason G.

description: Cool place to visit! But its really a lot of tourist here. You would better to leave you care in 2-3 blocks, coz its always problem with parking. Watch my video aout Warf https://youtu.be/cfvpyNe7-E4
author: Yuriy P.

description: Fisherman's Wharf is only for tourists or the occassional local jogger. It's worth a visit, to get there hop on the classic F tram for $2.25 (need exact change) and go for a wander around. Plenty there to see and do. Highly recommend an In n Out burger for lunch - but expect to wait!
author: Chris K.

description: This place is ok to come to. It has a nice view of the water and of Alcatraz (this is where you go to go see Alcatraz). There is an aquarium and lots of vendors and food. The coolest part about it is there are sea lions that just chill on the dock. Other than that, it's just a nice place to go for a little bit once in a while.
author: Shin M.

description:
I love Fisherman's Wharf. I've been coming here since I was a kid. I love that you could buy fresh crab from sidewalk vendors. It is so good! There is always something to see. My husband and I love to watch the street performers and sometimes just sit and people watch. San Francisco has such a diverse and sometimes strangely comical people group. It's always entertaining that is for sure. 

There are also so many shops and restaurants. The food is amazing and there is so much to choose from, but it is not cheap! So be prepared to spend some dough! And I'm not talking sour dough (which is also yummy here) lol! 

Parking is very expensive, $9-$10 per hour. Some lots have a maximum day fee some lots just keep charging for every hour. We found a lot by Joe's Crab Shack that charged by the 1/2 hour with a max. rate of $32. We were there for several hours so that ended up being the best deal for us. 

If you do come out to visit, you have to save room (and money) to try the chowder in a sour dough bowl. They are amazing and there is just something about eating this soup outside by the bay. Such a perfect atmosphere for a hot bowl of chowder.
author: Christina R.

description: Mostly a tourist trap but one of those places you have to check out as a first-time visitor to San Francisco. The shops have tacky, expensive gifts and the food is overcharged but it's good. Check out Boudin Bakery and it's breads shaped like different animals, but get your chowder in a breadbowl somewhere else to beat the lines and the hiked price. The Museé Méchanique has a huge collection of interesting old-time arcade games dating back to the turn of the 20th Century. The seals out on Pier 39 are fun to see but (I feel) overrated. Overall, check out Fisherman's Wharf when visiting San Francisco, and you'll see why the locals avoid it like the plague.
author: Matt P.

description: *My fiancé and I were taking a day in San Francisco. I just LooooooooooooVe how peaceful the water is. We bought some clam chowder and crab sandwich from the stands and walked to behind the Franciscan Crab Restaurant to eat by the water. Amazing view of the Alcatraz! There is a fence that has love locks and it was neat to see :-) We shall Definitely come back to add a Love Lock of our own. Afterwards, we were bird feeding which was fun. The seagulls get really really close just for a piece of bread. Quite a few birds were surrounding us. It was fun. If you like to try to new things and just go with the flow, take a stroll on the Fisherman's Wharf. It's a tourist thing but it's also very fun and neat.
author: Karina R.

description: If you need tips on how to plan and save money during your trip-check out buistyles.com/travel
author: BuiStyles ..

description: I enjoyed my time there, street performers, shops and food.
author: Tiffanie C.

description: I've lived in the Bay practically my whole life but every time I come to Fisherman's wharf, I always feel like such a tourist. I don't mind though because no matter how many times I come, it's still always exciting to see the sea lions, look at souviners, and decide where I'm going to get my clam chowder bowls. There's also great photo spots all around so if you come when it's not raining, you're in for a treat! Sure it's a tourist trap, but you have to admit, that's where all the fun is!
author: Stella Y.

description:
This place was great to wander around and look in all the different shops, eateries. Definitely for tourists but bathrooms were clean and who knows what you'd find there. I mean where else are you going to find a shop all about socks?
Loved seeing the Sea Lions. They are lazy and funny.
author: Christina V.

description:
My boyfriend moved in with me to the area without having ever been to San Francisco.  I'm the opposite of a hipster; I've liked Fisherman's Wharf ever since it became inflatedly and touristically extremely popular.

We wanted the classic San Franciscan tourist experience to celebrate the move-in, and this is the place to do it.  We got there by happy accidents with public transit from the CalTrain, walked all the tacky shops, visited the Maritime National Historic Park, got some Christmas shopping done at Ghirardelli Square, lounged on a bench in the sunshine while seeing the Golden Gate Bridge (for him, for the first time).

We battled the rules and regulations governing public versus private bathrooms along the Wharf.

Listen, we really like water. We're anthropologists, we like people-watching.  We like chocolate and I like seafood.  No complaints here, except maybe about people coming to Fisherman's Wharf expecting anything but a totally touristy experience.
author: Allison M.

description:
The wharf is about as touristy as you can get, but it's still a fun place to be and  IMO the best way to enjoy it is on foot.  Leave the car at home.  It is a nice stroll with nice views, but I would avoid the very high-priced restaurants there and expensive trinket shops.

And I would avoid Aliotos 8 unless you like snooty waiters, SMALL portions, and overpriced dishes.
author: David S.

description:
I liked it; however having lived in Seattle for years; I think the area around the Seattle piers definitely beat the San Fran one haha
The sea lions are pretty awesome though. I reaaally had no idea what to expect but I was surprised at the number of them chilling there in the sun :D
author: Dominique F.

description: Lots of people,  fresh air ..sunshine   Trollers .  Great way to spend a day people watching AND eating...the food is great and the people are from EVERyWhERE!!  excellent tourist trap!  So glad we enjoyed it! I will certainly return as it is just plain fun!
author: Pamela B.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco is an Eldorado of restuarants, shops selling tourist trinkets and beautiful seashells, Italian stands where you can have a crab cooked to order, or eat a lobster or a dozen oysters, all with sourdough French bread. On the sidewalks, blacks and hippies improvise concerts, against the background of a forest of sailboats on one of the world's loveliest bays, which surrounds the island of Alcatraz.  

Umberto Eco 1986.

Little has changed...
author: D M.

description:
Want to know where all the Tourists are in SF? Look no further than Golden Gate, Lombard, Academy of Sciences, and of course Fisherman's warf... 

It's Ok. You walk around for a bit and notice the old SF charm. It kind reminds me of an older version of the Santa Monica Pier. 

* Seafood restaurants, shops, street performers, and clean air. A first timer's and first time tourist to SF's must see place! Go Go go!
author: Justin Y.

description:
A seagull crapped on me. =( 

I guess it's karma for "acting like a tourist" at Fisherman's Wharf. I can't help it! if you are visiting a city you rarely go to what else are you gonna be?! You just ARE a tourist... you're gonna take pictures of things, wandering around holding a map and annoy people by asking for directions when lost. Then when you get to your destination block pedestrian traffic by staring at landmarks mouth agape.

All you SF peeps making fun of tourists, when you come down to LA and I'm reincarnated into a pigeon (no seagulls in LA) I make sure to give you a welcome poop as you stare at the Hollywood sign.
author: Karen C.

description:
What a tourist trap but fun nonetheless! On a beautiful day, it's a great spot to visit, walk around, peruse street vendors, see the seals, and grab a clam chowder bowl. 

And if the "bushman" is there, you'll be in for a good laugh =)
author: Denise H.

description:
As a kid, when my pops would take us here, I was always kinda iffy on this place called Fisherman's Wharf:

- sea gulls (lots of them...I was petrified)
- why does it smell like sewer? (dad says that is the smell of the ocean...gawd)
- dad, why is that long-haired man talking to himself? (son, that's what hobos do)

Fast-forward to today:  It's really not a bad place.

You can get fresh and LIVE dungeness crab from the side-wharf-vendors when it is in-season. That alone is worth the trip, and I must say is a big-time SCORE.

Some of the restaurants aren't bad neither. We never had a bad meal at Scoma's.
author: Derek N.

description:
This is very fun place for me like an entertainment park with free entrance with ocean view! 
A lot of things going on, stores, gift shops, little farmer's market, restaurants, an aquarium...and open until later than many of other touristy places. It was great to visit here for my last night in San Francisco.
The gift shops are well stocked with variety but they are more for personal memory items.

Lively atmosphere and everyone is happy as long as the weather is good.
I was looking for a souvenir to my company that maybe like box of chocolate or baked snacks that multiple people can share, but it was not easy to find here.
author: Blue G.

description: Number one tourist spot in SF, or close to it. We took the cable cars to it and walked thru to pick up our tour to Alcatraz. The restaurants were all packed. After reading Yelp reviews, we didn't opt to eat in any of them.
author: Ken J.

description: This place is amazing! So many people from different places! I went around July 4th weekend so many small kiosk set up, with different cool stuff! Def a must for a tourist!
author: Jay S.

description: Stinky fun so much to do here you eat, eat, and eat. This place has unique businesses. Bring cash as there is a lot self- employed talented artist on the sidewalks. Bring good walking shoes!! I enjoy this place every time I come. Depending on the season bring a sweater and umbrella even in the summer!!
author: Denise R.

description: Since I visited on  a weekday afternoon it was not too crowded. We watched the sun set with Alcatraz in the background. Wow the pix turned out great. It was a beautiful day. If you like Sea Lions make sure to walk over to Pier 39.
author: Richard L.

description:
Instant respect, to Yelp's display writers and niche marketing. You guys won!

I've posted a rave review of Fog Harbor House on your site -- premium content for free -- and the resto sits on the second floor of Pier 39.

Here is a data-point that would make Yelp co-founder Stoppleman . . . stop:

- in the universe of commercial real estate, Pier 39 is classified as a "mall"
- Pier 39 is the 8th-most trafficked mall in America

It has bleachers where tourists watch wild sea creatures!

Here is the dirty secret: San Francisco locals never walk north of Bay Street from Telegraph Hill, North Beach or Russian Hill.

Unless, of course, they're going to Gary Danko :)

But most of them do not know how Fisherman's Wharf is cool.

Here is how the Wharf is cool:

You get people who worked for 50 effing weeks just to spend one week of their year at a Fisherman's Wharf hotel like the Holiday Inn, Radisson, Comfort Inn -- or if they go for the gusto, the Argonaut.

You get street kids on Molly.

You get performance artists. 

You get foodies who lost their way and wandered into Fisherman's Wharf :)

What you don't get: A casting call for a Hollywood movie.

And THAT's why I love Fisherman's Wharf !

It is a perfect confluence of America in liberal latte-loving SF.

It's why the rest of San Francisco looks down on Fisherman's Wharf: It's the one enclave of this European high-tech, eco-city where the mainstream of America can find a home. 

(Come on down Hard Rock Cafe and nachos :)
author: Paul A.

description: Seafood seafood seafood! I was in heaven! There are seafood restaurants everywhere. Take your pick and go in for some clam chowder! I love this area of SF!
author: Jena D.

description:
What's not to like - eat outside -- it's the heart of SF -- you gotta go if you have never been.  It has changed - very commercial now. 

****  Be aware - the sour dough restaurant has an oyster HH -- GREAT DEAL!!!
author: Scott T.

description: Got a whole crab at one of the many fresh seafood booths. Go to the Chinese one! Cheaper and very fresh. You can find a seat if you're lucky in their store right behind their counter.
author: Jasmin I.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf is actually worse than Pier 39, simply because of the smell. It smells fishy and looks dirty. 

There's not a whole lot that a local would want to see (read: nothing) and it is a place filled with "Buy 9 t-shirts for $10" type stores. They have tons of stores selling lewd, ivory figurines of people (and sometimes with an animal... *barf*) engaging in sexual acts. I'm not even sure how they can sell ivory these days but whatever. Gross. What else? There is a big store that sells disposable cameras and batteries. There's also overpriced restaurants and a few stalls selling seafood. I doubt any San Franciscans shop there.

AVOID.
author: Rachel S.

description:
OK being completely honest, I wasn't the biggest fan of Fisherman's Wharf. Sure its quite a pretty area to catch what little sun SF gets, to people watch etc etc, but it just reminded me of the GC but not as intense. The sea lions ?? Apart from being obscenely offensive to the nose, they're just a bunch of moaners and groaners with a few biffs thrown in for good measure. 

I'm not completely writing this off cause Pier 39 was surprisingly fun and they had a hellava fruit store to boot .. seriously, biggest. cherries. ever !!! PLUS, a whole store dedicated to .. wait for it .. MAGNETS!! And who doesn't love a good magnet? Talk about killing 15 birds with 1 stone - gift shopping DONE.

Taylor St though was a bit of a let down - it looked great on the outset, what with all those take out seafood eateries, I was looking forward to grabbing some seafood to go, sit down at one of the piers and enjoy the food but it was all pretty much the same across these canteens - clam chowder, dungeness crabs, mammoth rolls, fried EVERYTHING, ton of oil, salt and mayo - where's the clean fresh seafood? Clearly not in the high traffic tourist spots. Shame.
author: Maria N.

description: Fisherman wharf is a chill spot to sit at the benches in the back and chill out. Watch the bay bridge and ships sail. Inside the building, there are quaint little shops where you can sample and purchase tons of artisan meat, cheese, bread, sweets and more. There is this FANTASTIC sweets places called Milles? But they have AMAZING caramel.I walked a mile there to get some caramel and yes... it was worth it lol
author: Esther L.

description: As much as I don't want to admit it, I do see the appeal of this place to residents and visitors alike. I've been four times now, and each time has been enjoyable. Sure, the shops are the same, the sea lions will always be there, and the food will always be expensive. But the great views of the Bay and feeling of being in an old sea town? Not too shabby. Parking is non-existent (lots only or park miles away on the street), so take the cable car or walk...if it's nice out, you can walk from there to North Beach, and it's not too bad at all.
author: Dan M.

description: Overrun with tourists and tacky souvenir shops, Fisherman's Wharf reminded me of a west coast Myrtle Beach. Sure, some of the restaurants serve some terrific seafood, and I suppose no trip to San Fran would be complete without a visit here, but the city's most charming spots definitely lie elsewhere.
author: Joe P.

description:
I was visiting from Chicago and everyone said to check this place out. We came and got some food. I don't like seafood but my boyfriend does. He was not a fan of the food we tried at Fisherman's Wharf (we went to two different places).

Overall, this place is crowded and full of people throwing foods to the birds and getting together in groups to cause sidewalk traffic jams.

The only saving grace while I was here was the antique video game arcade. I could have spent several more hours there but I only had so much money to spend before I had to remove myself.

I feel like this place was fun to visit but nothing spectacular. Maybe it's because I only had a day or two to explore San Fran, but I'd skip the Wharf on my next trip here.
author: Colleen B.

description:
The wharf is much cleaner than I've experienced on previous visits.
I brought 48 high school students who had a fabulous time (except for  five of them who got food poisoning at RAVS Ravioli shop- I don't recommend).
Very nice shopping after a long day of checking out local universities. Everyone's last minute gifts got bought, and that was perfect.
Even though it was late, there was still a street performer out and Ghiradelli hot chocolates rocked!
author: Brian A.

description: Criminals, lie about parking rates. Food sucks and over priced. This part of the city is such a scam.  San francisco has much more to offer, do no spend any money here you will feel empty feeling after being ripped off!!!!!!!!
author: Leo r.

description: Another one of those "I've been here to many times to count" places. Go for the sea food & great for people watching. Yes, there's plenty of cheezy tourist crap shack's & the parking may be a bit steep (I don't remember it being over $50, but it MAY have been awhile), but it's still worth at least a day of one's time to visit.
author: Ed S.

description: Been working in the area for 6 years I've seen alot of things come and go and parking spaces turned to meter or red zone.  Parking easy if u no where yo look.  I am running out of places for lunch and have been here for 6 years that's y only 4 stars lol.  During 4th of July New Years and fleet week either get here early or dnt drive trust me it gets worse than ny down here minus the ninja turtles as cool as it would b to meet them lol I no I'm cheating checking in everytime I work but it still fun to c how many I can get
author: Nick M.

description:
A must visit for anyone to truly enjoy and experience the San Francisco culture! Sure, that's a mighty statement, but still... sourdough bread bowls!!! (Filled with clam chowder or chili... our pick of poison). 

Come check out the sea otters and get an awesome shot of Alcatraz, (new) and old Bay Bridge, and the Golden Gate Bridge. 

There's always something going on here and right now is the America's Cup!
author: Charles K.

description: I'm sure at some point in time Fisherman's Wharf was THE place to go in SF. Growing up near Niagara Falls it has the same allure as Clifton Hill, a beautiful place that is overrun with gimmicky attractions and chain restaurants. That being said, it's worth checking out at least once. It's near the end of your stroll along Embarcadero anyways. Lots of cool street acts to check out and about thirty million tourists hanging out. Lots of overpriced restaurants to check out and a pretty sweet aquarium by the looks of it. You can pretty much do it all from here whether it's seeing the Sea Lions sunbathe or catching a duck tour.
author: Joshua C.

description: One of the nicest places to visit in SF you could always come here watch some shows or just do some shopping or even walk to the pier 39 or just enjoy the beautiful city  I would recommend this place to anyone going to sf
author: Johnson Y.

description:
You can't stop by here and NOT try a crab. $44.00 (I think) and worth every penny. 

I also had a salad, as did my daughter.

A San Francisco staple for sure!

Go for it!
author: Scott S.

description:
I have been to the Fisherman's Wharf a number of times and I absolutely love it!

The cons -
SO many tourists all year long - nonstop.
It rains most of the time so be prepared.

The pros -
Pier 39 located right next to it, which is THE touristy spot for shopping, dining, and entertainment.
Chowder and shrimp sandwich (and of course other seafood) are absolutely delicious!!! (Right next to the sign of the Fisherman's Wharf, you will see a number of street food stand selling chowder and stuff, they are all the same prices and I would recommend you walk just a bit further and find a less crowded street food stand area that offers seats.)
There are lots of small shops you can buy gifts and stuff - also there are lots of "regular" restaurants like McDonald's, In-n-Out burger place, etc.
author: Maria G.

description:
This is a nice place to visit. There are a lot of shops at the Wharf for you to buy hats and other gifts to bring home to your friends and family. There are a lot of unusual sightings there, such as the tin man. You have to give him tip to take a picture of him, or else he'll scare you...
There's a couple of places to eat around there as well. I always go to the In-n-Out there, because my family are In-n-Out fanatics.
You can see Alcatraz from the Wharf as well as other boats and odd looking ships. You can also see Pier 39 from there as well, I think there are seals there too.
If you like taking the cable cars, it always leads you to the wharf :)
author: Cathy M.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf is a tourist trap.  It seems very comfortable with that identity and plays the role well.

I was a tourist.  Being comfortable with my identity, I went ahead and got trapped there.

Had some clam chowder and sourdough.  Took pictures of sea lions and old prisons.  Wandered through shops and generally had a lovely afternoon.

There were a few too many chains for my tastes.  And there seemed to be about 97 little shops selling souvenirs from places I wasn't visiting.  I don't need Hawaiian jewelry and Celtic trivets.  I'm in SAN-FRAN-CIS-CO.  I'll buy that shit when I visit those other places.
author: Sarah W.

description: I was here in '08 with my son and I'm dying to go back!  Being a Native NYer I didn't think I could possibly fall in love with any other place, but I was won over with this one!  The food, the shops and the atmosphere was awesome.  I'm looking forward to visiting again SOON!
author: Violet R.

description:
A HAIKU REVIEW

A tourist icon
Shops, food, and entertainment
"Arrrrhhh!" says sea lion.
author: Jonathan S.

description: how can you go wrong with the fishermans wharf!  so many places to shop and venture around. awesome seafood shacks to grab some crab lobster etc.  few street performers but not as many as hollywood.   not as many bums either!
author: Greg Z.

description:
The Wharf is a must do while in San Fran for a few reasons. 

   1. The sea lions!  Did you know a male sea lion can grow up to 800 lbs?! Although they are loud (picture a massive dog bark), and a little stinky, they are definitely a sight to see!  Also, on the same pier 39, you can see Alcatraz very clearly.  Great place for a photo opp. 

  2. The chowder!  Who doesn't like a good clam chowder served in a delicious sourdough bowl. No one, I know. The Wharf offers many restaurants, from casual to elegant, where you can "get your seafood dine on."  

 3. The aquarium! Even though I live in LA, I don't spend a lot of time in the ocean, checking out the wildlife.  As such, I love going to the aquarium.  The aquarium on the Wharf is great, not too big and fill of fun sea life. 

Final note- make sure you take a coat if it is cloudy.  Near the water gets really chilly!  This is also a major tourist spot, so maybe plan your visit on off hours to avoid the massive rush.  If Pier 39 is too crowded, head in either direction and you will run into additional piers, all equipped with restaurants and shops.
author: Taylor W.

description: Very touristy as you can tell by the numerous souvenir shops with cheesey tourist shirts.
author: Gavin M.

description:
There were tons of people walking around and plenty of shops as well.

Not much to say here!
author: Scott N.

description:
I just love going to he Fishermans Warf. I must say the steamed crab did not taste as fresh as I was hoping but if definitely hit the spot! I love the clam chowder in a yummy sour dough bread ! 

Just love the SF atmosphere.
author: Danielle A.

description:
Loved watching the sealoins. I could have stood there for hours. 

I didnt go into one single shop. WAYYYY to many people!
author: Kirstin E.

description: This is definitely a tourist trap. The restaurants aren't great and there aren't many sights. But the views of the ocean from here are great.
author: M B.

description: The Times Square of San Francisco. Take a nice, quick stroll, and then continue on to less chaotic sites. T-shirt shops and street peddlers galore. The clam chowder is okay.
author: C. D.

description: So. Touristy. I'm a tourist  and it was even too touristy for me. It's a must see if you've never been but the shops and restaurants are all tourist traps. All I needed was to spend 20 min there and I was good to leave
author: Lauren M.

description:
When my out-of-town guest always want to go to Fisherman's Wharf, I cringe and the thought of all the schlock and the "milk the tourist" vibe and pricing and parking. Then I suggest going to Alcatraz (from the Ferry Building direction), Muir Woods, or another waterfront experience in Sausalito or Tiburon. And where exactly are all the Fisherman here? I don't think they could afford the tourist-fueled rent.

Yet, some Kid in the out-of-town family insists on seeing Ripley's Believe it or Not! or some other must see feature. Oy. 

Lemons - Lemonade. So while I'm here, there is an IN N' Out Burger for Lunch, the nearby Buena Vista for Irish Coffee, and maybe a ride up to Lombard on the Cable Car.  I can also hang outside of Pier 39 and watch the Sea Lions, or wander around Ghirardelli and end up with some decent ice cream. Then there's the old Liberty Ship, the Hyde Street Pier/Aquatic Park, the SS Jeremiah O'Brien and maybe dinner at Alioto's.

OK, if you make me, I can have a good time at Fisherman's Wharf and nearby attractions.
author: Eric B.

description:
I love coming here to shop and eat!  Sometimes my boyfriend and I go here on some of our many travels.  It is a favorite spot of mine.  The shops can be fun to explore even the tourist shops.  I have found a few good deals on sweatshirts and jackets at some of these shops.  But, I have to admit some of the tourist shops are tourist traps as well.  Some of the clerks at these shops can be pushy and aggressive when coaxing customers to purchase merchandise from their store.  I have learned to avoid the stores with the worse aggressive clerks in them.  

Anyhow, there are some unique and fun shops to explore.  I  especially love to shop at Rainforest Cafe (as well as eat there). Nearby is a huge two-story Ross that I absolutely love, it is one of my favorite Ross stores to shop at with a Cost Plus nearby.  Although, my favorite unique shops are in Pier 39 that include a store that sells items for Left handed people (my boyfriend and I are both left handed), an Irish clothing store,  a fairy themed store (although their Mountain t-shirts are over priced), Hard Rock Cafe gift shop (but I also like to eat there as well) and more.  

There are many great places to eat here.  As I mentioned, I like to eat at Rainforest Cafe and Hard Rock Cafe. But there also is Crab Shack and Wipe Out to name a few more.  Someday I hope to eat at the Bubba Gump's restaurant there.  I have been to the Bubba Gump's in Cannery Row and thought it was pretty good, but to be honest not great.  Still, I have heard the view from the restaurant in San Francisco is breathtaking!

There are a few things that I do not like about Fisherman's Wharf.  As I mentioned, there are some aggressive clerks at a few of the shops that try to push customers to purchase items from the store.  I prefer to decide for myself what I want to buy and if I think they are charging too much for a particular item, I will not pay for it.  If they are willing to bargain, I may consider, however.  

Second, there are a lot of homeless people who hang out at the wharf.  Some of them can be aggressive in trying to get money from tourists.  At one time when my boyfriend and I were walking down the wharf, I saw a man who covered himself with a fake tree bush and would jump out of it to scare people who walk by.  Also, you have to watch where you walk or ride a bike as homeless are often sitting and sleeping directly on the sidewalks.  I am sure there are not too many places for homeless to stay in San Francisco and they would prefer for be where most of the tourists are in hopes that there will be some that will be generous to give them money.  

But  it is the aggressive ones that scare me.  I have also read a few months ago, that this is a serious issue.  I am not the only one who does not like to being harassed to give money away, many others who come to San Francisco to shop, eat and explore feel the same way.  I sympathize with the homeless but I want to not have someone aggressively coming up to me asking for money.  Anyhow, I do not travel with much cash especially since it is not safe, wallets and purses can get stolen.  I also prefer to give to charities.  
 
 I have heard that recently there is this unusual homeless man who has been hanging out there who dresses up in an Elmo costume (Elmo is a licensed character of Henson Co. and is used in Sesame Street).  Anyhow, this homeless man swears all the time and is just very negative even with children present.  And, then he still expects people to give him money!

Pros:
-there is so many things to do here - lots of shops, restaurants, museums and attractions

Cons:
-some of the clerks at the tourist shops can be pushy & aggressive
-there are a few tourist traps to avoid 
-many homeless people on the sidewalks and some can be aggressive
-parking can be costly unless you are lucky to find some of the few free parking spots a few blocks up
author: Irene S.

description: Meh it's alright very tourist trappy kinda cool something you can spend a few hours in I guess. Smelly loud seals at the beach, good view of the prison, boat tours and such departs from here.
author: alfred g.

description:
This place is nice.. except it's so crowded.

The food is okay.  There's not much.  Calamari, clam chowder, shrimp sandwiches.

It's nice though.
author: Emily S.

description:
Tourist location for sure. I ate at a lot of places here and took a cruise. I loved the wild life. Most of the shops are nice to browse but I only bought a postcard and some bath salts. Plenty of places to sit too. It was within walking distance from my hotel so I was here a lot. Great place to bring kids too. 

IF I ever come back to San Fran, which I doubt but who knows.... I'd come here with my future children but there is a lot to see in San Fran so I wouldn't spend as much time here as I did.
author: Holly C.

description: DO NOT GO TO MCCORMICK AND KULETOS!!!!  Fishermans wharf is a great place to visit and have a great time, but do not waste your time or money going to this restaurant. Don't bother getting a reservation as your time is of no importance to any of the staff members. Horrible experience and incredibly disappointed this restaurant is essentially stealing money from their customers.
author: Nick L.

description:
Come for the fish, stay for the Bushman.

Don't get me wrong, the reason Fisherman's Wharf gets three stars isn't because of the tourists...jeeze I can handle 60k people in Disneyland I can handle a bunch of out-of-towners trying to watch guys paint with spray cans on the sidewalk.

I guess I just get tired of all the rip-off stuff for sale, how there is a street performer every three feet and how it smells like bodily fluids half the time.

Sooooooo

Things I love about Fisherman's Wharf:

Clam Chowder Bead Bowls
The good polished street acts
The cheap sunglasses
Bubba Gumps at the end of Pier 39
All the random people from around the world

Things I dislike about Fisherman's Wharf:

People who try and scam or guilt tourists out of their money
Those silly little go-carts that use the regular lanes of traffic
Most of Pier 39...it seems like such a ripoff
Parking
Parking
Parking

Tip:  Go in the middle of the week and anytime besides summer.

Now that should be something that everyone does for anything that is a tourist thing but hey...you never know.

Every big city needs a tourist mecca...I guess maybe FW is just one of them.  Maybe all those people should be over supporting the Giants. 

:0)

If you dont know what the Bushman is...keep walking down away from the Bay Bridge and Pier 39 on the right side...you will eventually meet him.
author: Eric N.

description:
Walking on the Wharf is not something I normally do.  If we do come here we usually go eat then immediately go to Jacks Cannery Bar.  One of my all time favorite bars.

On this last trip we walked around quite a bit.

I cant stand the street performers and cant understand all the Ham & Eggers standing around watching them.  They're Carnies!!  I refuse to be sucked in by Carnies!

Also, please walk on the side walk like you would drive on the highway.  Maybe there is a lot of foreigners here that walk on the opposite side but there needs to be some sort of rules established.

My brother and I plus a guy and his grandma almost got ran over by a heard of people not following the rules of the side walk.  Then when I said,"Why is everyone walking this way?!"  

They got scared and got out of my way.  I had to apologize to two strangers because they thought I was yelling at them.  I wasn't I was trying to stop his grandma from being pushed around.

I guess just go try the tourist thing out once in your life.  Or more depending on how much family you have and how old they are.  Its a good kid place.

If you don't have kids with you, just go to Jacks and have a beer.  They have like 63 of them on tap.  Have a Boddingtons for me please.
author: Ivy R.

description:
Super cool atmosphere! Went on a weekend and grabbed fried fish and clams at the outdoor market and ate it on a bench overlooking the water. Up and down the street are tons of great places to eat and and buy souvenirs. 

TIPS:
Take the bus and save on cab fair. Check in on Yelp and get a free discount booklet.
author: Kim J.

description: Tourist, meet trap. It's not the best spot to find original San Francisco flavor, but it is a convenient and centralized spot to catch ferries to attractions, grab a quick bite to eat, pick up souvenirs and watch the sea lions. It's also a great people-watching location. But I wouldn't eat seafood from over here.
author: Zenovia E.

description: A must do if on vacation in San Francisco - well at least the first time :)  We walked around the wharf our first day in town and enjoyed the scenery, people watching, food and drinks.  But it was definitely crowded!  We kept taking breaks and stopping in bars so the alcohol helped.  This was on a Thursday, we went back on Saturday to finish up some souvenir shopping and of course it was even worse - so yes more drinks!  We weren't in a rush and just made our way through the madness but it was nice to walk around and taste the salty air.
author: Bianca A.

description: Tourist trap, some decent seafood restaurants but mostly eateries and shops you can find in your own neighborhood.  Something you might wanna do one time to say you were there but other then that no real reason to return.  One highlight was the fresh fruit stand they had there selling fruit by the pound.  Really refreshing in the midst of all this unhealthy fast food that there is real food available albeit overpriced because of the area.
author: Vinh T.

description:
FISHERMAN'S WHARF
Classic landmark of San Francisco, Fisherman's Wharf offers bundles of seafood, seafood, and more seafood. If you are visiting, you must visit this landmark and experience the vendors hawking crab, clam chowder in a bowl, fried calamari, shrimp cocktails, oysters, etc. In addition to all the tourist shops, your an even see sea lions lounging at the docks! Come and have fun here!
author: Stanley C.

description:
It's worth checking out, but most f the stores are definitely tourist traps. 

The sea lions are definitely the best part and free to see. It's entertaining to just watch them interact and once in a while push other sea lions into the water. 

It's usually pretty packed and they have the standard shops that offer food, souveniers, and other trinkets. 

There are also ppl on corners who sell their shows (robot man, magic shows, etc) and ppl demonstrating their art (carton drawings, spray paint art, etc).

An interesting spot and a must do for an out of towner, but I usually don't end up buying much as most the items are overpriced and definitely geared towards tourists.
author: Suie C.

description: Great touristy location perfect if you're looking for a restaurant or gift shops! I have to say it wasn't too busy for a Sunday I was on Pier 39 where you will notice most of the shops and bars and I also walked. 33 where Alcatraz is. The walk between piers isn't too bad I would recommend wearing walking shoes or you can rent a bike for $9 a day!
author: Alexandra Linette S.

description: Ahhhh, major tourist attraction alert! This place is uber crowded, but I still prefer this side over the pier. First, it's closer to Ghiradelli Square, which is nice!  Secondly, the wharf has a ton of clam chowder stands, which is great if you love to eat like I do.  Thirdly, there are some museums and I noticed that some of them even have free admission! Unfortunately, we didn't get a chance to check these out...but maybe we will next time!!
author: Nancy T.

description: Pretty touristy, but it's not terrible. Want to see some sea lions? Yeah, you can do that. Get some drinks? Done. Great seafood? Absolutely. Clam chowder bowl. Trust me, you'll thank me later. Get frustrated with tourists in front of you? A given. Watch street performers draw things, jump over people, dance like robots in gold/silver paint, get scared by the bushman? You can do all of that! But it will cost you so much money. Still, you can do it here. Oh, and get bay cruises and all that other touristy good stuff.
author: Danny C.

description:
I think Fisherman's Wharf is a tourist trap worth visiting and being "trapped in". There are many worse places to be. 
You won't starve here. Average seafood galore.
You won't easily get bored of the sights.
You also have plenty to do here.
There's random entertainment.

On a clear day, you can see the Golden Gate Bridge and Alcatraz clearly.
There are sealions stinking up the place.

It's an easy place to take people from out of town who have never been before because you have to be able to say you went. People will ask and if you respond no....then that's just odd and wrong.
author: Nick L.

description: Fishermarn's wharf is a great place to visit if you want to eat.  For shopping, it's just souvenier stuff.  typical tshirts, hats, blah blah blah.  Food is hit and miss - read your reviews!!! I've heard there is great crab to be found, but I have yet to find it.  Last place I tried was bleh.  Francisco's is great for view, lousy for food.  Doesn't mean I won't keep trying other places!
author: Linnea E.

description:
I have mix  feelings about the Wharf.   While it is a must do for tourists it's sad that the wharf is so commercialized with all the cheap trinkets stores.   If you want seafood other than crab please don't eat from the crab stands.  It cracks me up when I look at the "beer batter fried fish"  that look like frozen commercial fish sticks.  Yet people have  no idea what their eating and think it was freshly caught lol.  

Walk pass the crab stands to the Arcade museum and make sure you go outside and check out the USS Pompanito and Jeremiah O'brian WWII museum
 ships to get  a real taste of what San Francisco was like during WWII
author: Manny R.

description: I've visited San Francisco twice and have visited Fisherman's Wharf both times. It's a must-see if you have never been to the area.  There is great people watching and views of the water.  Parking is expensive and the traffic is horrendous, so if you're staying in a hotel near the area you would be better off taking a bus or the trolleys.  It's chilly here because of the winds, so dress in layers.  If you think you'll be walking around as the sun sets, bring a thicker jacket or you will definitely be buying one from one of the street vendors!  I still have my fleece from my first trip in late July of 2009!
author: Lisa K.

description: Full of bright colors, lights, piers, ships, fun things to do and see and experience... this place may be a "tourist trap" but it's one I would love to visit again and again.  With plenty of public transportation options, it's easy to get to, and there's so much to see and do for people of all ages.  We enjoyed drinks, shopping, food, games and scenery, as well as some talent.  Lovely spot!
author: Courtney L.

description: With lots of activities going on in and around its a fun place for all ages. Great food and recreations equates to time spent nice. Even if you dint plan ahead of time on what to do you could just  walk by the wharf and enjoy the musicals that happen by the signal and grab a bite. There is no way you could go wrong coming here. Surrounded by museums, shopping centers to explore the wharf gets exciting in every visit of ours.
author: Geetha K.

description: Great tourist attraction with lots of seafood to eat, but if you're like me and from soCAL, it's just like any beach destination like Santa Monica, Venice, or San Diego.
author: Jason F.

description: If you love fried food, huge sweaty crowds, tourist shops and greasy restaurants, this is the place for you.
author: Caroline C.

description: Worst tourist trap in the city. Locals tend to avoid it. Grimy and extremely congested, with $15-$20 parking. Very expensive, bad to mediocre restaurants. Even pricey Scoma's and the snooty Franciscan have gone down hill. We stopped going to both of them years ago. Junky souvenir shops galore. All of the fine artisans found there years ago are gone, boutiques at the Cannery included. Avoid the crooked gray market camera stores and trashy gold jewelry dealers. Ghetto street performers all over the place and unavoidable views of nasty Alcatraz worsen the atmosphere. If all you want is a relaxing Bay view and the weather is decent, take a good brown bag lunch and go to Fort Mason or the Marina Green.
author: Pam J.

description:
I didn't know Yelp existed in the weeks leading up to my San Francisco trip so I was left reading guidebooks that only gave the author's opinion about attractions and restaurants. Thank goodness I discovered Yelp. All the guidebooks warned against going to Fisherman's Wharf, calling it an overrated tourist trap.

I ended up being pleasantly surprised with Fisherman's Wharf. I was staying in the neighborhood and it was a nice place to walk around in the morning before I explored the city. Fisherman's Wharf is overpriced and most of the items and restaurants in this neighborhood didn't seem to be anything special but if you're staying in the area then I suggest you explore the neighborhood a little. I thought the nicest place in Fisherman's Wharf was Pier 39 where you could look at cute sea lions. 

If you're not staying in the area then you might be better off spending precious sightseeing and transportation time going somewhere else in San Francisco unless you're really curious about those sea lions.
author: Laura B.

description:
VERY RUDE on the phone when I was inquiring about reserving a table...he cut me off and said "We don't take reservations..." without allowing me to explain why I might need reservations.  If he was nicer about it, I would have been fine. 

We were planning on spending a  nice anniversary dinner there.  We don't even live in the state.  

Such a disappointment.
author: Judi P.

description: The Fisherman's Wharf is indeed a tourist trap....but that is what makes it so cool! Any time we have people visit, this spot is at the top of our to-do list.  Tons of restaurants, stores for shopping, fun activities, street performers, different museum opportunities, beautiful views, wonderful photo opportunities, the SEA LIONS, and so much more!!!  A great spot with lots to see and do!
author: Kori M.

description: Very dirty, crowded and feels extremely unsafe. Not much to see aside from bums and tourist shops
author: Joshua W.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf - DO IT. Yes - it is a tourist trap.  And YES, it may be overpriced.  But it's so much more if you are able to look passed it's deceptive exterior.

Even if you are not a tourist - it's nearly impossible NOT to appreciate the view and the cute streets and shops that align them.  It was truly breathtaking, looking out towards Alcatraz Island from the top of Ghiradelli Square, where all you see is water between you and the island.  Or just appreciating Ghiradelli Square itself, the architecture and greenery that surrounds it.   Or partaking in a clam chowder bread bowl and a pound of crab.  Everything about it screams San Francisco whether the locals and natives want it to or not.  

We walked. And walked.  And walked.  Through the little coin arcade that reminds me of the carnival scene from the movie Big.  I half expected the fortune teller machine to grant me a wish.  We walked past the ships, the shops, the restaurants.  Yet it never felt as though we were walking - there was so much to see!  Writing this makes me reminisce about how it felt to be there - the cold, brisk ocean breeze, the smell of salt from the water.  The smell of clam chowder and seafood.  It's enough to make me want to book a flight out tomorrow. 

I have been to San Francisco and the wharf numerous times with family and friends. My most recent trip was the most magical experience, vacationing with my fiance, showing him the sights and watching him awestruck by the views.  And even though I had been many a time, it felt like I was experiencing everything for the first time!
author: Kristy K.

description: Neato. There are plenty of little shops selling tchotchkes and other assorted knick-knackery like a Gangnam sweatshirt, which come on, everybody including your mother needs. Great restaurants, fun bars, nightlife, a good walk around the block for people watching. I like this part of the city, they have crab and lots of it.
author: Daniel L.

description: Over crowded tourist trap.  All the shops are extremely expensive, our restaurant experience sucked and you pay a lot for parking.  Gone are the days where you go down to the Fisherman's Wharf and enjoy a fish meal and walk around to enjoy the quaint shops.  Now it is all about money and packing in the most amount of people possible.  It felt like a busy day at Disneyland.  Very disappointed.
author: Elisa P.

description:
A great area of town with some real great highlights.

Enjoy some sourdough or clam chowder. Enjoy the views over the north bay and out to Golden Gate bridge and Alcatraz. 

Take a walk down pier 39 and see the sea-lions and enjoy the shows.

Lots of tourist shops including the great little spy shop and some awesome restaurants.

Parking is extortionate as it is everywhere in central San Fran, make use of the trolly cars and the cable cars it makes the trip extra special.
author: Duncan W.

description:
Ok, so this place might be a tourist trap, but it's still an iconic part of the city and it's fun to walk around if you can navigate around the endless hoards of wide-eyed tourists. All of the shops are geared towards tourism (there are 2 magnet stores that sell a variety of San Francisco-themed magnets - do the world's refrigerators really need that many Golden Gate Bridge magnets?), but they're still amusing to browse. There's an ice cream shop that makes fresh waffle cones that gets me every time. The sickly sweet smell of those freshly made cones calls to me like the song of the sirens, and man are they yummy. There are usually performances going on towards the entrance to the wharf and by the carousel and the surrounding street sidewalks are home to a number of performers who cause pedestrian backups but they're fun to watch.

A good time to be had by all. Just be prepared for crowds. And watch out for the bush man.
author: Emily D.

description:
Fishermans Wharf...something about this place just makes me feel happy. Maybe it is because my family used to come here with relatives and we would always walk around looking at the random things here and there.

I remember back when I was younger they would have the guys breaking crabs with these two sticks. Throwing the sticks in the air like taiko drum sticks and stuff. Really cool. 

Nowadays you just see a guy use a mallet, nothing flashy. The street performers are a sight, and the usual guys that are wearing gas masks spraying beautiful pictures of sunsets and the bridge. My gf and I like to walk around here every once in a while, going down to Pier 39 or Ghiradelli Square. 

Yes this place is very very touristy but its part of home. This place probably reminds me of home so much more than maybe any other part of the city...
author: phillip w.

description:
Cable cars, crabs, seals, sourdough, souvenirs, the list goes on and on! While Fisherman's Wharf may be the place locals dread, it is a place you HAVE to hit at least once when in San Fran. 

I have to admit, for the most part a large portion of the Wharf is just too busy for me, but that doesn't mean I don't like it. It has everything a good tourist needs to get a taste of the city. 

Get some bread, watch a street performer and gaze out at the bay. Its a must!
author: Jessica J.

description:
A must see when you have friends and family in town. As a "local" I never get tired of going down here on weekends and people watching. Just make sure that you realize that nothing is cheap down here.

The best way to get to Fisherman's Warf is either on one of the trains/ buses or take a cab from the Embarcadero BART station. Parking is a pain!
author: Casey S.

description:
Tourist attraction warning. This place is always packed. I mean, you have to be part of the crowd to survive. But it's fun, and a nice place to get the full touristy feel of SF. There are plenty of places to check out. And always a street performer or two to enjoy. I strongly recommend keeping your eyes peeled for the very sexy gymnast family. Three guys, one girl and tons of hotness. 

It's lame but spend two hours here and you won't regret it. Lame can be fun, right!?
author: Tai F.

description:
I'm not quite sure how to review Fisherman's Wharf, I mean, it's Fisherman's Wharf for crying out loud. It's obviously one of those hot spot tourist attractions that you have to visit when visiting San Francisco or catering to visiting guests not from San Fran. If I actually lived here, I don't think I'd go unless, I too, had guests in town... but a standard tourist staple nonetheless.

1. The seals are always awesome to see on the docks, no denying.
2. The Crab House (& their garlic-y dungeness crab goodness) rocks & always will, hands down... OK, maybe I'd revisit as a local for this place  : )
3. The farmer's market (when featured) has some killer produce. The enormous cherries are to die for.
4. High time people watching, always a plus.
5. The Rock's right there so u can snap your ever-required Alcatraz pics... 2 birds,1 stone.
6. Very clean, well-maintained, exceptionally photo worthy collaboration of shops, always appreciated.
7. Huge shopping extravaganza... all your gifts in one place.

Need I say more? The wharf is another touristy 'bucket list' type of place that actually is worth the visit. Like I said, if I was a local, I'd probably go to a) return to a favorite restaurant or b) bring visiting guests, but the place deserves it's cred and is always well worth the $14 parking fees (unless on public transit) and people dodging efforts. Definitely a fan.
author: Jenna H.

description:
As much as I go, "Boooo tourists!" I can't help but love Fisherman's Wharf. I don't fully know why, either. It's definitely not the junk-filled shops. Not the overpriced restaurants. 

In all of my wanderings throughout this city I always end up here at some point (as well as Chinatown and the Palace of Fine Arts). 

It's just one of those places that somehow maintains the spirit of San Francisco. It seduces you with steaming crabs, the bread bowls of hot soup, the street performers, the buskers, the Bush Man, the antique coin-operated machines in the Musee Mechanique, the salty smell of the Bay and the sticky air, the views of the bridges and Alcatraz, foggy walks around boats at the Hyde Street Pier, the vintage street cars rolling by on the MUNI's F line, and the scent of sourdough wafting in the breeze. 

And with all these things in mind, it's still something for which I'm constantly pressured to feel guilty about liking due to Bay Area friends who've sworn off the Embarcadero (which is roughly all of them).    

OK, it can be filthy. And parking is shit, I'll give you that. Don't bother with the structures unless you're willing to pay $20 for a mere couple of hours. Walk or take the MUNI (it's $2 for the historic F car and runs all the way from the Castro, down Market).
author: Christine A.

description: This place is a tourist trap for sure, but I embrace it. I don't see the ocean everyday, and the views here are plentiful. There's lots of cute sea lions laying around at pier 39 for you to gaze at and an abundance of ferry tours you can take. Don't worry about going hungry because there are restaurants and food stands lined up one after another with plenty of fresh seafood.
author: Monica V.

description: Stop #4 was Fisherman Wharf. Its a busy, busy spot with lots of people. There's so much going on. It kind of reminds me of Venice Beach on a pier all crammed into a smaller space than the boardwalk. Many stores, restaurants, bars, etc. to check out and keep yourself busy. Very touristy, but im sure most of the people there are tourists and stuff like fisherman's wharf is fun to experience. definitely a place to check out if in San Fran.
author: Florence L.

description:
I was a tourist & still wasn't impressed by Fisherman's Wharf.  It was just very blah for me.  Not a place to spend a whole day at all.  I was bored after about 2 blocks.

It's very similar to a place in my hometown of Miami (Bayside), so it was pretty much a been there, done that for me.  It's an outdoor collection of not-so-good restaurants and flea-market type souvenir shops.  The Boudoin Bread Company might have been the best thing about it and even that wasn't too exciting.

Actually, the best part about it was the Bushman - having him scare me half to death & watching him scare other people half to death.

Looking out at the bay was nice during the day and haggling at the souvenir shops was fun at night.
author: Amber L.

description: Other than the crowds (I guess I have a mild form of claustrophobia), this place is a pretty nice.
author: Rachell N.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf is such an iconic tourist spot and a MUST stop if you are visiting San Fran, especially if this is your first time. Fisherman's Wharf is such a fun place to go for photos, seafood, walking, people watching (especially all of the bums with the hilarious signs like "need sex, why lie?" and "need beer, why lie?", spray painted people, talented performers all around the streets, etc), shopping and so on. 
Love coming here and acting like a tourist with my camera. 
Yes the parking around here can be a bit expensive, but if you are lucky, maybe you can score the free 3 hour parking that is near Pier 39 (there might be other lots like that around the other piers, but you have to look for it). 
This place is very kid friendly (but the public restrooms aren't all that clean here, so bring your hand sanitizer and disinfectant wipes). 
Hey and you may even be lucky to see elephant seal, sea lions, fish and seagulls. 
The Fisherman's Wharf is just a fun place to be, at least once.
author: Vic C.

description:
Hmm..comparable to the Jersey shore without the fist pumping.
Good views only if your willing to get off the pier and onto a boat.
The only gem here is the Boudin Bakery.  It's the only smell that deters you from the stinky bums and tacky street performers.  The seafood restaurants here are geared towards tourists and are usually overpriced and just so-so food.

If you want to buy some cheap gifts, there are a ton of gift shops along this street to buy.  

Other than that, this is where all the homeless and bad street performers congregate.
author: Sandy C.

description:
This one time (a few days ago), I was at Fisherman's Wharf using a public restroom by the In-N-Out, and I almost died. Ok, it's possible that I'm exaggerating. But seriously, use those bathrooms with caution, especially when they aren't as busy as usual. You have to enter a code to get in, and when I used it, I found myself trapped in there alone with a slightly out of touch from reality/possible schizophrenic individual yelling at me and standing outside my stall facing me. So yeah, this is a good spot to use the buddy system. 

Other than that mildy frightening situation, Fisherman's Wharf is amazing! The smells, the sights--so much to take in! Definitely plan to eat here--the chowder in sourdough bread bowls from any of the multiple stands/restaurants offering them are incredible, and there is seafood aplenty on the cheap. 

The Boudin's offers a little tour/musem, and it's awesome to see the history of the company, and get the scoop on what makes their bread so incredible. OH AND THERE ARE BREAD SAMPLES. Mmmm....Their bread is incredible. BYOB (bring your own butter). Plus, the bakery downstairs is amaaazingggg. I love this place!

Bring your camera, too--great shots of the harbor, historic piers, alcatraz...just gorgeous.
author: Dani J.

description: After walking from Chinatown to Coit tower, we made it to Fisherman's Wharf. There was soo many people, and it was hard to navigate and look at each store while avoiding running into all the people. It was nice to sit on the bench and stare out in the sea... contemplating life and whatnot... HAH nawttt. I liked looking at the sea lions playing on the pier :D so cute.
author: Tricia M.

description:
Fisherman's wharf is super fun...for about an hour.

Pros:

- The Crab House at Pier 39 - AWESOME food
- Chowder's - Authentic clam chowder in a sourdough bread bowl. Do it.
- Delicious salt water taffy
- The seals!

Cons:

- Everything else...but more specifically:
- Tour guides who may or may not be licensed (is there such thing as a tour guide license?) battling each other to try to get you into their boats for a tour of the harbor. Excuse me sir, I do not know you, and I am not getting into your unmarked boat and heading out into open sea. My momma taught me better than that.
- Tourists tourists tourists - everywhere is packed with people trying to haggle down the price of cheap magnets or toy trolley cars
- The dismay of realizing that every shop that you enter has the EXACT same thing...and the thing that you just bought is available four dollars cheaper at the store you are currently in.
- There is seagull shit everywhere.

So go get your chowder and crab, watch the seals, and grab some taffy for the ride home. And then go home. Because spending too long in this tourist trap will make you cranky.
author: Jessica O.

description: Neat collection of touristy places. A must do for anyone's first trip to SF.  Lots of shops and restaurants. It might be more fun to people watch down there than anything. Get a coffee and hang out. If there are no protests going on it might be fun just to watch the nonsense.
author: Bobby S.

description: Touristy and Cheesy.  I cringe when guests want to come here because they just have to see Fisherman's Wharf.  It's a good place to get a crab sand, clam chowder breadbowl, and take pictures.  All of which can be done in an hour so haul a$$ and try not to get caught in the hoards of people who seem to sloth about like zombies.
author: Melissa R.

description:
This neighborhood has many shops with Very Agressive sales tactics or scams! 
I got scammed out of thousands in Firenze Fine Arts. Overpaid 10x - even after their "discount". They lied about real prices & that they selling everything to some whole sale buyer that day. 
 
Also, there are many CAMERA SHOPS with similar scam system.
They lie right into your face & using all possible tactics, even guilt, etc.

TOURISTS BE WARNED!
If you need something for your camera or anything else - shop somewhere else or 
CHECK REAL PRICES ONLINE!
Watch out!

And remember that many shops don't give refunds!
So, you cant get your money back, after you got scammed!
author: Martha C.

description:
Ummm, welcome to Tourist Trap Central.  

This is a check the box part of seeing San Fran.  Come once and then make it a don't come again until someone who has never been.  But you'll have a good time here.  

Lot's of things to see and definitely have to try a Dungeness Crab from one of the crab places.
author: Caesar R.

description: Absolutely a must stop!  Food is really good. I've had quite a few different thing from the menu on a few different occasions and everything was perfect!
author: C J.

description: Loving coming here to the pier and enjoying a clam chowder. Love the smell. The only reason why it's not a 5 is because of the amount of tourists.
author: Nancy L.

description:
It is difficult at best to navigate through the throngs of tourists gawking at the tourist shops and it drives me insane. The shops have approximately nothing worthwhile to offer and everyone keeps gawking at their awfulness and darting in and out of them all willy nilly. I had to come here to take the Alcatraz tour and had to make a serious effort to find a restroom that wasn't demolished. Try the new bathrooms near the In-N-Out or take your chances with the public restrooms located near the giant boat tour departure. The couple of times I went in there the sit down toilets were destroyed but your luck may be better!

There is a beautiful art gallery nearby if you need to take a breath from the insanity outside. The arcade museum is kinda neat but definitely kitschy. My hatred of the unwashed masses pushes this to 2 stars. The art exhibit and the Alcatraz Tour are the only reasons to come here. I've been twice now and I'll never be back again if I can help it. If you are spending too much time here please make sure to get away and experience some of the rest of this great town!
author: Chris L.

description: This is a great spot to visit on a nice day.  Good shops to windowshop and some places to grab some grub.  It can get a bit crowded though.
author: Jimmy M.

description: This is such a beautiful place and I'm so glad I got to experience it.
author: Lauren O.

description:
Good ole' Fisherman's Wharf.

This is THE tourist spot in SF, aside from lombard st that gets crazy on any given day. I will say though that if you ever plan a trip here, make sure you find the surrounding parking lots and NOT the pier 39 'official' parking. It can get expensive if you do not eat here and get your receipt validated. Instead, there are all day parking lots that just charge a flat rate of 20 dollars till 12 am. I also recommend parking here and just traveling by foot/public transportation while here. Parking enforcement is big business here and that will tow/ticket your car all day everyday.

Anyways, I will say that this is a must visit. I highly recommend you walk around this whole area and check out all of the little shops on the pier and if you can, book early in advance and check out Alcatraz Island.
author: Soung S.

description:
Oh how I dream of the days where You couldn't assign stars to anything. Why? Because then I wouldn't feel so bad about giving this area no stars. I am going to start by saying that there are a couple of great places in this hood, however, they are few and far between. Check out my other reviews and you will see what they are. 

Here is my big beef, Fisherman's Wharf as a Whole. Sucks Patootie! and not in a good way. First, I want to give you all considering coming there to stay a piece of advice, if you are looking for a hotel under 100 bucks because you are a cheap skate, well hey, this is not the place for you!

Make sure to bring a credit or debit card, because all of the hotels in this area but one require credit ID for deposits. Why you may ask? in case you decide to throw a tv out the window with one of your wild parties. 

Don't go whining about how expensive everything is because YOU were the one who decided to go there in the first place. And when you pay for bad food that is over prices, well, who's the idiot? certainly not me. 

Couple of places that are decent enough to go.
Fior D Italia. Excellent Italian food, some what pricey, but worth it.

Mamita's Mexican Restaurant. This place is fairly new but its good and very resonable and the amount of food you get is awesome.

Hot Spud.
All they serve are baked potatoes and Salads but I'm going to say, this place is 5 star!!

Where not to go
ANYWHERE ELSE.

Now, a bit more advice. Don't look for a public restroom there are 2 in the neighborhood. one near Fisherman's Grotto, and one near Ghiradelli Square. That's it! oh wait there is one more that keeps odd hours. Don't go into hotels or restaurants asking if you can use theirs as most likely the answer is no. 

There is a half way decent view of Alcatraz from the shore line, but...if you actually want to do Alcatraz, book it before you arrive because it is sold out most of the year.


if you come to San Francisco make sure to get out of the area. I mean seriously folks. Why in the name of all that holy would you want to stay there when there are places in San Francisco that are actually worth going too instead of this waste of time and money.


You don't want to do what I just saw happen. 3 ladies attempted to defecate in a hotel parking lot and each got a 500 fine. per person. that's right. Show some damned respect and hold it!
author: Damien K.

description:
This is yet another childhood favorite of mine- yes, my family and I went here many many times. So many seafood restaurants featuring clam chowder in a sourdough bowl (it's so good), as well as little souvenir shops, and finally, attractions. I remember spending my 14th birthday at Ripley's Believe It Or Not! 

Some notable chain restaurants include the Rainforest Cafe (good food and atmosphere) and Joe's Crab Shack (that sounds funny because there are so many longtime seafood restaurants here, I mean decades). If you eat here, I highly recommend going to Boudin's- there's a guy in the window making sourdough crabs. Not only is there a cafe with minimal seating (you might have to stalk someone for their table), but there's a shop where you can purchase all the sourdough baguettes that your heart desires- oh, the sourdough is the best. (If you miss it, you can still get it at the SFO airport, at the food court.) 

A funny story: On our first trip (my hubby's been here 3x with me), we ate a clam chowder bowl out in the open, and soon lots of birds gathered round- we'd never do that again, what a mistake. It was not too far away from that famous sign- Fisherman's Wharf- that I'm sure if you've ever visited, have taken a picture of/with. C'mon, you know you're guilty. 

We've eaten in this area around 3x- there are so many restaurants serving the clam chowder sourdough bowls. You can also get fried clams and crab legs too. Lots of cart vendors on the sidewalks. 

Also, the new home of the Musee Mechanique- it's all antique machines with a carnival/circus feel featuring one of the two black and white photo booths (this was a frequently visited favorite of mine, especially when it was at the Cliff House- and I have a ton of those booth pics too). 

Don't trust the electronic stores- I've heard this warning since I was a kid. Lots of souvenir shops with San Francisco logo clothing- shop around before you settle on spending some money. There's a suede/leather store with inexpensive jackets. It's been here for a while- at least the last three trips there.  

Lots of street performers here. We saw one Silver guy use a public restroom (where we park- a little shopping center) to take off all his makeup. You will run into crowds. 

You will spend a few hours here. Yes, it's crowded and you will probably run into those clueless people that stop short, stopping foot traffic.
author: Margret C.

description:
Ick.  Can we just cede this thing to San Jose and get it over with already?

Fisherman's Wharf has exactly two redeeming qualities:  The Bush Guy and the sea lions.  The Bush Guy can take his act anywhere, and I'm sure he has, and the sea lions didn't even live here until 1989.  I'm pretty happy that they made so many Marina people angry, and they're very cute, but I miss sea lions on Seal Rocks.

Seriously.  

People of San Jose, we have a very under-utilized and tourist-overrun piece of property to offer you.  You'll get millions of dollars in tax revenue.  All we ask is that you don't refer to this "neighborhood" as a part of San Francisco.  Fisherman's Wharf of San Jose.  It has a nice, honest ring to it, right?
author: John S.

description: Continuing the tour of the Frisco area and if you want a low key day, take a walk along the pier, browse in the stores and stop for a quick bite like we did. Nothing big here, just a way to spend another day in this great city. Cable car ride anyone? Geez, a tourist trap? we are all tourists and there will always be shops to purchase items, restaurants to grab a bite and not everyone will enjoy this area. At least you can enjoy the sights and sounds of being by this  body water and the seals that are close enough to watch. Just a very laid back day here. Key point, there will always be wierdo's where ever you travel so be careful in your travels. As for the sea gulls, it is more their area then ours, give the birds a break.
author: Gloria B.

description: Get fresh seafood from the outdoor stands! I love getting the crab sandwiches & calamari. Street performers are really talented, keep an eye out for the bushman! ;)
author: Tracy C.

description:
When I'm home, I avoid Times Square because I abhor crowds.  No, the irony is not lost on me.  People are slow.   They linger.  They take up way too much space.  And unless you're shopping, there's nothing really going on there with few exceptions.

This is basically San Francisco's Times Square.
author: Chris C.

description:
It's our first holiday season in San Francisco and my mother was in town visiting (who had never been to SF before)...so we thought a trip to Fisherman's Wharf was a must! 

A few highlights...
*Incredible views of the water, bridges and Alcatraz. 
*Great variety of restaurants (casual and fine dining), shops (clothing, candy, souvenir) and even a few museum and other attractions.
*Crepe restaurant...even if you just stop and "window shop" while they make the crepes (savory and sweet)...it's almost magical. 
*Several clean restrooms. 

Note - Parking garage offers 1 hour before 6p and 2 hours after 6p of free parking with a validated ticket. SOME restaurant/attractions will validate. If you don't get your ticket validated...it's about $6/hour, I think. Not too bad.
