Overall...Fisherman's Wharf is a MUST SEE stop to take all visiting friends and family, as well as a fun place to spend the afternoon if you're a local. Regardless...it's always a great place to people watch. :)
author: Dru M.

description:
If you're looking for something super touristy, you've found it.  I actually enjoyed being able to find some gifts while shopping here.  It remind me of most beach towns, with many stores all selling the same things. This would be a fun place to take kids, as there was an arcade and stores geared toward a younger crowd.  You can get a nice, clear look at Alcatraz from here as well.  

The restaurants are a plenty, and it was pretty crowded too.
author: Melissa E.

description: Tourist trap area, but ah.. so many fond memories of when my folks would bring me here.. almost got a crab.. then decided that crab season is in like 2 weeks so I'll just wait for the season to start and the prices to drop. Otherwise, there's a lot of things to see and do in the area.
author: David C.

description: Clam chowder all day errrrday!
author: Danny N.

description:
It smells and there's nothing here unless you want to eat at a touristy seafood restaurant or go to a cruddy souvenir store. Have fun trying to walk around all the strollers and the people that stop in the middle of the sidewalk for no reason.  Worse than Pier 39, and that was pretty bad.

Parking is 4 bucks for every 20 minutes, so make sure you do what you need to do and get out.
author: Nicole W.

description:
We spent a 3 day weekend here recently and I don't think we left the Wharf area at all. Definitely a ton to see and do here!

Tons of crap shops. Need a shot glass, a betty boop tote or a tshirt saying you belong in the psych ward at Alcratraz? You can find them all in any of the 20 shops in a 1 block radius.

Want a nice sit-down dinner or tons of grease on your pizza? You can find that too!

Why not take a Segway tour? There's a couple of places you can go and do that too!
author: Jason J.

description:
Enjoy the views. Great spot to people watch!

This area is nice for tourists to spend some time before a tour of Alcatraz or to just watch the ships and boats go by. It really is a lovely area. There were very little vagrants in the area and it felt safe. This is a great place to keep your kids entertained with all of the different shops. There's even a magic shop in there with live demonstrations.
author: Rosie P.

description: Total tourist trap... But when you're a tourist you have to do it. It's dirty, crowded, and the food is not good. Cheap boardwalk stores and old asian women digging bottles out of trashcans. The seals are cool to see and pier 39 is worth a walk around. Can't imagine driving or parking in this area. Walk there or take a bus/cable car. Also- the food stands.... Avoid avoid avoid. Nothing but mayo and lobster/crab/shrimp mixed and slopped on a roll. Nothing like "fresh lobster" from Maine on the west coast. Yuck.
author: J. M.

description: My favourite place in San Francisco! :) You get to see Golden Gate Bridge and Alcatraz Island, listen to the sea breeze, walk along the pathway, take pictures of the sea lions at Pier 39, street performers singing or dancing, eat seafood and the popular clam chowder sour dough bread. Also, there are shops for you to visit! :) Pretty scenic! :)
author: Jasmine T.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf was fun. Looked like a good place for a family to hang out for the day as there was lots to do. There was a free magic show geared towards kids, and plenty of restaurants and shops to keep you busy. Pier 39 had a space dedicated to sea lions so it was exceptionally fun to watch them basking in the sun and barking at each other. This is a great place to get a variety of tickets to Alcatraz or ferry to the Golden Gate bridge and around Alcatraz. There was some kind of vintage looking train that was cruising up and down the Wharf that could be fun. This was obviously a great place for seafood hence being at a Wharf and other members in my group seemed to enjoy some clam chowder, shrimp pesto pasta, and fish and chips. 

As a vegan it was not too difficult to find an option. While everybody else was chowing on sea critters i was able to enjoy a penne pasta with tomato sauce, veggies, and a superb glass of vino. Fun place, lots of options, and super touristy but that goes without saying. If you're a tourist and want to chow on sea food, tour Alcatraz, or take a ferry under the Golden Gate then this is the place for you.
author: Hollie W.

description: Fisherman's Wharf is one of my favorite places in San Francisco! It has it's own hipster, classy, mysterious culture of it's own. I love just people watching here, as you'll see many interesting characters. It has quite a few good restaurants, cute cafés and bakeries, touristy shops, and tour ticket shacks. Not to mention the piers, which are an obvious breathtaking sight. I love coming here and just walking around, sipping coffee, breathing in the fresh air, enjoying the sights of the water and the boats, and just people watching. The culture is very casual, although there are some definitely fancy restaurants in this area. I'm not sure how many locals make it a point of coming here but quite a few people run up and down the Embarcadero, getting a nice work-out in. Whoever you are, I'm sure you'll find something interesting here!
author: Alyssa L.

description:
great place to walk around.  the good restaurants have an hour wait on a Saturday night but their café versions down below are just as good.  they had a giant Christmas tree in front of the hard rock café but too bad it wasn't lit yet.  Its nice that they have benches everywhere so you can sit and relax if you want to.

the parking structure is convenient but $9.00/hour is crazy.  you can only get validation at the full sit down restaurants not at the cafes.
author: happy b.

description: One of America's wonders of California.  We love it.  Best scenery.  Great food and great weather.  What can you say.  Maravilloso :)
author: Jose P.

description: One of the most lively places to take an evening stroll and also grab some great seafood grub if you are into crabs and clam chowder.
author: Gopi V.

description: How can you not love this place? Obviously its crawling with tourist, but who cares! Its such a great way to spend your day watching the street performers and being harassed by the smile police. Im a tourist myself when i come here so the abundance of people doesnt freak me out, im to busy buying cheap crap and eating seafood to care.
author: Ella A.

description: Great place to spend a few hours on the water front. Lots of shops and restaurants. You can see street performers along the walk through and of course the sea lions at pier 39. Great views of Alcatraz, Golden Gate Bridge and the harbour.
author: A H.

description: This is one of the best spots in all of San Francisco. An absolute must-see if you're in the Bay Area. You can easily navigate it by walking around, there's so many shops and restaurants and stores, and piers, and boats, and sea lions, and you have great views of Alcatraz. There's also Ghirardelli Sq, home of some of the best chocolate in the world. There's a small beach area where you can go swimming. There's also Boudin, home of the world famous sourdough bread. Fisherman's Wharf is just amazing.
author: I G.

description: Must go tourist attraction. Lots of street art music food etc. Tons of restaurants. Great view of Alcatraz. It's worth going.
author: Evan D.

description:
Visiting San Francisco? 
Didnt really invest too much time into making your itinerary?
Fishermans Wharf is the spot for you my friend!
This place is packed with stuff to do and things to look at!
There are even about 50 sea lions (or seals, i can never tell the difference) sitting waiting for you to look at them (in the summer time at least), and thats a guaranteed thing! 

However, if your a frisco native, you know to stay clear of this god forsaken place. Its absolutely THE worst place in frisco when it comes to human traffic. But its always a nice place to go on a sunny day regardless :D
author: angie r.

description: I know everyone loves pier 39...but if not for the seals...I would easily pass. Souvenir shops, t-shirt shops, and fried food.  Probably a must stop with your children, but otherwise it's too much hype.  The waterfront piers have cool spots between ww2 museum and the ferry building one mile away.
author: Robert C.

description: This is a great place for families and friends to get together for site seeing, lots of stores and places to eat and the view is always nice no matter the weather!
author: Christopher Z.

description: I love the wharf.  It was everything more than what I thought it would be.  For so long i thought The Fisherman's Wharf was a restaurant.  It was more like The Jersey Shore.  Best treat aside from the view:  Bubba Gump's Restaurant.  We went twice in a 6 day stint.  I will be back.
author: S T O.

description: The work, but sometimes too getting loaded however I do love definitely I want to talk to the wife out bar and grill it might as well although honestly a little expensive for the quality of food. I say go on a Saturday off early or Sunday early and enjoy the market aspect as well
author: Giulia B.

description:
Ever the tourist trap.  I came here after not stepping food on the wharf for almost 20 years...and it looked the same, smelled the same, and was just as overcrowded as I remembered it.  Here you can get your happy snaps of Alcatraz and the Golden Gate (although it's a bit far away) along with some good but overpriced seafood dishes at the restaurants.

If you're visiting a local, go just once - but then after that, you'll be able to get the same seafood and quality of bread elsewhere.
author: Jake K.

description: A great place to explore... boating, eating, cruising, shopping, strolling around.. just be here and you can easily spend a few hrs, going around enjoying the various things. You may take a day or a sunset cruise that will take you around the Alcatraz island, Golden gate bridge, treasure island. Visit Lou's fish shack for some nice fish n chips or shrimp fritters at the Jefferson street. the weather's fantastic and the place is lovely! Visit is highly recommended.
author: Anindita D.

description: feed the birds!!! Fisherman's Wharf is loads of fun & reminds me of Brighton a bit. Tourists beware of the scams in the area, high prices, and traps. As interesting as the Seafood Bars are its not as if the Vendors are out at sea fishing your Seafood and making fresh chowders out of the Clams they find. The only thing authentic about Fishermans Wharf is quite possibly the bread being baked at Boudin, otherwise this is a great attraction on a cold day but all together should be avoided!
author: Julian I.

description: I expected to see the Gorton's Fisherman reeling in Worf of Star Trek fame.  I saw nothing of the sort.  I did have clam chowder and it was ok.  Then I saw a man walking a llama down the sidewalk.  If I wanted to see that I would have gone to Llama's Promenade not Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Ryan L.

description:
The fishermans Wharf has everything!! theirs restaurants, candy shops,  bakerys, just about anything you can thing of. You can also see Alcatraz from there its so sereal! I had so much fun here!! I totally recomend this to everyone its great for friends, family, even if your on a date! 

Take LOTS of pics! :)
author: Tawny P.

description:
Great views, loads of tourists, plenty of places to shop.  Some of the shops are more touristy than others, but I enjoyed browsing and was tempted by the seafood, chowder and candy shops along the boardwalk.  

The clown-entertainer toward the end of the boardwalk was a big hokey and he wasn't very good at holding the crowd's attention.  The carousel was a beautiful attraction, I've never seen one so big in my life!!!

I would definitely plan to visit again and would bring other visitors as well.
author: Shannon H.

description: I little crowded but the food was amazing, and we had a good time here. The price is ok as well.
author: Jessica L.

description:
YOU NEED TO SEE THE BUSH MAN!!

I was walking along the street from Pier 39 and headed towards Fisherman's Wharf!  I love Fisherman's Wharf!  They have the best restaurants and food but the one thing that was rad was the BUSH GUY!  He was great!  He sits near a trash can behind a bush wall that he holds and as people walk by and aren't paying attention, he yells out and scares then as they walk by!  It's hilarious!  After he scares them, he says, "That scare was worth some money!  So hook it up!"  Hilarious!  I love the Bush Man near Fisherman's Wharf!
author: Hula R.

description:
Looking for things to do before heading to Chinatown, so one of the guys suggested "HEY, let's go to the pier and look for the bush man!" and that's exactly what we did for a few hours.

We quickly found out that metered parking is 365 days a year. So even on a Sunday, we paif $2.50 an hour for metered parking, it was a great place to tour and sight see and as a local, we never really took time to explore our own backyard.

There were ample parking at 10 am and as noon approached, it quickly filled up!

Fisherman's Wharf and Pier 39 were very tourist-y, but it was such a great street to walk down, watch street performers and sea lions. We didn't even buy any souveniors, but we did finally see the famous bush man!
author: Anne T.

description:
The sea lions deserve 5-stars...they were truly the cutest things I'd ever seen.

The endless droves of people who don't know how to walk without stopping for no reason, the seagulls threatening to poop on your head [or eat your clam chowder bread bowl out of your hands -- it happened to my friend who was with us once], and street performers who kindly try to shake you down for money aren't so fun, but it's a tourist spot, what do you expect?

I had some really brilliant fried shrimp and chips that were quite overpriced at $9.50, but still delicious.  It's a good place to walk around, lightheartedly look at the shops, and take in the great view of Alcatraz.
author: Katie M.

description: What a great place to visit see culture and learn about San Francisco. For the best Irish coffee go to the Buna Vista Café. For a fun cheap tour take the $10 boat ride around Alcatraz (they try to get more but they will take $10). Then you can eat the best sea food of your life. They even have an old school arcade that is a trip to walk through and play old games.
author: Raven R.

description:
I love Fisherman's Wharf. 

I love all the great little shops there that you can buy some really inexpensive gear. I bought this great, what I call 'SuperFly Girl' belt buckle. It the big 'S' in silver surrounded in pink...totally bad ass.
author: Patricia V.

description:
Those tourists say the darndest things! 

Mom to boy gazing forlornly, camera in hand, at the spot where the Golden Gate should have been, were it not shrouded in fog: 

"Well, we'll just go to one of those junk shops and you can take a picture of a plastic bridge, how's that?"

Poor little piker.
author: Gwynnie P.

description: Yes it's full of tourists, I know, I know. Seafood everywhere, Jackie's heaven......Normally I hate crowded places, but I forgive this place. Love being surrounded by places selling fresh seafood.
author: Jackie D.

description: This is a great place if you are visiting San Francisco! There is a lot to do and see, just put on your walking shoes and go. There are a lot of novelty shops and good food all over. The seals are awesome to see and there are some great viewing spots for Alcatraz. My advise is to take a tour bus of the city if you have never been. It was a little pricy at $30 a person but you get your moneys worth and they take you everywhere you would want to go.
author: Steven W.

description:
I have had a love affair with the San Fransisco Fishermans Wharf since childhood.

Whether it be to browse the hokey shops, eat a clam chowder bowl or simply relax and watch the sea lions, the Wharf is always a destination that will be fun and relaxing. Watch out for the bushman, hopefully he doesn't scare you to bad. 

Yes, it might be touristy but it is still fun and there is always something to see. The end of pier 39 with the moon over the water and Alcatraz in the distance is a great place to have that late night make out session! 

Don't have any game? Don't worry, this city did all the work for you already!
author: Jay K.

description: when you think SF, fisherman's wharf always comes to mind.  crab crab crab! plenty of places for crab and clam chowder.  just walking by you can smell all the fresh crabs and seafood.  plenty of tourists, always busy.  all the robots on the streets. rrrrrrippppp.  a couple of the places i love are nicks lighthouse and pompei.  everything is so fresh.  can walk by on the sidewalk and get fresh crab sandwich.  bring a lot of cash!  lots of tourist gift shops.  plenty to see and do especially on a nice day out.  even in the summer its a bit breezy because by the bay.  its so highly talked about because its such a nice area. even locals love coming here.  crazy shirt is here, in n out, and others.  no more hooters though.  sad face...
author: Matthew G.

description: My last visit at the Wharf saw me on what was a perfect (crowded) saturday, having a bowl of ice cream from Dryers and watching all the street hustlers play their music or whatever else.  I do recommend going to the visitor's center because they give you a little coupon book  to go towards some of the countless stores you'll step into, or just sit on a bench and people watch
author: Jamarcus T.

description:
I live in a nearby town close to San Francisco and sometimes on the weekends I like to take the ferry over to Fisherman's Wharf with my family. Even though there's many other interesting things to see here in the city (Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz, the museums, etc.) it's fun to go there on a nice sunny day and walk around. 

There's plenty of stores and restaurants nearby and I've always had a great time when I've gone. Fisherman's Wharf is a pretty safe area and it's defiantly worth checking out. 

A lot of the stores here are tourist traps and most of the items are over priced. I've never bought anything from the stores there but there are some pretty nice things in them. You could probably find the same items somewhere else for a cheaper price.

Other than that, it's a really fun place to be at. There is usually bunch of sea lions near by and the area is always packed with people. There's a wonderful view of the Bay Area and Alcatraz and it's a very interesting spot.  Defiantly one of my favorite things to do in San Francisco.
author: Jackie R.

description:
THIS IS FOR TOURISTTTSSSSS!

Maybe it's because I live an hour away from SF and this place is pretty much my backyard compared to those living elsewhere but I just felt so.. touristed out! I never in my life felt COMPELLED like I HAD TO GO to Pier 39, and only go when my family and I have nothing to do.

I was really shocked at how many people did feel compelled to come here, like this was the number 1 stop of their vacation here in California (or for some in NorCal) Really? I mean everything here is so.. expensive.. SAVE YER MONEY!

I definitely can't deny that it's definitely something to look at. All of the fun looking stores kind of pull you into checking it out, and it pulls the tourists to overspend on souvenirs that they probably will forget about in a few months. I also like coming here around Christmas time to take a picture with the big tree and the prancing reindeer bush. I started taking pictures around this area for the holidays with my family a few years back and now its become a tradition! FUN!!

I DID try eating at the Crab house once here with my family and eating there pretty much sums up all of the dining in the area. Delicious and EXPENSIVE!!

ANYWAYS it IS a fun place to LOOK at.. but beware it is EXPENSIVE AS HECK!!! Try to keep your spending to a maximum of 0 dollars. You will still leave with the same experience, if not better, of those who did spend their money here.
author: Rebecca K.

description:
I know i'm being a little repetetive with my San Fran reviews but this is another place I must almost always visit when I'm in town!  there is so much to see and do!  street entertainers, wax museum, Ripley's Museum, check out the bread factory where they make sourdough breads into cute animal shapes! =D  and I LOVE the penny arcade!  they have some very cool and fun old school penny machines!  so fun to turn everything on!  and a great place to get some cool pressed pennies!  (I like to collect them for my scrapbooks!)

And if you get hungry there are so many places for a nice sit down meal or a quick grab and go snack!  

some people might complain that it's a little too touristy but I don't care because it's fun!  Anyone visiting San Fran must stop by here at least once!
author: Christine Y.

description: There were plenty of random chachkies as my buddy Ken G put it, but we still had to check it out. The whole kitschy atmosphere warrants a star in itself! Didn't get a chance to go to Ghiaradellli square or Kara's cupcakes nearby...if i ever HAVE to come back, i'll be sure to go get my sweets!
author: Michelle T.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of seafood, nor gloomy weather - and there were both during my visit.

the stars are for my friends who seemed to enjoy the hell out of the calamari and oysters. 

bleh.
author: Shanika H.

description: If you are in San Francisco you must go down to see fisherman's wharf once. Every trip I make it a point to go down there at least one time. I recommend going on a weekday not a weekend. There are great views of the bay and Alcatraz along with some decent shops. The weekends are overcrowded down here which makes it less enjoyable. There are some decent seafood places in the area, but I would go for  the views and the walking.
author: Scott M.

description: Good food..lots to choose from... Parking is like 8 bucks an hour.... There is garage on bay st about a block away from the wharf it's 20 bucks till 3 pm get there early.... We got there at 10am it was worth it!!!
author: Mike H.

description:
To beat the summer heat of the Sacramento Valley....my friend and I often go the city by the bay in San Francisco to feel that Cool Pacific Ocean Breeze...It is always cooler in San Francisco during the summer months...we often go to the Fisherman's Wharf to get a view of Alcatraz....the Pacific Ocean and the Pier...I love coming here because it is entertaining, lots of fun-filled things to do including bicycle tours...There are many food vendors selling crab and seafood even as burgers there which I thought was unique....

There are Sea Lions that rest and take naps if not playing...there are garage parking that charges  $5.00 and up which is good for the whole entire day...My friend and I usually leaves early morning around 9 am to beat the traffic in both Sacramento and San Francisco...and to find a great parking space...

We eat Tuna or Tuna melts every time we come here cause it's all great with great people and overall...great eatery's...Even our friends the sea lions and sea gulls have something to say...lol...i always have a great time with my friend when we come here just for the day...
author: Rudy E.

description: I really don't understand why Fisherman's Wharf is such a big destination in San Francisco.  It isn't particularly pretty, there may be some history there, but if so I totally missed it.  Other than that it's just a big ole' chain of souvenir shops and restaurants.  Granted, I didn't get to eat in any of the restaurants, so there may have been some delicious food that I totally missed out on.  However, this isn't so much of a tourist destination as a tourist trap.  If you want great views of the bay, just head down to pier 35, or pier 14 (which is waaay down) you'll get the same effect without the crowd.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
The famous Fisherman's Wharf! For the locals, an over priced, tourist trap. For the tourists visiting, I would say, this is one of the stops you have to make while visiting the city by the bay.

There are numerous shops, restaurants, and tours to go on while you're here. You can grab a bite to eat, shop for numerous souvenirs, and take the tour to Alcatraz island. 

There are seals the time we went and they were just hanging out at one of the ports, laying out, taking in the sun.

The view of the Bay is beautiful from Fisherman's Wharf, You can see Alcatraz and the Golden Gate Bridge and the Bay Bridge on a clear day.
author: Wes S.

description:
LA has Hollywood, New York has Times Square, San Francisco has Fisherman's Warf...here's what they all have in common:

-Ripley's Believe it or Not? Museum
-Hooters
-random chachkies 

No thanks!
author: Ken G.

description:
I'm from SF.

Actually Minus two zillion stars.

If this is what you want, knock yourself out.  This is NOT SF.

It saddens me when I see tourists here.  I am a native San Franciscan and while I appreciate your sales tax revenue, there are so many cabazillion things to do in SF and the Bay Area, why waste it at Fisherman's Wharf.

Sad....sad.  

Have you thought of Noe Valley or the Mission District or the Haight or the Castro or the beach or.......

Fisherman's Wharf gives me the creeps.
author: Sam P.

description: It's a fun place to visit and just really spend the day... better do it on weekdays so it's less crowded...  A lot of great interesting stores around.  Parking is quite expensive so get validation if you can...
author: Rose F.

description:
A friend who lived in SF for a while warned us not to go here. Said it was all tourists and no one who lived in SF actually goes there.  We had to see for ourselves.  Oh yeah, she was right.  Tourist Extreme!!!  I couldn't handle too much of it.  Not that I don't like people, but I don't like "tourists."  And I was a tourist of sorts, but these people are extreme.  And then there are all of the street performers and overpriced food and things.  

Do yourself a favor and and check out SOMA or Sunset if you want to see some nice parts of SF that aren't super touristy.
author: Taryn B.

description:
Too touristy.  I didn't really see anything exciting here other than too many tourists, most of whom are from abroad.  It's a great experience for them, but it was too congested, and had too many cliche gift shops.  There are more exciting parts of the city to visit, although parking in general is difficult.

Note about street parking - it's $3.00 an hour, 2 hour maximum, but they do take credit cards, and go in 5 minute increments ($0.25 per 5 minutes).  Public parking in lots is around the same price, with a $25-40 max per day.
author: Paul K.

description: A good spot to visit, because it is the beckon of tourism.  It is a great spot for walking, seeing the world-famous sites, and people watching. Make it a point to visit.
author: Jac H.

description:
It was like South Street Seaport without the schooner (sad!) but with way cooler shops.  Of course, they all cost an arm and a leg, but who needs those anyway?  VACATION!

This was great.  Be sure to see the sea lions.  You can hear them from a mile away!  

Some of the shops here are totally touristy, but some are pretty cool.  I went to a puppet shop expecting to buy a stuffed sea lion and ended up buying a moose finger puppet.  Go figure.  Anyway, it's a very cool place-- we ended up getting wine, then chowder, and then donuts that evening.  Walking along the pier just feels special.  Something you must do when in town!
author: J. K.

description: It is fun to walk and widow-shop here. Also, you can chose between fine seafood restaurants and street kiosk to satisfy any craving. The problem: too many chain restaurants spoil an area that should be an authentic neighborhood of San Francisco.
author: Olga K.

description:
I sometimes go down here to people watch, definitely a popular tourist destination.

Nice views of the bay and many boats with lots of street entertainment.

Besides all the crappy souvenirs, my only disappointment is that there isn't a fish-market(like Pikes Place in Seattle).
author: Ayall S.

description:
I know... I know... touristy... but guess what Californians? You know what's great about not being from California? We don't take the wharf for granted!!!

Sure it's busy in some places, but hell it's great for people watching! I could spend all day here just watching. 

My favorite spot was watching the sea lions sunbathe. But just looking at the ocean, the boats, and the jet skies. The warm weather with a cool breeze. This experience was surreal for this Chicago girl. 

When I come back to Cali, I will most definitely make another stop at the wharf.
author: Katie B.

description: Food here is delicious but there aren't many tables or seats for people to enjoy their food. There are also birds waiting to munch on your leftovers or crumbs.
author: Cindy L.

description: I love the Fisherman's Wharf. I love seafood and therefore, I come here to get my seafood fix on! There are so many restaurants and food stands to choose from. They have a lot of souvenir shops too so you can get your "I heart SF" stuff here. This is a tourist attraction so you will see people from all walks of life here. The prices are decent for the food but some restaurants can get a little pricey. Parking sucks and is hard to find. There's always a lot of car and people traffic so be careful!
author: Lisa N.

description:
Yes,Fisherman's Wharf is a nice place to come check out if you are a tourist. Sometimes locals might want to do something down here. 

There are a ton of restaurants(yums),shops,tours,museums,interesting people and plenty of fun things to do.Children even will enjoy the experience. 


To the point..


(Forgot the name of this store,but this was my point of this review which is below.The lady was nice and when I suggested she get some Family Guy items she giggled) 


I stopped into some place and looked around.They had all these funny shirts and things. When I approached the counter I had seen these ID's..these ID's were different,well they were celebrity ID's and I thought that was hilarious. I was looking at the Nick Nolte one the most,but that wouldn't fly,but I would do it..also I took the Austin Powers one "yea baby yea", "oh behave". How can you not love that one. I will still try and get into a place by placing my ID in front of the gentleman/woman whenever I go somewhere that they ask for ID's.

Oh,and Halle Berry...If I showed that one if I got carded they would look at it like "oh come on".. There were a ton of them too. I just got them for fun.A ton of cartoon characters too and I am not sure if you are a Pamela Anderson fan but I think I seen one there..not quite sure. 

Also,at a liquor store these might be fun just to be funny and make someone laugh because they usually just wave their hand and see it and say ok,thanks... location varies,personality and humor varies.

Funny,but would love to see someone walk in with a Nick Nolte one.
 I still think he is an ok dude thou...I was kind of upset there was not one of David Hassleholf with a hamburger next to him and a smile.

Still love him thou.
author: Dani D.

description: It's small compared to other fisherman wharfs for a coastal city. However, it's really cute. There are plenty of shops and seafood stands you can choose from. We enjoyed our time here just walking and looking around.
author: Nari L.

description:
Two Words: SUPER TOURISTY

To be honest, I only come here when I have friends coming from out of town and even then you practically have to drag me here kicking and screaming. 

I used to come here a lot as a kid to see the sea lions and chill out at Pier 39. I've even waited 4 hours for a lunch at Rainforest Cafe before. 

These days its saving grace for me is pretty much the sea lions and the bushman. The Boudin's here isn't even that great unless you wanna see different animals made from sourdough. Hog Island over at the Ferry Building is a much better choice for clam chowder, you might as well tack on some oysters while you're there.
author: Constance C.

description: For instant entertainment, go straight to the sea lions , they are funny creatures and it's a lot better seeing them vs animal planet . Food around there looks great and shops to see. You can spend a good 4-5 hrs there with $50 you'll enjoy you're stay there.
author: Sammy S.

description: It's smelly, there's bird poop everywhere, lots of bums & pan-handlers and crowded but you have to go if you're a tourist, at least once.  Grab some seafood from the vendors and eat it while standing up or visit one of the sit down restaurants.  Check out Boudin's nearby and walk down the Ghirardelli Square and get your free piece of chocolate and visit the cafe with yummy concoctions.  You can also catch the Trolleys here too.  Or take a ferry ride to Alcatraz Island.  Also, look out for the Bush Man.
author: Kim T.

description:
I give it 3 stars because I've been coming here since I was born. Mom is a North Beach native, so there is no opt out.

I give it -5 stars for the crummy bathrooms. Seriously, please install appropriate diaper changing stations in your restrooms (Pier 39, I'm talking to you specifically).

I love the wharf, and while no self-respecting native will ever visit here without being dragged here by their out of town friends/relatives, I keep coming back for more.
author: caryl r.

description: Full of  shops, restaurants, pigeons, seagulls, and tourists.
author: Sandy N.

description: Its nice, touristy etc....  In San Diego we have Seaport Village, same sort of hook up...  But, look, its still fun to shop and see some of the kookie shops they have.  I suggest you go - but beware the food, move on to the fish grotto for some of the best seafood you can buy....  CHOWDER!!!!
author: Dean P.

description: Fun place to hang out in San Fran.  Great people watching...
author: Mike S.

description: Like any place heavily visited by tourists, Fisherman's Wharf is full of both annoyances and guilty pleasures. You'll come to see the sea lions and boats and maybe stop to get a bite to eat. You shouldn't be  surprised by the the high prices or the crowds of obnoxious tourists that will plow you with their strollers because they are looking at the puppet shop rather than where they are going.  You'll find little gems like the saltwater taffy at Candy Baron and with things like the Musée Mécanique nearby, taking the trip down to pier 39 is worth doing.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
I didn't have time to experience it all, but the little time I had, I think I got the full experience of San Francisco.  Sourdough Bread bowl, Clam Chowder, Alcatraz, View of the Golden Gate, and wind... even saw a seal.

Parking is a little pricey, but its a tourist town... what should I expect?
author: Robert G.

description:
OK, total tourist trap - but 100% San Francisco.
You can't help but go there for the seafood - although overpriced - but very fresh!
author: Peter S.

description:
Seems like it would be a seafood lover's paradise (too bad I'm not a big seafood lover) with all the huge crabs and stuff. Brings to mind that scene from Aladdin when some random fishmarket guy shoves a fish in Jasmine's face. FRESH FISH! http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RW5n4sIOj9s Except at Fisherman's Wharf, they are more known for their crabs. 

My favorite part about this spot are the street performers. There was a guy and a girl playing the sax and keyboard when we went there. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fm6Np2yAdeU

And those random street hustlers. Gotta love them! Just learn a phrase in a foreign language and appear confused so they'll leave you alone. =) 

Across the street are the regular touristy stuff like Ripley's Believe it or Not and a wax museum. And of course McDonald's had to cash in so they have a restaurant there too. But I prefer walking further down to the In-And-Out Burger. YUMMY.
author: Julie A.

description:
I don't care if it's touristy. I absolutely love the Fisherman's Wharf. There are so many restaurants and little shops. I love it. The thing is to be careful. After a couple trips, you realize that many of the same souvenirs sold on the Wharf can be found in Chinatown for much less moolah. But, they are cheap, so don't waste your money anyway. The nicest souveniers can be found in the shops at Pier 39. No matter what you do, it's fun to walk around here, day or not. Check out the seals at Pier 39. Take pictures. Take a look across the Bay to Alcatraz. It's actually much farther than it looks! Also, if you are lucky enough to catch some street vendors or musicians. Check it out! I have bought original photographs, hand-made earrings, and even caught a fire-dancer one night.

The Verdict: Man, the Wharf is awesome. I wish I could go right now.
author: Cara S.

description:
Someone was liking us on this day.  We enjoyed a painter's dream of a day on the bay, on Fisherman's Wharf.  San Francisco IS such a hottie of a city, and the Wharf affords you some excellent vantage points to it's sexiness.

Walking the wharf's entirety is a must.

There's plenty of transit opportunities--we took the cable car and the other train-car to get here and leave.

Yes, it's hella touristy.  We were tourists.  But dang---places like this warrant being a cheezy tourist.  It's a must.
author: Corey G.

description:
touristy.  I can watch the sea lions for hours, they are a pretty entertaining group of mammals.  The way they grossly sneeze, or bark at each other, walk over each other, its always good for a laugh.  

Other than that, I would say that if you are visiting, it would be worth a visit to get some views of the bridges, bay, sausalito and alcatraz.  Get some SF clam chowder in a sourdough breadbowl and do some sightseeing tours.

If you are from SF, I would stay clear of this entire area, its just too packed with tourists and you can find better food and shopping elsewhere in the bay area.
author: Kevin W.

description:
My best friend's boyfriend who lived in SF for a few years, refuses to take her to the Wharf. So it was my duty to cross that off her list and show her why she'll never return again. It's like the bastard child of Times. Sq. and all the tacky beach-town boardwalks of the east coast with kitschy souvenir & candy shops, overpriced mediocre food and circus reject, sidewalk entertainment. 

I saw a couple get their pants scared off by the Bush Man last year so this year I was on high alert for him, refusing to walk along certain streets, and ready to punch him in the face if he jumped out at me.

The sea lions are fun to watch but smell like rotted ass. 

It's a place to keep the kiddies entertained while you take in the magnificent views of the bay - which is hands down, the best reason to come here. But like every other great city and their tourist attractions, you should at least visit once to say you've been there and to form your own opinion.
author: Lizz K.

description: This is a upscale tourist trap.  Having said that it is in a beautiful setting with many options to eat and shop.  It is ideal for the tourist who has never been to San Francisco.  The seal watching makes it worth the trip.
author: Lori S.

description: Really nothing like it in the United States and if you can see past the masses of tourism and look at it for the amazing beauty it offers this is a magical place, surely family friendly in every way!
author: Mr B.

description: I never get tired of the wharf...and the seals...arf arf arf arf *clapping hands*. I'm only 30 min away and I never grow tired of coming back and acting like a tourist. To be quite honest, I don't buy much from the shops. It's more so the eating and window shopping. I also think the shows are entertaining and classic.
author: Judie H.

description:
I give Fisherman's Wharf a few stars because my dogs like to go there and people watch, get their pictures taken from tourists, and maybe get to eat some potatoes out of the chowder that I might buy so we can all get into the spirit of being there.  We do this every few months or so...anything for them.

They like to bark at the sea lions, walk around, and once we went to Ghirradelli, and they got to lick the whipped creme from my sundae.  I go here only for the dogs.  It is all about them.
author: Lisa M.

description:
All you hear is tourist trap.  If so, I love it.  Everytime that we visit S.F. we are there.  
The restaurants are great, the shopping is fun.  The experience is totally awesome. 
What views!  Alcatraz, Golden Gate, sailboats galore.  Great parking nearby, so cheap compared to Chicago and other large cities!  The atmosphere is great.  Street shows nearby, purely a great experience no matter how many time you will visit.
Love it!
author: B W.

description: Definite sight see for the toursit and still fun for locals.  Check out the super classic arcade with games from before video exhisted, enjoy the shops, lots to eat and see sea lions off the docks and the occasionl dolphin in the bay!
author: Jo A.

description:
Reminds me of Reading Terminal Market in Philadelphia, Lexington Market in Baltimore, and Pike Place in Seattle. I think every big cities have these kind of markets.

Pretty lively. Pretty fun. A lot of restaurant and random stores. A lot of random street performance. There's a bushman there. Bunch of parking spots in the area.. that's a plus. It's not free though.

There's this huge sourdough bread store, which displayed how their bread was made into funny shapes. They let few windows open so passer by can smell their sourdough bread.

Definitely a must go to place when you are at SF as a tourist.
author: Yohann S.

description: Fisherman's Wharf is the place to take your family when they come in town. Its a tourist hot spot and there are a lot of fun things going on! Lots of food, vendors, shops and great views. If you dont like big crowds, do not attempt coming here! I have been many times, and no matter what time of day or day of the week, it is CROWDED. But that's also what makes it fun! It has a great energy about it and people watching is at its finest. Make this one of your stops if you are visiting the Bay!
author: Laci S.

description: Great time window shooping but it would have been better if it stayed oppen a bit longer. We had a great time none the less. Thre seals were huge!
author: Richard R.

description: Yes, parking sucks here and is way too expensive.  But nothing screams SF more to me than Fisherman's Wharf.  It brings back lots of fun childhood memories and I love ordering a freshly steam crab and chowing down.
author: Lai T.

description: Tourist Trap, But hey, just like Chicago's Navy Pier; They were doing some construction on our visit, but Thank heaven for In and Out burger!
author: Manda V.

description: The best thing about the wharf is watching that scary shrubbery dude scare the tourists.
author: Vlad A.

description: It's like Times Square but in San Francisco instead of New York.  Okay, okay, it's better than Times Square because there are sea lions.  But don't let the sea lions fool you, it's still a total tourist trap.  Walk through, take a pitcute and leave.  No need to try the overpriced chain food or buy the overpriced tourist shirts.  Just go and wave hello to the sea lions.
author: Jennifer B.

description: Super touristy spot.  Worth going at least once or twice, maybe even thrice to make sure you check it all out.  As with any tourist spot, expect it to be pricy.  But you'll have fun.  Try the restaurants and if you get there for the food trucks, get yourself some seafood!  Crab on!
author: Wyman L.

description:
Pros: 
A variety of shops for visitors to get there San Francisco trinkets. 
Short walk from Chinatown, Little Italy and the Marina.
A excellent spot to take a photo of Alcatraz. 
Excellent area to take a morning stroll.

Cons:
Everything is overpriced. 
Namcoland has been replaced by a Hard Rock Cafe.
There's always a line to hop on cab.
Getting mistaken for NFL pro shop worker.
author: Gabriel A.

description: Great place for food, touristing, and watching the sea lions. However as a tip: if you hate crowds and/or get panic attacks like me... YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED!!!! Popular tourist spot and it gets crazy packed. Bf prepared, bring a friend to keel you calm or don't come.
author: Alyssa C.

description: As a New Yorker, I feel what people are relating to that there's so many tourists in this area. Just like how I feel when I pass by Times Square in NYC. But as a New Yorker visiting Fisherman's Wharf, I am a tourist. And it's true there's just a lot of people here. It's a pretty neat place to visit, many places to shop at and grab a bite. Most importantly I used so many quarters and pennies for those stretched penny machines. I'm like seriously addicted to those penny machines!
author: Sandy C.

description:
I visited San Fran for the first and only time in November of 2008. It was unusually warm from what I hear (mid 70s) All I know is that I loved being up there. We stayed in the Nikko Hotel and took a cable car to Fisherman's Wharf. We started out at 1 Embarcadero and walked way, way down. It was such a cool, fun, fantastic place to hang. The bay, the statue of Gandhi, the tchotchke shops, the restaurants, the colorful locals, the huge Christmas tree, the view of Alcatraz. It just felt like we were having the most iconic day. I wish I could say more, but it's been a few years now. All I know is that whenever I think of my trip there, when I don't think of the outstanding wine country tour we took (which left from Fisherman's Wharf), I think of the Wharf itself.

That said - the place that does bus tours out of the wharf that's right across from that big seafood place? Use them. When I told our concierge we wanted to go on a wine tour but didn't want to rent a car to drive up there ourselves for reasons of imbibing and not being from the west coast, she set us up with this company. All I know is that we had a bus driver pick us up, drive us there, and bring us back, all the while providing commentary that was both hilarious and informative. We went to 3 vineyards, where all of our tastings were included. (Reserves were obviously available for a supplemental fee.) It was $75. It was the best $75 I've spent to date.
author: K B.

description: Fisherman's Wharf is one of my absolute favorite places to visit in the Bay Area.    There are dozens of places to eat - obviously, the freshest fish possible, street performers everywhere, souvenir shops, the ferry to Alcatraz, and my favorite, Pier 39 which hosts dozens and dozens of lounging sea lions giving us all a lesson on how to properly chill out in No-Cal.  Best part though is not being more than a stone's throw from Ghirardelli's chocolate shop.  This is a great inexpensive way to spend a day in San Fran.
author: Stacy F.

description:
I remember coming here as a kid with my parents spending the day/ It was always an adventure. Now that I am a grown up I feel the dirty dinginess of the wharf and I don't know why its so appealing to so many people. Parking is over priced and ridiculous. There are always the same street folk doing funky dances, painted up in gold or silver paint. 

It's fun I guess but not my favorite thing to do when in the city.
author: Michelle C.

description: I always have a great time when I come here its a great place to explore and look at things ... if your bored there is always something to do here .. they always have entertainment and a lot of food :o) parking can be pricey so might as well stay the day and explore ...
author: Farrah F.

description: Fisherman's Wharf is a tourist trap! Even so, they have little shops that you can buy your family members gifts to send home. One advice that I can give you is to shop around. You may be able to find the same thing cheaper at another shop.
author: Tommy H.

description:
NOT FOR ME!!!!

Wow!  I wish I had some warning of what it was going to be like here, I would have done more to prepare myself.  If you have ever been to TJ, Mexico... then you have some idea what you are in for.

Hoards of people!!!  I mean Hoards!!!  People walking in front of moving cars like they are queens and kings.  The smell is horrible and I'm not talking about the Ocean or the seafood.  There is ONE area for bathrooms, that's it!  The line is horrible!!!  Make sure you go to the bathroom just before heading here, put your kids in pull ups, and maybe a some depends for the adults.  

We had spent time on Lombard Street and decided to wait to use the restrooms at Fisherman's Warf... NO WAY!!!  

We were mostly there so my son could go on the USS Pampanito, so while my son and hubby were on the submarine, I found a couple of port o potty's that were in good condition!  After they got off the sub, I sent them there too.

It was so congested we didn't want to look for a place to eat, so we just ate at Johnny Rockets (paying customers get to use their, buzz you in to use, restroom).  

We can say we were there and the ships were great as well as great views of Alcatraz (we didn't have the time or $$ to go there).  So I got some good pics.

I don't think I will return... too many people, too dirty, and it just brings out the worst in people.  Oh street performers were cool, but caused a ton of traffic and congestion too.
author: Cyndi S.

description:
VERY VERY interesting.. I would want to come back. The only thing I don't like is parking is expensive. :( && I didn't get tickets for Alcatraz!! Seafood is very good here. fun place.. but kinda crowed or maybe because I came here on a sunday afternoon..

very fun.. A LOT of different things to do and places to eat.

BTW: claim chowder isn't all that great as I expected there..
DISAPPOINTED!!
author: Lilly N.

description: Your typical tourist trap, yet I can't help going there at least once a week since it's always full of life and colorful people... My absolute favorite is the Musee Mecanique, which for me is basically pure nostalgia as I play a game of Tekken 3 on an authentic arcade machine.
author: Nicolas S.

description:
One star.

I am local. I think I had been to Fisherman's Wharf a few times growing up. My Mom and I went there one day to see all the museums and just hang out. It was fun back then, since it was like going to Disneyland.

Now, as an adult who has seen and experienced the City for all it is. This place sucks. It's a tourist trap. The food is really bad and the only thing worth seeing is the Musee Mechanique and Alcatraz.

I wouldn't take Out of towners here. It doesn't represent the City. I'd take them anywhere but here. To Ocean Beach...to the Academy of Sciences, etc. This isn't the City...this is a horrible money trap.

My b/f loves places like this. I guess he doesn't want to go down to Mr. S leather with me.
author: Lana P.

description:
I hate tourist trap. es I do and why am I giving Fisherman Wharf a 5 star? Surprisingly, I actually liked it!

I only went there to look for the famous bush man scaring the poor  people passing by... BUT I couldn't find him. :-(

I'm coming back... please read my review for pier 39, it should written here but pier 39 seem to e the center point of Fisherman's Wharf, so it's better to write it there instead of here.

5 stars for being an excellent place to people watch!

Oh! by the way, if you're looking for souvenirs, I was told that the Fisherman Wharf isn't the best place to find them. Ashbury Haight is the place to go! I haven't been there because I'm the ditz who asked the reception "where" at midnight, the night before I fly back home...
author: Matt M.

description:
My Ratings:
Quantity - 4 Stars
Quality - 3 Stars
Price - 4 Stars 
Location - 4 Stars 
Service - 3 Stars 
Speed - 3 Stars

My Opinion/Story:
One of the reasons why we visit SF is to enjoy a beautiful day outdoors eating seafood at the wharf. I love the craziness and the tourist attractions. I love that the pier has character and entertaining views. Lots of places to eat, see and do.
author: Cherryl D.

description:
For all its carnival happy-fun-time attractions, this place is oddly depressing.

Based on what you see here, it seems most of the tourist families who visit here are looking for the following:
1) Trinket shops, many of which sell stuff that has NO discernable link to SF (like "funny" bumper stickers). Because it's not what you see, it's what you buy.
2) Overpriced, bad chain restaurants (the Rainforest Cafe)
3) Overpriced, bad seafood restaurants "with a view"
4) Junk food you can get back home (Cold Stone Creamery)
5) A few "tourist attractions" (Ripley's Museum) that are merely clones of what you find in other tourist trap zones

Not that they should take the kids to the Tenderloin, but come on, are there really that many visitors to SF who can't be more imaginative than this? I wouldn't be sorry if a tsunami wiped it all away overnight - after everyone evacuates the hotels, that is.
author: S R.

description:
I didn't want to believe the hype about this place being a Tourist Trap but with some knowledge from traveling I knew it when I saw it and I definitely saw it. 

But there was one redeeming trait of this place: the Bush Man / Guy. 

This was one of the few things I enjoyed about Fisherman's Wharf. 

It was just a guy with some broken bush branches and he would just sit along the street. It looks really dumb if you are paying attention but most tourists are too busy looking around or on the cell phone to notice this guy sitting there. As you walk by he jumps at you and screams!!! 

It's hilarious because some people are literally crying in fear! 

Lame, but it's a job I guess.
author: David N.

description: Coming from Seattle I can safely say the fisherman's wharf is the exact same thing as a California version of Pike Place Market...except twice as big haha XD !! There's tons of stuff to do here...a lot of great seafood and little open market resturants that serve up the daily catches most notably clam chowder.....two down sides however....NOTHING is cheap...it is pricey as heck...I'm saying like 12 bucks for a 16 oz bowl of chowder pricey all throughout the wharf....and no matter how sunny it may be u better bring a jacket! cuz the sea breeze is FREEEEEZING!!!....OH, ALSO! a homeless man hid behind a park bench......he was painted in black and gold with tree branches sticking out of his jacket..he jumped out trying to grab my leg and scared the living shit outta me....I did a running jump and screamed like a girl and about a hundred people laughed their asses off at me.... -_____- ......then I threw a quarter at him.
author: Tay H.

description: Wow is this place crowded now. But it is a tourist spot, so it is expected. It was fun to check out.
author: Tiffany G.

description: Good place to people watch. Impossible to find parking at a fair price.
author: Katie L.

description: Tons of stuff to see as well as several shops to check out while you're there. There's tons of dining in the area and places to walk around and see that don't cost you anything at all. You can view Alcatraz from the pier, as well as the sea lions hanging out barking at one another, as well as people from all over the place doing whatever it is that they do. We bought souvenirs here since there were tons of small shops with gift items which drove costs down versus buying these items at the hotel that we stayed at or the airport. The only restaurants places that I can vouch for in this area was the Boudin Bakery (delish!), Bubba Gump Shrimp Co. (Okay, not stellar - great view though),  and Ghirardelli's (although we just got desert here). There's an old arcade at Pier 42 I think it was as well as a couple of old ships that you can tour for a small fee. All in all it was worth it and definitely a place to go to check out while you're there. If you want to ride the cable car, I don't recommend getting on here. You can jump on it up the street without having to wait in a crazy long line to get on it. There are boat tours and bus tours that leave from this area as well as the little yellow 2 seater bike car looking things.
author: Nathan G.

description:
Wish I could give Fisherman's Wharf a LOWER score. I have lived in San Francisco for 36 years and I can say with certainty--this is not San Francisco.

The food is godawful and the retail joints belong in Phoenix or Orlando, not SF. Except for the Hyde Street Pier there is NO REASON whatsoever for folks to be wasting time and money here. I am embarassed by it. If you're a visitor to SF, please skip this area and go directly to the Ferry Building on the Embarcadero, or walk through Golden Gate Park, or have dinner in Hayes Valley and then catch an evening at the opera or symphony, or visit Yerba Buena Gardens and the Museum of Modern Art. Those places are much more representative of our great city.
author: Denny S.

description: Vibrant, touristy strip. Lots of different people, shops and restaurants make this a cool spot to check out. Also got to see Bushman in action, a local street performer who sits behind some shrubbery and startles people as they walk on by. Apparently, he's been doing it for a while. That was entertaining.
author: Peter D.

description: Fun little place, very touristy, overpriced, always packed, great views and kinda has a Coney Island/Boardwalk vibe.
author: SoCalSkippy ..

description: Great place to spend the day. My bf and I came here first thing in the morning making our way from Chinatown. The walk was scenic and relatively short. Great spot for sightseeing Alcatraz, Treasure Island, Golden Gate, and the Pacific in general. Saw some great street performers and was enchanted by all of the novelty shops and trolleys that pass by this area. You definitely have to make it a point to visit IN-N-OUT when you're in this area. My only regret is that I didn't go more than once. Another great "find" in this area is the amazing seafood. Definitely make sure to have some crab before you leave. I went to Fog Harbor Fish House -- great pacific view and delicious meal to go with it. If you keep walking alongside Fisherman's Wharf you will also be able to see Ghiradelli square. By the end of my day, I was able to watch the sunset along the small beach in front of the square. Really can't get better than that.
author: Esther C.

description: I don't care how cold and touristy Fisherman's Wharf gets, I love it. In fact, I think all the tourists are actually a part of this place's charm. There are so many cute and fun shops to peruse through, and if you get really bored, there's always imitating the sea lions! You may get a bunch of weird looks from those around you, but I guarantee you'll get a kick out of doing so. Taking pictures is always a good thing to do here, too. The scenery of the bay is gorgeous, particularly at night when you're able to catch glimpses of moonshine reflecting off the water :) Whether you go with family, friends, or a lover, it'll be worth the trip.
author: Kara C.

description: Seriously, skip it. Spend your money and time on cultural and educational spots in the city. The Wharf is the biggest tourist trap ever. I guess it is part of what makes San Francisco the place that it is, but I don't get why people like this place.
author: Jeromy W.

description: Only wanted to aware everyone of a BushMan who is hidding somewhere in a Fisherman's Wharf and scare people) He scared me so much recently! Watch out. Actually, it was fun!
author: James D.

description:
If you like Branson, Pidgeon Forge, the Wisconsin Dells or Myrtle Beach, you'll love Fisherman's Wharf.  It's packed full of people, trinkets and "turn-n-burn" restaurants.  It's the poster child for all tourist "must see" places around the world.

I've been to San Francisco several times on business, and just visited with my wife and daughter on vacation.  I knew they needed to experience Fisherman's Wharf at least once in their lives so we walked from Ghirardelli Square along Jefferson St. to Mason St.  The walk was enough for all of us.  No one needed to visit any of the shops or "seafood" restaurants.

There is so much more to San Francisco and the Bay area than Fisherman's Wharf. So if you have to see it, just walk through at a brisk pace without stopping.  If your time is limited, don't go at all.
author: David B.

description: This is  fun place to visit when visiting San Francisco.  There are plenty of shops and restaurants around to keep you entertained for quite some time.
author: Larry C.

description: Walked here when my kid and I were trying to make it to the embarcadaro. Seemed closer so we went straight instead of right. Our big huge bad. The view was pretty but I could give a damn about boats or blubby sealions. I did enjoy the people watching from the sidewalk as we walked away. The art galleries were cool too....
author: Carolyn T.

description: trying to figure out how to begin this review makes me shudder in horror at my memories of this place.  over-priced food, stores that sell nothing but expensive crap that no one needs/wants, restaurants that boast the best seafood, yet are really just overpriced chains, too many people......ugg.  San Francisco is great because there is such a variety of residents, neighborhoods, restaurants, and historic places and if you're spending your time and money amidst hundreds of other tourists in a place where no San Francisco resident would ever go - Fishermans Wharf - then you're really wasting your trip.  You might as well go to Disneyland or Navy Pier or Chucky Cheese because you're going to get exactly the same experience; it couldn't matter less that you are in San Francisco when you are at Fishermans Wharf.
author: Luthien N.

description:
Had a nice touristy walk through here and checked out the shops and restaurants. Ran into the infamous bushman as well.

The breeze when you walk through here is great, it's not really a local hangout, us tourist's were packed shoulder to shoulder.

Most places are a little pricey, I wanted to try the restaurants, but I didn't want to eat the entire trip.
author: Eric H.

description: Three days and I miss it already!!! Make yourself a favor and allow the whole day for this place, definitely a spot to relax and forget about everything bothering you. Just smiling people rushing everywhere, live music, stores, big and tiny, sky and water!... Amazing!
author: Natalia B.

description: Had a blast at all the shops and amazing restaurants a must see in San Francisco!
author: G M.

description:
It was bright, sunny, and amazing here the day that I went.
I tried to greet some people on some tall ships, though it did take me a while to find tall ships, but the gate was locked, I didn't know that I had to pay, but I would've just to see some good tall ships. I would've told them that I was from the Adventuress and showed them my turk's head.
I love the boardwalk with the stores. Love, if only I could go here all the time. The boardwalk, if we even have one, in Seattle needs some improvement. But then again, it is Seattle, and the waterfront is beautiful the way it is.
author: Ivy L.

description:
read some comments below, seems like I'm not the only one that don't like the place very much
first of all, there's not much things to do ( not like biking across the golden gate bridge) maybe it is suppose to be a place to slow down and relax. I just don't get excited and felt quite sleepy especially after eating
second, I had trouble finding the bathroom. ( some restaurants don't  have one while some others only allow customers to use their bathroom)  There's one public bathrrom opposite the crabs stands, but very long line. 
third, maybe it is because a lot of people recommend this place, the more you expect, the more you get disappointed, for me, the experience of visiting fisherman's wharf is only taking a look at what it looks like and so leaves no regrets
author: Qifei S.

description:
The Fisherman's Wharf is a sight to remember. There is all kind of things to do around here, there are all the tourist traps, the restaurants, the museums, the lefty store, and of course Alcatraz.
Very family oriented, great seafood. Also, Ghirardelli Sq.
If you are in town this is a must see.
author: Ali C.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf: #1 SF running route on Monday nights.

Running through the Wharf is the best time to be had on Monday night in the city, guaranteed.  You get to detox your demons from the weekend while also enjoying the bustling tourist scene.   While huffing and puffing away, you feel superior to the tourists both athletically (all kinds of gasps and exclamations can be heard in passing about how many "joggers" there are in San Francisco) and fashionably, as chances are that you are more stylish in your Lululemon running gear than 99.9 % of those SF sweatshirt-sporting tourists.  

You will catch the finest sunset EVER on the top of Ft. Mason with GG Bridge as backdrop starting at Marina Green.  If you do an out and back, the return incline on that hill will kick your butt in the most rewarding way.  

The Monday night Wharf running strip offers more live music, from the blues tunes blaring from the restaurants to the banjo playing street musicians, than the entire 26.2 mile length of the Nike Women's Marathon course.  I don't think I remember mimes, spray can artists, or the latest addition to the wharf scene- a four-man steel drum band playing Bob Marley covers, on that over-rated Nike course either.    

If you are to add this run to your route repertoire, I issue this caution: there is no longer A lone BUSHMAN; there are now TWO BUSHMEN on the fisherman's wharf strip.  Watching everyone's reactions from yelling, to laughing to freaking out, as well as contemplating the devastation and destruction that would occur if bushman #1 one confronted bushman #2 for taking over his turf, is pretty amusing and will keep your mind busy on your last leg. 

The Wharf is THE place to be on a Monday night, guaranteed.
author: Kerrie T.

description: Avoid at all cost, friends dot send harms way and this is one perfect example. Total tourist trap - cheesy easy listening music live, whopping parking fee, over priced food venues, and junky souvenirs. I've been there, done that, have drawer full of shirts. Unless you are really into touristy thing, and must do, I'd say skip it & spend some quality time at other parts of town. Your feet and wallet will thank you after you go home.
author: Tom I.

description: It was my second time here in eight years.  Nothing has changed and is still a great place for everyone to meet up.
author: Cathaleya C.

description: Fun..touristy and a must for visiting San Francisco! It's a great experience for all visitors.
author: Ken N.

description:
As a tourist or a guide to visiting friends, going to the Wharf is a must even if it screams tourist trap.  I've noticed that the south side of the sidewalk along the Wharf area is more touristy han the north side.  ie) the tacky shirts, flatten bottles (really?) etc.  It reminds me of a classier version of Niagara Falls's touristy area which makes me feel like it's draining my soul. 
The convenience of it makes it nice, being the transition between Pier 39 and Ghirardelli Square. I'd recommend grabbing some clam chowder either along Taylor & Jefferson (there's a bunch of stands and restaurants) or Boudin Bakery.  If you grab a bread bowl of clam chowder at one of the stands, there's not much seating (ie - you can sit along the pier but there isn't formal seating) and it costs about $6-7/bowl.  At Boudin, it's more expensive at $8.95 but there is designated seating if you don't want the hassle of finding a place to sit. 
Walking along the Wharf is fun the first time because of the novelty and the bustling tourists but I guess I've been here too many times to appreciate it like I used to.
author: Tanya N.

description:
I'm sure that most locals hate this tourist attraction but from an out of townees perspective, this place is great!  

My friend and I took the bus here (excellent transportation system!), and our first experience was witnessing men painted in silver doing robot dances to techno.  In my mind, this sort of talent should give our Seattle street folk a run for their money!  It was great and very amusing...I sort of got lost in a trance!

We stopped along the shops to browse but rarely bought anything.  We hit up the taffy shop and walked around, just enjoying the sunshine and fair type atmosphere.  Eventually, we took the tour to Alcatraz and then stopped to appreciate the seals bathing in sunlight.  Adorable!!

I of course did take note of some swanky looking fellas but mostly there was just a happy fun vibe that helped initiate my lust for San Fran!  This along with some other experiences in other parts of the city make up what I call, my 'Cali Love Affair'....an addiction in the works. (Heart).
author: Delilah R.

description: Yes, this place is your typical "tourist trap" - but who cares? We were tourists and wanted to check it out.  They have plenty of seafood restaurants to eat at that have great water views.  There are lots of little shops that sell San Fran themed items. You even get a nice view of alcatrez.  I'd recommend starting your trip out here. There are a lot of different tours that start off here as well.  You also can hear the sea lions from here. Unfortunately we didn't get a chance to go see them, but maybe next time. Fisherman's Wharf is also convenient to the famous cable car that takes you to Union Square as well as Ghiardelli square.
author: Stephanie I.

description:
I do enjoy the San Francisco piers, and when I'm in San Francisco I have to hit Fisherman's Wharf for the food.  Of course I always hear of the hype back in Elk Grove that they have the best Clam Chowder.. I think it's ok, nothing AMAZING, but it's good in the bread bowl ($5.75 outside stands).
The seafood is good, but it's very minimal, but it's a tourist attraction and it has everything you can check out from the Wax Museum, to the vintage quarter arcade, back to the Ripley's Believe it or not museum!  There are many shows and performances out on the street corners as well such as the Bushman (Man who hides behind a bush and scares people walking by), Spray paint groups (they paint abstract pictures usually of the town), Robot men (Bums in silver spray paint), and the usual many personalities of people walking the pier!  This is usually my get away from home and I love every part of it, even the uphill walk to Ghirardelli factory!
author: Christopher N.

description: Yumm.. Clam chowdah!!! No other place will you find a more bubbling melting pot than at the wharf. The crowds and workers here are so divrse its amazing. Of course it's a major tourist trap, but it has a lot to offer, and yes it can get pretty expensive but that's why you save up to go right?? Anyways, the people surrounding the wharf with all their crazy but fun talent make it what it is. You have guys dresses up dancing, people singing, playing guitars and drums, and home made instruments, and they all fit in to this San Fran hot spot. I always find myself making my way to the Pier Market, it's the place with the blue canopy, they have the best sourdough bread bowls... Yummm, A bowl of clam chowder always makes my trip to Frisco complete!
author: Louie B.

description: Just a series of trinket shops that all have the same trinkets. Iit is not worth finding parking then wading through the crowds. There is a reason that the locals stay away from this place.
author: William P.

description: Best place to get clam chowder in sour dough bowls! The street entertainers are interesting and we love to hit Ghirardelli Sqaure for some yummy ice cream to complete our stop! Check out some pictures and tips from our last day trip that we blogged about at http://peekabootravel.com/blog/?p=518
author: Kara M.

description: What a tourist trap! Please do not eat at any chain restaurants here. Do yourself a favor and go to one of the little stands! There is a cool retro penny machine arcade here that you must visit and of course you gotta take one of the boats over to Alcatraz.
author: Vanessa T.

description: Touristy but cool. We loved the sea lions.
author: Jim N.

description: This place is a must see if you are a tourist, but other than that, it's not all that great. Maybe because I've been here a ton of times, or maybe it's because it's just boring. They do have a Bubba Gump Restaurant, and another store with deep fried donuts so that is a plus... Take a minute to check out the sea otters because that is all you need. It stinks! :)
author: Melissa B.

description: If you feel the need to go to just about the most touristy spot in SF, then this is your place. It's everything you could possible hope for in that aspect. Just think "it's a trap!" and you'll understand the rest when you visit.
author: Phil M.

description: Lots to see, interesting area. Fairly safe with lots of restaurants.  Definitely worth seeing if you're visiting the bay area. Fun for all ages
author: Dominic D.

description:
Four cause I give 5 to everything.

This is part of the life, culture, tourism, scent, and feel of the city.  Like it or not, it is a huge part of what makes our city, as well as employing many of our residents.  I know it isn't anything wildly exciting, but what they do is add to the energy and vibrance of our city, whether they are barking like carnies from their front doors, or selling an overpriced glass of wine.

The Wharf is not just for tourists.. it is for city folk that need to be reminded of the tourist experience once in awhile!
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: The best part / only good part about fisherman's wharf is the kickass congregation of sea lions.   Everything else is a tourist trap.  If you're from NYC, think south street seaport.  I almost got suckered into a 25 minute massage inside what looked like car wash tanning bed.... I love you San Francisco, but I don't love your fisherman's wharf.
author: Opinionated B.

description: Nice tourist attraction. We have been here several times and enjoy going for the food and to people watch. Great restaurants and there is something for everyone. They also have great street performers. They have a trio of brothers from England that are acrobats and their show is fantastic. Get out there have some crabs, get some awesome dessert and chocolatel.  You could definitely spend the day and spend very little.
author: Tom P.

description: This is the place for tourist and locals alike. I mean you able to have a drink and people watch. The crabs are a plenty and lobsters. Steamed right in ftont of you hot not really fresh is my guess as it was not crab season and they were all on ice. It's nice place to spend with friends or partners or even with the family. But remember place for tourist means big $$$$.
author: yvonneandscott j.

description: Tourist trap hell during the day, but a bout of insomnia one night gave me a morning of wandering through this place a 7 am, and it felt like the beginning of 28 Days Later. It was wonderfully eerie, and I'd really only do FW that way from now on. There were only 4 sea lions (but that day, there were only that many during the afternoon too).
author: Ryan L.

description: What a great tourist spot!  Plenty of souvenirs, shops, food, walking space, artists, and specially... friendly people.  San Fran folks are very nice to tourists from my experience.  I asked for directions around the Wharf and everyone was friendly and took their time to explain to me annoying directions.  I wish I lived here!
author: Camilo G.

description:
ok it's got 5 stars 'cause i live in SF and i am biased. I agree with the other posters that say Fisherman's wharf is NOT just for tourists. Though i admit to staying away from it most of the year. But its a fun part of SF to see even if you have lived here for decades.
Trick, poor man's (or tourists) Lunch at Fisherman's Wharf: 
One mini-loaf of our famous sourdough bread, have them slice it like a sandwich would be sliced, one crab cocktail (get the kind where the cocktail sauce is seperate from the crab). Spread cocktail sauce on both sides of the bread, spread the crab on one side of the bread utilizing all the crab - put the top piece of bread on and munch! Tasty - filling - and just plain GOOD! 
Don't forget to check out grotto #9! 

One more thing - watch out for any very human like statues down there some of them ARE NOT Statues at all and some have scared the heebie jeebies outta me! IN FUN! Worst is my husband once tipped the guy a lot of money for scaring me like that...hmmmmm..... 

One of the hardest things about living in SF is being able to tell your touristy family what to go see, we live here we take it for granted i think but Fisherman's Wharf is ALWAYS a goodie!
author: Candy H.

description: It's hard to talk about all the things you can do on Fisherman's Wharf without going on for several paragraphs.  This was my 2nd trip here and this time we brought our son along since he is old enough (6 years old).  The views you can get of the bay, the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz, and San Francisco is phenomenal.  We took some great photos just from walking the piers at Fisherman's Wharf.  There are always some sea lions to look at and watch them play together.  There is a bush man who hides and waits to scare people.  The food here is just amazing.  They also have some really nice shops, people selling art, additional attractions like the wax museum, and the Ghiradeli chocolate factory.  From here you can go on boat tours to Alcatraz, or cruise under the Golden Gate Bridge.  There are small faster boats, and large comfortable boats to take tours on.  So many fun things to do here, we spent one entire day here finding all the things we could do.  Driving anywhere in SF is not fun, but be warned if you take a Trolly car you may have to wait in a long line to leave depending on the time you choose to head out.  Really nothing bad to say about this place, it's an obvious tourist attraction, but it's nothing like anything we have in Las Vegas so it's a lot of fun to experience everything the place has to offer.
author: Jesse C.

description: The best clam chowder spot here is Chowder Hut, located near the fisher man's warf sign.
author: Valerie D.

description: I was told to go here to see the wildlife. While they were not active I did have a lot of fun people watching. This place is a must even though it is a bit of a tourist trap ha ha. Great experience.
author: Darcy M.

description: Really don't like fisherman's wharf because its just so expensive!!!!!
author: P G.

description: I love fisherman's wharf!  Great seafood and clam chowder with sourdough bread.  Interesting people (artists, musicians, eccentrics, etc) are just part of the fun.  There are also some cute shops to check out.
author: Safa S.

description: Fisherman's Wharf is to San Francisco what Times Square is to NYC, in that it's full of tourists foolishly looking for an authentic part of the city, gift shops selling every little Chinese made nick-nack they could possibly get the name of the city onto, all the while restaurants are pumping out some of the most mediocre food at the highest prices they think they could get away with charging.
