On the flip side, like Times Square it's a recognizable part of city, is fun to walk around and people watch, and is full of a rich history. Unlike Times Square though the prices aren't as outrageous and there's a few things of substantial value to check out. Besides the view and the people watching I loved MUNI's historic F line, Musee Mechanique, and this one spray paint artist on the street doing amazing works of art in the matter of minutes and selling them for as little as $10. If you're into sourdough bread then Boudin is here and if you like steamed crabs then Fisherman's Wharf is still great for that as well, otherwise the wharf isn't the best eating destination in the city.
author: Matt E.

description: very touristic place, chaotic but nice. don't forget to try a crab chowder
author: Andrea M.

description: This is definitely touristy and very crowded. It was okay. Should probably go just to see it and get some seafood just to say you have been there. Not a place I need to visit again.
author: Ellie S.

description: It was fun walking along through the little shops, but I didn't buy anything - everything looked way too touristy and kitschy for my taste.  It was nice to see the sea lions while we were there, but oh boy do they smell!  No one had ever mentioned that and I was unprepared for how much those things stink!  Consequently we did not stay very long to watch them play, but they were very cute.  The view of the Bay from here was also pretty fantastic.  We grabbed some sourdough while we were there from one of the nearby bakeries (I think it was Boudin?) that was pretty good.  All in all it was one of those things you have to do while you're in San Francisco, but I don't think I'll feel any need to re-visit the next time I'm in town.
author: Erin D.

description: Clam chowder, clam chowder, clam chowder... Make sure to get it in a bread bowl! Doesn't really matter where you go, I've eaten at a few and all are relatively the same.
author: Sean S.

description: If you're local, avoid at all costs. Scratch that. Avoid if you have the slightest bit of common sense, regardless of where you're from. Horribly tacky, expensive, crowded and filled to the brim with Euro tourists. Not for me. In fact, if San Francisco ended at North Beach (or Barbary Coast like in the olden days), imagine how much better this city would be.
author: Chase S. K.

description: There is not much to say about Fisherman's Wharf that is probably not known by word of mouth, or written in another review.  This is a must see and a must eat for first timers and infrequent SF visitors!  Fresh crab or clam chowder in the bread bowls are a must!
author: Brett F.

description: My boyfriend would never take me here on our visits to SF because as a former resident he said that "it was for tourists" and that it was horrendous. I just thought he was being a stubborn ass, until my best friend took me there on our last trip out to SF. Baby, I'm sorry I ever doubted you. If you took Coney Island, mated it with Times Square, and added a couple of sea lions for stinkiness, you would get Fisherman's Wharf. Crowded, loud, tacky shops...meh I say. Some of the views are kind of nice.
author: Jenn C.

description: Fun area! As the other reviews say, its definitely for tourists but always nice to visit. Your visit wont be complete to San Fran without getting a bowl of clam chowder. Its a fun atmosphere and there are many places to eat and shop in the area.
author: Melissa W.

description:
Tour of San Francisco by bus- $50
Buying a novelty Golden Gate Bridge paperweight- $25
Eating a lobster roll while being swarmed by seagulls - Priceless

The place had lots of fresh seafood stalls but lacked anywhere to sit. The views of Alcatraz were nice though somewhat hazy through the fog.
author: Jeffrey Y.

description: Love the easy parking (lot across the street), and the yummy chowda in a bread bowl. Tons of places to buy your souveniers too.
author: Nilam P.

description:
It's a total tourist trap, but at least it knows it is and is actually kind of proud of it which makes it less like a tourist trap. If that makes sense.

When I first came to San Francisco, my hotel was literally a block away from here. The minute I got settled in my room I walked down here and grabbed myself a bowl (made of sourdough) of clam chowder. Sitting on the wharf slowly eating my boiling hot chowder while watching the scenery all around. Perfect way to begin an experience in SF if you ask me. 

It's practically the real center of the city in some ways. You can see the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz, Angel Island, Treasure Island, Sausalito and Oakland all from pretty much anywhere on the Wharf if you look over the bay. Look into the city and you can see pretty much the whole entire city (almost literally, it's built on a million hills). There's the Piers, each of which serve a unique function. Ghirardelli Square is only blocks away, and the Powell-Mason cable car line is underneath that. There's the F-Line Streetcar which takes you to the Embarcadero and Market Street. It's also in walking distance to Lombard (but that's up very steep hills so you might as well just take a bus or cable car to that). 

There's also a vibrant street life in this area. You see all kinds of tourists and then there's the locals. You have street performers, burnt out hippies, activists and people involved in the fishing industry among many others. Sometimes you just need to take a stroll in this area in order to be entertained. 

My hotel in particular (Holiday Inn Express) sucked, but I am so happy that I stayed on the wharf for my first time in San Francisco. I'm not sure how I would have gotten a real feel for the city otherwise.
author: Philippe C.

description: Def a tourist spot. There was a small free juggler show going on in the center. Lots and lots of shops - small boutiques souvenirs, food.
author: Ms. Reviewer M.

description: Kinda scummy. Dirty streets. Difficult to drive to unless you have all day. We had high expectations so maybe that's where we went wrong. We did get some good pictures of Alcatraz Island. There are seals. And seagulls.
author: Mario C.

description: It's an overpriced tourist trap but I love the views, the streets & all the hustle & bustle of San Francisco. Nothing like grabbing a quick latte & talking a stroll down the Embarcadero.
author: Sean S.

description: You can't visit San Fran and not go over to Fisherman's Wharf.  It is seriously one of the beautiful, most scenic places I have been to.  I went here on my first day ever visiting California.  There are a ton of restaurants, shops, entertainment, bars....really everything :)  The walk from my hotel to Fisherman's Wharf was kind of a bitch because we had to walk up a huge ass hill.  But it was totally worth it.  Lots of photo ops here too.  There are museums, stands with people selling jewelry outside.  And you can see Alcatraz and The Golden Gate Bridge too.  Amazing
author: Erica H.

description: I don't really get it, I mean, its like what San Francisco wants people to think it is like, to people who don't live there. The warf area is nothing like the mission, or soma, and not like the polk gulch at all. Is that a good thing? Well that is up to you. I try to keep my family away from here when-ever they are in town Five stars, super cool! Next time you are down here, look for the neck keyboard guy, tell him that Johnny sent ya.
author: John R.

description:
I think people tend to get Pier 39 and Fisherman's Wharf mixed up.  

Coming to Fisherman's Wharf seemed similar to going to the Redondo Beach pier to get fresh dungeness crabs.  There are a multitude of small stalls selling seafood. You can SMELL it in the air, that odd mix of appetizing yet slightly too fishy scent.  There are other little stores nearby selling miscellaneous souveniers and other stuff.  It's a nice place to walk by and check out the stands, but I don't think I'd want to eat outside on a bench like I saw other people doing.
author: Janet P.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf is NOT just for the tourists!  My kids and I enjoyed a beautiful stroll down Fisherman's Wharf today- a tourist in our own city and had a great time doing it!  

We started at Ghiradelli's for ice cream.  There was a huge line at the original store but if you are willing to settle, there is smaller Ghiradelli's cafe a bit futher into the courtyard.  With ice cream in hand and dripping down their t-shirts, we hit up Starbucks for Mommy's caffeine fix!  (Note- this is one of the FEW places with a decent restroom stop!)  We stopped at the taffy store next- my sister is going to remind me about that show (Honey, we're killing the kids) when she reads this!

Walking down Beach street, we stopped to watch street performers doing magic tricks and even better- the robot guy painted in silver.  My little Tevin put a dollar in his cup and he came alive- my kids loved it!  It was also entertaining watching the dozens of street artist doing caricatures- they seem to have gone down in price...only $2.75 per person now.

Less entertaining was how the parking meters seem to suck up your money!  My kids and I were in disbelief that we were only getting 1 minute for each nickel we put in!
author: Judy K.

description: I love Fisherman's Wharf. There is so much to see. Great place to shop, enjoy the ocean, site see and spend time with the family. Highly encourage to either take public transportation. Do not try and take your car, it is a mess to drive in an to park. Very relaxing and just all around great. Love bringing my family here.
author: Roxanne S.

description:
ok I admit it ... I kinda like Fisherman's Wharf...... it's kinda fun to walk around (as if I haven't walk enough!) and watch tourists in awe of the beauty of San Francisco. Makes me proud to live here * although I'm a newbie* LOL
the clam chowder is yum and watch the overweight birds fighting over the leftover sourdough bowls is even more fun!
author: Maria H.

description: Great Food! We had Fried Shrimp & they were good without a lot of batter. We enjoyed the food and had no complaints. Will return!
author: RanGirl A.

description: Yes, one of the most touristy traps that I have ever been to. I feel like it is the main tourist attractions of all San Francisco. I don't know what it is about it. Maybe the wide view of both the Bay & Golden Gate Bridge, the ocean landscape, or the rows of places to eat, which mainly consisted of seafood, like the awesome clam chowder. I went maybe two out of the five times I visited San Francisco, but that is all I needed. I'm not one for crowds, so two visits were more than enough.
author: Charlene F.

description: The sea lions are the highlight, but you can  see them in more natural settings at various locations along the coast. If you like junk food and souvenirs, you're in luck. Otherwise, there's more to SF than this.
author: Robert P.

description: Hello welcome to the SF tourist trap. The place is packed with people and the food is over-priced and just not that good. Will probably avoid this place the next time I am in SF. Go experience the other neighborhoods before you expose yourself to this area.
author: Steve M.

description: Always fun to go to . There are quite a few places to eat at and shop. The Hawaiian jewelery is nice too.
author: Darlene Q.

description: A must see for anyone visiting the Bay Area for the first time.  Residents of the Bay Area should also make time to visit the Wharf every now and then.  I hadn't been there in a while.  Was good to go back.  Saw some stuff I'd actually never seen before.
author: Billy D.

description: Cheesy and touristy - probably best for families with kids.  Worth a walk through, if only to people watch.  I recommend skipping the chain restaurants and flagship restaurants - eat from one of the food booths/trucks if you want to experience true, local seafood.
author: Dee K.

description: Omg, has San Fran lost the will to provide a family friendly environment?  We had been planning a trip through San Fran for years.  We got a overpriced hotel close to fishermans ward so we could walk around the tourist spots easily.  On the first day we were headed to pier 39 and the first thing we see is a guy with a ponytail on rollerblades with no clothes on.  My kids saw his private parts.  I think they are still in shock.  Not too much further into our day a couple more naked guys were just hanging out.  We saw a policeman and told them about it and they said welcome to San Fran.  They said it was against the law to be naked in public but they didn't enforce it.  We decided to be more vigilant and try and shield our young daughter from being exposed to older naked men.  As we proceeded to down the street we were approached over and over and over avian by homeless people, who were pretty aggressive seeking money.  During this adventure we smelled marijuana smoke the entire day, all over.  Needless to say, we didn't stay 4 days I. San Fran.  We didn't even stay the night.  We decided not to expose our kids to public displays of nudity, public use of drugs, aggressive panhandling and in general lawlessness..  This is the last time we ever go to San francisco.  no wonder the city is broke.
author: Master B.

description: After lunch we decided to walk around and shop a bit before heading to San Jose. One of my girls saw some baby clothes and decided to get something for her little niece so we ended up hanging out for a bit. There were cute, funny, over the top items that we saw along the walk, and then something caught my eye. There was a particular store with quite a few baby things so we chilled there until she decided what to get. Along the way we took some silly pics with the big statues of animals and people hahaha and we just had some silly fun. Shopping is always good!!!
author: CJ J.

description:
Tourist trap.
Good for boat rides.
Nice walk to the Ferry Building.
author: Kool B.

description:
The Wharf is the only place in the City where San Francisco's legendary bay meets the land, in a spot where people can get up close to its post card beauty, without having to have port clearance (and still have the view blocked by another pier).  Sure, there are a lot of places to get down to the Bay, but the Bay off the Marina isn't quite the same; and that beyond the Bay Bridge is almost a different bay, it certainly isn't the same San Francisco.  I've always gone to parts of the Whaf, especially the area around Aquatic Park.  

As I've told legions of tourists, when warning them away from the restaurants, it's not that the food is bad--it's just that at the prices you pay, you could eat at the City's finest restaurants, but the Wharf food is as mediocre as any in the Four Corners.  Still, a freshly boiled crab is about as simple as great food gets.  Add a loaf of Boudin's Sourdough , some cheese and wine from Trader Joes, and you've got San Francisco in a bag.  The thing to do, is what too many tourists fail to do...WALK AWAY FROM THE PARKING LOT!!! There's a killer view less than a block from the crab pots, and the tourists are all eating their gooey chowders on the curb amidst the cars, buses and fumes.  The Boudin Museum is worth the money, a great way to learn about San Francisco, sour dough, and there's a bread tasting at the end, and right after that, another nice little restaurant bar.

In any case, I've never had a bad drink in the Wharf.  It's a thing about this city, the food can be crap, but the bartenders seem to know what to do about it.  I love the bars, upstairs especially, at Fisherman's Grotto.  Old dark wood-like plaster ambience.  The oyster bar at the newest version of the Eagle Cafe is a nice place to sit for oysters and cocktails, and I've had nice appetizers there as well.  

For atmosphere, I like to walk out on the piers.  There are no "Keep Out" signs, and you can go quite a ways off the streets, among the fishing boats, and out on Pier 45, and if you're up early, you can see the fish come in.

The Maritime Museum is closed for another year, but that was always one of my favorite buildings in the City, and the fact it held a great little maritime museum, full of ship models and local history, only made it better.  Hopefully, given they are spending so much money, and actually planning it as a museum (as opposed to stuffing one into a bath house) it will be so much better this next time around.  And then, of course even with its decay, the Municipal Pier is a delight.  What better place to stroll hand in hand, steal a kiss, or even get more involved, on a high backed concrete bench, than there?  The City glimmers in icy detachment so close you can almost touch it, the lights of the bay seem so remote, and in the distance, that Bridge...  the moon...  the stars...

If the food were better, if there was more a feeling of neighborhood, instead of selfish greed on the part of the merchants; if the buildings were closer to architecture, or at least something like a local vernacular, instead of a strip mall expediency plastered with some of the biggest names in the City; if more of the Wharf had the spirit the view  suggests, even demands; I'd give it four or five stars.  I give it three (instead of two) because the "F"line goes there, and brings the locals who might someday force a change for the better.  All that said, the locals who avoid the Wharf are little more than fools, no different than the tourists who eat their food on the curb.
author: Paul T.

description: This place is a tourist trap . There's a lot of stores that sell lame souvenirs and a lot of stores that are just tourist traps . Only thing really interesting here are the street performers . Not a good place to go for locals but if you're a tourist , it's probably a good idea to come here at least once ...
author: Eileen L.

description:
The wharf is a completely different society within San Francisco. My favorite is strolling jefferson street to watch all the characters; the rat on cat on dog, the breakdancers, the clown, and watch out for the bush man, he'll get you good.
Most of the restaurants are still family owned which gives it a homey feel.
I personally love the view from the aquatic park. You want something to do that is truly local. Jump In! I dare you
author: ebony k.

description: You cannot leave the city without stopping at Pier 39 for clam chowder in a sourdough bread bowl! -- Always delicious!!
author: Rachel S.

description:
It's a little sad that Fisherman's Wharf is so often dismissed as solely a tourist destination and generally eschewed by most natives. It's true, that while it has become a corporate playground designed to wring every last penny from hapless tourists who think they are having a genuine San Francisco experience there's still a little Old San Francisco under the shiny patina of Boudin and Hooters. It's mostly the smell of fish but at least that's authentic San Francisco.  I like to imagine it as it was a hundred years ago when it's streets were teeming with drunken seamen (tee hee) and syphilitic prostitutes. Yes, I'm a romantic.

Although the seamen no longer represent the true spirit of the Wharf, there is now an equally compelling sight which is the tourist trade itself. I'm talking hours of free entertainment. Hours. Despite the reputation San Francisco has earned as being full of freaks, you'd be hard pressed to find a more bizarre and surreal environment as the present day Fisherman's wharf. Where there were once grizzled fisherman there are now Germans hunched over steaming Sourdough bowls full of clam chowder. The syphilitic prostitutes replaced by non-ironically mulleted children wearing "Git 'er done!" t-shirts and packs of silver clad statue dudes. Once the center of the seafood market in San Francisco, one can now readily purchase Alcatraz psych ward sweatshirts, (how insensitive, REALLY!) $5 carmel apples and, on my most recent visit, I spied a pair of pink hot pants with "I have the pussy, I make the rules," written on the ass. We've come a long way baby.

So, five stars for the spectacle of the human condition. Minus one star for the Bushmanhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Famous_Bushman. Yeah, he's gotten me before. Fuck that dude. Seriously. FUCK. THAT. DUDE
author: Josua P.

description: Awesome place. Way too many people....but lots of fun. Check out Boudin if you can. You will love their sourdough bread.
author: Surajit D.

description: This place is famous all over the world so a description about what it is seems like a waste of time. I will then focus on what to look out for. Watch out for crowds regardless of rain or shine or weekday or weekend. It doesn't matter. It will always have plenty of tourists. Fisherman's Wharf, not to be confused with Pier 39, is older and therefore has smaller, narrower sidewalks so beware of being occasionally pushed of the street. Don't forget to visit the Musee Mechanique (separate review), it's one of the highlights of Pier 39. Lots of great shops and restaurants! Great for tourists!
author: Rylan C.

description: nice place to take pictures of Alcatraz...any tourist should check it out when he gets to san francisco
author: Derick A.

description:
years ago... 

as a little boy... 

i pissed on myself while playing Pole Position in Fisherman's Warf...

I had to go, really had to go, but no matter how I shook, jumped, shimmeyed and danced my Pole Position skilz kept me going...

Please god.... let me crash.... let it end...

But no... not until I wizzed and promptly dumped a soda on myself to cover it up...

for some reason I just can't have fun at Fisherman's Warf now. it must be all the damn tourists! The wax museum is cool though, and so is Alcatraz... I bet the inmates pissed themselves too, but they didn't have soda to cover it up.
author: Zeke S.

description:
Overall it was ok.  I liked it from a tourists stand point of never seeing anything like this before. But overall the majority of it was over priced food and TONS of gift shops, also over priced. I would check out Chinatown for souvenirs, much better prices.

A few things in the Warf (there is plenty more to see & do though):
-Alcatraz, a must see.  
-Aquarium by the Bay, I would skip it. Their website is more impressive. -Ghirardelli Square, don't go before 11 nothing is open.  
-In & Out Burger, a must try. Remember to order it Animal Style! 
-Bourdin Bakery, good over priced food w/horrible service.  Buy some of their sourdough, it is excellent.
-Sea Lions, probably the best part!!
-The Bushman, definitely a must see!! So funny! Keep and eye out.

Overall it is a must experience if your a tourist and understandable why I only saw other tourists.
author: Stephanie K.

description: It's a touristy place, I know, I know, but I LOVE IT.  The jumbo lobster, the proximity to Hard Rock Cafe and Ghiardelli Square, and some local bars with live music.  I'm a fan.
author: Rose L.

description: A great place to go even if you're not a tourist.  There are interesting shops and sidewalk events that take place here.  It's very lively and you can get some good food here!
author: Ian F.

description: I just came here on a freezing cold day during a torrential downpour. Not only was I able to purchase a warming scarf for $5, but they had umbrellas on sale for $3.
author: carrie c.

description: For almost four years I've avoided this part of town.  Of course you pay an obligatory go see at some time, but until today I never really walked through it.  Fisherman's wharf is touristy, nobody can dispute that.  There were giant talking shrimp, beckoning you to come eat them, a lady belted out her fleece vest 2-for-1 at more than one crosswalk crossing, and it is sort of both sparsely populated, and dense with people.  But, walking through there was a good reminder that next time I'm visiting somewhere, hopefully far away, I'll remember to steer out of these places and find the real amazing things that lurk outside of all the false novelties.
author: Kathryn M.

description: Sure, it's touristy as all get out *but* it is a verty pretty neighberhood and all of the toursits and hawking aside there is a sort of 'old san francisco' charm that still ingers on the foggy air in the wharf....plus the only in and out burger in the city is up here....and when you combine that with the stupid bushamn it all equals out to about three stars...
author: Francis K.

description: cool but watch the one way streeets lots to do.
author: Robert C.

description:
Hey, it's not all about restaurants and souvenir shops. The wharf is still a working fishing port with drag boats, herring gill netters, salmon trollers and long liners. Check out the boats. The wooden ones with a beautiful clipper type flared bows are called Montereys. They were  made by Italian immigrants and had their roots in Mediterranean hull designs. Some of them were built 80 years ago and still earn a living. Fish are still unloaded at pier 45, often early in the morning while you sleep. Many fishermen who have departed the wharf never returned, long before the dangers of commercial fishing became glorified on the Discovery Channel. One incident is burned into my mind. A wharf based boat full of albacore tuna was sinking off Half Moon Bay in a storm during the 1960s. It was  beyond the reach of Coast Guard helicopters and could not stay afloat long enough to be reached by other boats. They had no life raft. The crew radioed that they were closing the doors and "going down with the ship". With all the bloody tuna aboard they knew they would be shark food if they tried to stay afloat in life jackets. The bodies and the boat were never found. In 1986 the wharf based drag boat Jack Jr. was run down by a tanker off Pt Reyes with the loss of the entire crew. In that tragedy, the skipper's last words, captured in an emergency radio transmission later replayed on news broadcasts, were, "Oh, my God, you're going to hit us!" The tanker kept right on going and never even stopped or searched for survivors. The captain of the tanker was charged with a crime but got off on a legal technicality. 

I fished with my Dad out of the wharf during the 60s. We had no radar and no life raft, couldn't afford either one. How we went from the wharf to the Farallon Islands and Pt Reyes, time after time in the dark and in pea soup fog without getting run down by the numerous freighters that come in and out of SF still amazes me. Someone was watching out for us. 

Next time you are at the wharf, take a good look at the boats. There are sport fishing boats and a few pleasure boats, but there are still a number of hard working fishing boats which call Fisherman's Wharf home. Today they have radar, GPS, life rafts, satellite distress beacons and other devices to improve safety, yet danger still claims lives and boats in the seas off SF. In 2002 the Reliance went down with all hands and in 2004 the Relentless disappeared without a trace.  Next time you are down at the wharf, pay some respect to those who paid the ultimate price to put fresh fish on your plates. Their names are on a plaque in front of the little chapel on the pier straight across the water from Scomas.
author: Mark M.

description: Good God what an unholy nightmare! From the depths of Hell itself comes this most unnatural travesty, this most vile testament to all that is tacky and cheap. The lesser angels of our nature hath ne'er unleashed such a wonton scourge upon God's green earth as this tourist trap! Lo, lo and take thy leave of this most heinous nightmare. Leave this place and never speak of it again. For should God Himself strike fire upon the Earth, ridding the world of Man's most cruel and vile undoing, then, surely, this Fisherman's Wharf should stand as the first sign of impending apocolypse! Lo! Lo! Burn thine San Francisco sweatshirt and novelty license plate! And never speak of this tourist trap again!
author: Dave S.

description: My aunt and uncle were in from Chicago last month and they just had to go to Fisherman's Wharf.  Of course I drew the shortest straw and had to take them.  God I hate this place.  Anyway to make a long story short I got pick pocketed here!  They got my wallet with $200 in cash and my credit cards.  By the time I realized they had racked $1500 in charges.   A**holes!  I will never go back!  This place is always packed with lowlifes and tourists.
author: Kayte M.

description: tourist trap, but if that is what you are in to, go for it.  plenty of the usual suspects, mediocre food, some things for kids to do, street performers.  truly nothing to write home to mom about.  like i said if this is the kinda thing you fancy, i mean you no disrespect, just not for me...
author: Nick S.

description: This is a good place when visiting SF. I went recently because i haven't been there for so long. There's lots of shopping and restaurants. The best part was there was this homeless dude on the bridge and he has this huge branch of leaves. He would hide behind it and scare people as they walked by. It so was so funny.
author: Garrett L.

description:
This place has been there since 1935;  menu all seafood, of course.
food quality is good -  service is consistently poor;  it has been poor
each of several times I've been here in the past four years.

Prices a little high-  this place only survives because it's on the wharf
and tourist business keeps it going.  Of course, a few SF residents,
like me, do go there sometimes.

Recommended if on the Wharf;  don't go out of your way to eat here.
author: Richard D.

description: tourist trap. but man does it have a nice scenery. easy to get around the good places too.
author: Leocris L.

description:
When I first saw it staring me in the face I couldn't help but be a little intimidated. The giant metal crab in front of The Fisherman's Wharf was looking at everyone who past it or walked in front of it. The San Francisco bay is full of cool stuff like the Ripley's Museum, the Wax Museum, and Alcatraz. By far my favorite part is The Fisherman's Wharf the smell of seawater taffy and seals fill my nostrils and for once it smells kind of nice. Everywhere I look is restaurant I want to eat at or store with something I want to buy. It was amazing. 

 At the Wharf there is some pretty cool places to eat one of my favorites was the hard Rock Café. Everywhere I looked I saw the guitar or signed record of someone famous and the food and service was great. If you collect autographs the place you want to go is The Field of Dreams, they have possibly every great autograph a sports fan would ever want. Another great part of the Wharf is the Taffy Barrel; it literally has barrels overflowing with amazing salt-water taffy and other candies. Another cool thing about the wharf is all the seals that wash up on the little rafts. They are always fighting each other to get a nice warm spot to lye down on and feel the warm summer sun on their bodies. Believe me if you ever go down to San Francisco visit the Fisherman's Wharf you will not be disappointed.  I give this amazing place a 5 out of 5 it is hands down won of my favorite places I've ever been to.
author: Holy Rosary S.

description: For all the bazillions of tourists coming here in droves and packing Pier 39, Ripley's Believe It Or Not! or any of the other tourist traps, I have news for them - there is a real, honest-to-god fisherman's wharf here, one that the tourists never see, and I discovered it last night during one of my lengthy night hops. From the Marina Green I crossed Fort Mason, came out at the end of Van Ness and strolled through Aquatic Park and out to the Wharf area. Had a burger and fries at In-n-Out (came in  just as they were fixin' to close) then moved on. Strolled past the row  of tour/fishing boats with glamorous names and  then veered left, onto a deserted boardwalk, past a few seafood restaurants... There, along the boardwalk, was a fleet of San Francisco's commercial fishing vessels, those hard-working boats without which there would be no seafood restaurants to go to. It was quiet here, and the air smelled of day-old fish, but I didn't mind. I strolled on past a small Mariners' Chapel, then out onto the fish processing piers, empty now and dotted with derrick cranes used to haul the catch out of the boats. A few of the processing plants were still busy even at 2 a.m., and I could glimpse the bustle of activity inside the cavernous warehouse spaces. I  was at the heart of San Francisco's fish processing district, the real Fisherman's Wharf. So think of the fishermen the next time you sit down to enjoy steamed mussels or Dungeness crab. Think of the people who, day in and day out, tirelessly bring you the bounty of the sea. Or even visit the fishing piers yourself - despite the fish stink, it is a rather humbling experience.
author: Froggy V.

description: Fisherman's warf is a great place to hang out if you are a fan of seafood.  I've been going there for years and had a lot of great memories of going there as a child.  I tried most of the resturants there and found my favorite one to be Pier Market (in Pier 39).  After a full meal I would enjoy a nice stroll to Gharidelli for a Ice Cream sunday for dessert.  You really can't beat this place,  the food, the sights, the sounds, the people,  and did I mention the food?  This is definitely the place to be if you are a seafood lover (yes the clam chowder at Boudins is acctually really good, much better then almost all the resturants).
author: Roast D.
